[[File:Russian Empire (orthographic projection).svg|thumb|250px|The [[Russian Empire]] at its peak in 1866, including the spheres of influence; this territorial expansion largely corresponds to the extent of contiguous exploration by Russians.]] This is a '''list of [[explorer]]s from the [[Russian Federation]], [[Soviet Union]], [[Russian Empire]], [[Tsardom of Russia]] and other Russian predecessor states''', including ethnic [[Russians]] and people of other ethnicities. This list also includes those who were born in Russia but later emigrated, and those who were born elsewhere but immigrated to the country and participated in its exploration activities. At {{convert|17075400|km2|sqmi}}, Russia is the [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|largest country in the world]], covering more than a ninth of the [[Earth]]âs land mass. In the times of the [[Soviet Union]] and the [[Russian Empire]] the country's share in the world's land mass reached 1/6. Most of these territories were first discovered by Russian explorers (if, of course, we don't count indigenous peoples of inhabited territories). Apart from their discoveries in [[Siberia]], [[Alaska]], [[Central Asia]] and the [[Far North (Russia)|Extreme North]], Russians have made significant contributions to the exploration of the [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]], the [[Pacific]] islands, as well as [[deep-sea exploration|deep-sea]] and [[space exploration|space]] exploration. For the full plain list of Russian explorers on Wikipedia, see [[:Category:Russian explorers]]. See also the [[list of Russian and Soviet cosmonauts]]; several [[cosmonaut]]s, who've set [[List of spaceflight records|important records]], are listed here. ==Alphabetical list== ;Areas primarily explored: {| |{{legend2|#dfffdf|[[Siberia]]/the [[Far East]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}||{{legend2|#DFDFFF|[[Alaska]]/[[North Pacific]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}||{{legend2|#FFF8E7|[[Europe]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}||{{legend2|#FFE8D5|[[Tropics]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} |- |{{legend2|#F0F8FF|[[Arctic]]/the [[Far North (Russia)|Far North]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}||{{legend2|#ffdfff|[[Antarctic]]/[[Oceania|South Pacific]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}||{{legend2|#FFFFD0|[[Central Asia]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}||{{legend2|#F0F0F0|[[Space]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} |} {{Compact TOC}}__NOTOC__ ===A=== {|class="wikitable" |- !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center| |'''[[Valerian Albanov]]'''
(1881â1919)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Imperial Russian Navy]] officer, lieutenant, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Albanov was '''one of the only two survivors of the ill-fated 1912-14 [[Georgy Brusilov|Brusilov expedition]]''', the other being [[Alexander Konrad]]. They left ice-bound ship ''St. Anne'' and by [[ski]], [[sledge]], and [[kayak]] crossed the [[Kara Sea]], reached [[Franz Josef Land]] and finally were rescued by [[Georgy Sedov]]'s ''Saint Phocas''. The data about ice drift of ''St. Anna'', provided by Albanov, '''helped [[Vladimir Vize]] to calculate the coordinates of previously unknown [[Vize Island]]'''.Valerian Albanov. In the Land of White Death

A glacier in [[Severnaya Zemlya]] is named after Albanov. Either Albanov or Konrad is a prototype for a hero in the novel ''[[The Two Captains]]'' by [[Veniamin Kaverin]]. |align=center|[[File:Kara Sea map.png|120px|thumb|center|The [[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Pyotr Anjou.jpeg|100px]] |'''[[Pyotr Anjou]]'''
(1796â1869)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Imperial Russian Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], hero of the [[Battle of Navarino]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1820, as a lieutenant, Anjou '''described the coastline and the islands of [[Eastern Siberia]] between [[Olenek]] and [[Indigirka]] rivers and mapped the [[New Siberian Islands]]'''. In 1825-26 he participated in describing the northeastern coast of the [[Caspian Sea]] and the western coast of the [[Aral Sea]].[[Russian Biographical Dictionary]]

[[Anjou Islands]], the largest group in the New Siberian Islands, bear Anjou's name. |align=center|[[File:New Siberian Islands map.png|120px|thumb|center|[[New Siberian Islands]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Danila Antsiferov]]'''
(?â1712)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[ataman]], explorer of [[Kamchatka]] and [[Kuril Islands]]''' |Danila Antsiferov was elected [[Cossack]] ataman on [[Kamchatka]] after the death of [[Vladimir Atlasov]]. He was '''one of the first Russians to visit [[Kuril Islands]] and describe them in writing''', including [[Shumshu]] and [[Paramushir Island]].[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]

A cape and a volcano on the [[Paramushir Island]] and one of the Kuril Islands bear Antsiferov's name. |align=center|[[File:Paramushir, Atlasov, Shumshu - Landsat 7.jpg|80px|thumb|center|[[Paramushir]], [[Atlasov Island|Atlasov]] and [[Shumshu Island]]s]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:AnuchinDN.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Dmitry Nikolayevich Anuchin|Dmitry Anuchin]]'''
(1843â1923)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, anthropologist, ethnographer, archaeologist, explorer of [[European Russia]]''' |In 1880 Anuchin '''researched [[Valday Hills]] and [[Lake Seliger]]'''. In 1894-95, joining the expedition of [[Alexei Tillo]], he again studied Valday. Anuchin '''finally determined the location of the [[river source|source]] of [[Volga]]''', the largest [[Rivers of Europe|European river]]. He published a major work about the [[relief]] of [[European Russia]] and founded the Geography Museum at [[Moscow State University]].[[Dictionary of Scientific Biography]]

[[Anuchin (crater)|Anuchin]] crater on the [[Moon]], a glacier in [[Novaya Zemlya]], one of the [[Kuril Islands]], a mountain in [[Ural (region)|Ural]] and Anuchin Institute of Anthropology of [[Moscow State University]] are named after Anuchin. |align=center|[[File:ÐÑÑÐ¾Ðº ÐÐ¾Ð»Ð³Ð¸ 20.jpg|120px|thumb|center|The [[river source|source]] of [[Volga]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:VK Arsenyev.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vladimir Arsenyev]]'''
(1872â1930)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''military [[topography as the study of place|topographer]], explorer of the [[Far East]], writer''' |Arsenyev '''wrote a number of popular books about his journeys to the [[Ussuri]] basin''' in 1902-07, where he was accompanied by [[Dersu Uzala]], a native [[Nani people|Nanai]] hunter. Arsenyev was the first to describe numerous species of [[Siberia]]n flora; he produced some 60 works on the geography, wildlife and ethnography of the regions he traveled. In 1975, the joint Japanese-Soviet movie ''[[Dersu Uzala (1975 film)|Dersu Uzala]]'' by [[Akira Kurosawa]] won the [[Academy Award|Oscar]] for the [[List of Academy Award winners and nominees for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign-Language Film]].[http://vld.ru/ppx/Krivsh/Arsenev.htm Vladimir Klavdievich Arsenyev and his heritage] by Sergey Krivoshenko {{ru icon}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}}

A glacier on volcano [[Avachinskaya Sopka]] and [[Arsenyev]] town in [[Primorsky Krai]] are named after Arsenyev. |align=center|[[File:Dersuuzala.jpg|80px|thumb|center|[[Dersu Uzala]], photo by Arsenyev]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Vladimir Atlasov.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Vladimir Atlasov]]'''
(1661â64 â 1711)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[ataman]], explorer of [[Kamchatka]], [[Kuril Islands]], [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] and [[Japan]]''' |Atlasov '''established the first permanent Russian settlements on [[Kamchatka Peninsula]]''' and led its colonisation. He was the first to present a detailed description of the region's nature and people, and also accounted on the lands near [[Kamchatka]] â [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] and [[Japan]]. Atlasov brought [[Dembei]], a shipwrecked Japanese merchant, to Moscow, where he become the first [[Japanese language education in Russia|to teach Japanese to Russians]].[http://www.kamlib.ru/resourses/atlasov.htm Russian historians about Vladimir Atlasov] by N.V. Tolkacheva {{ru icon}}

[[Atlasov Island]] off the southern tip of Kamchatka, a bay and a volcano on [[Kuril Islands]] are named after Atlasov. |align=center|[[File:Kamchatka peninsula topo.jpg|80px|thumb|center|Topography of [[Kamchatka]]]] |} ===B=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Monument to Babushkin.JPG|100px]] |'''[[Mikhail Babushkin]]'''
(1893â1938)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''military pilot, polar aviator, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]'''
(a monument in [[Moscow]]) |Babushkin took part in an a expedition to rescue [[Umberto Nobile]] in 1928, and in the rescue of ''[[SS Chelyuskin]]'' crew in 1933. He '''performed the flights to the first drifting ice station ''[[North Pole-1]]'' '''in 1937. In 1937-38 he participated in a search for [[Sigizmund Levanevsky]].

A district and a street of [[Moscow]] (in the area where he was born) and the [[Babushkinskaya]] station of the [[Moscow Metro]] are named after Babushkin. |align=center|[[File:Chelyuskin Ship.jpg|120px|center|thumb|''[[SS Chelyuskin]]'' sinking]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Soviet Union stamp 1940 CPA 730.jpg|140px]] |'''[[Konstantin Badygin]]'''
(1910â1984)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Soviet navy]] officer, writer, scientist, [[Arctic]] explorer, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]'''
(Badygin left, [[icebreaker Sedov|''Sedov'']]'s mechanic D.G. Trofimov right on the Soviet postage stamp) |In 1938 Badygin became '''the captain of the ice-captured [[icebreaker]] [[icebreaker Sedov|''Sedov'']], turned into a kind of [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|drifting ice station]]'''. Most of the crew was evacuated, but 15 sailors and scientists, including [[Vladimir Vize]], stayed aboard and carried out a valuable scientific research during their 812 days on ''Sedov''. After drifting from [[New Siberian Islands]] across the [[North Pole]], they were finally freed between [[Greenland]] and [[Svalbard]] by icebreaker ''[[Icebreaker Joseph Stalin|Joseph Stalin]]'' in 1940.Armstrong, T., The Russians in the Arctic, London, 1958.[http://www.whoi.edu/beaufortgyre/history/history_soviet.html Early Soviet Exploration of Arctic] |align=center|[[File:G SedovMarka.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Icebreaker Sedov]] on the Soviet postage stamp]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Karl Ernst von Baer 2.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Karl Ernst von Baer]]'''
(1792â1876)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''[[naturalist]], a founder of [[embryology]], explorer of [[European Russia]], [[Northern Europe]] and [[Arctic]]''' |A prominent [[naturalist]], Karl Ernst von Baer was also an explorer. In 1830-40 he researched [[Arctic]] meteorology. He was interested in the Northern part of [[Russia]] and explored [[Novaya Zemlya]] in 1837 collecting specimens. Other travels led him to the [[North Cape, Norway|North Cape]], [[SÃ¡pmi (area)|Lapland]], and the [[Caspian Sea]]. After his explorations of [[Volga]] he '''formulated the geological ''[[Baer's law]]'', '''stating that in the [[northern hemisphere]] [[erosion]] occurs mostly on the right banks of rivers, and in the [[southern hemisphere]] on the left banks. Baer '''was one of the founders of the [[Russian Geographical Society]]''' in 1845, and also a co-founder and the first President of the [[Russian Entomological Society]].

Baer Island in the [[Taymyr Gulf]] of the [[Kara Sea]] is named after Karl Baer. |align=center|[[File:Rgolibrary.jpg|120px|center|thumb|Library of the [[Russian Geographical Society]] in 1916]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Baidukov Chkalov Belyakov.jpg|120px]] |'''[[Georgiy Baidukov]]'''
(1904â1994)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''aircraft test pilot, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]'''
('''Baidukov''', Chkalov and Belyakov in 1937) |Baidukov was involved in a number of [[Soviet]] ultralong flights. In 1936 [[Valery Chkalov]], Baidukov and A.V.Belyakov on [[ANT-25]] '''flew 9,374 km from [[Moscow]] through the [[North Pole]] to follow-up [[Chkalov Island]] in [[Okhotsk Sea]]''', which took 56 h 20 min. In 1937, also on ANT-25, the same crew '''flew 8,504 km from Moscow through the [[North Pole]] to [[Vancouver, Washington]]''', which was '''the first transpolar flight between [[Europe]] and [[North America]] on [[airplane]]''', rather than on [[dirigible]].[http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=404 Heroes of the country ] {{Ru icon}}

[[Baydukov Island]] near [[Chkalov Island]] in the [[Okhotsk Sea]] and a number of streets are named after Baidukov. |align=center|[[File:Chkalov1w.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Chkalov Island|Chkalov]] and [[Baydukov Island]]s]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Baranov Alexandr.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Alexander Andreyevich Baranov|Alexander Baranov]]'''
(1746â1819)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''merchant in [[Siberia]] and [[Alaska]], first Governor of [[Russian America]]''' |Baranov was hired to head the [[Shelikhov-Golikov Company]], which was in 1799 transformed into [[Russian-American Company]]. Thus Baranov became '''the first Governor of [[Russian America]]''' and held this post in 1799-1818. He '''explored the coast areas of northwestern [[North America]]''', helped [[Russian Orthodox]] missionaries and improved relations with [[Alaska]] natives. He established trade with [[China]], [[Hawaii]] and also with [[California]], where he '''founded [[Fort Ross]]'''.Chevigny, Hector; Lord of Alaska - Baranov and the Russian adventure, Portland, Oregon, Binfords & Mort, 1951, LIBRIS-id 2331138

[[Baranof Island]] in [[Alaska]] and [[U.S.]] [[liberty ship]] ''SS Alexander Baranof'' have been named after Baranov. |align=center|[[File:Fort Ross inside.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Fort Ross]] in [[California]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Nikifor Begichev bust.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikifor Begichev]]'''
(1874â1927)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Arctic]] explorer'''
([[forensic]] facial reconstruction) |Begichev was the bosun of ship ''[[Zarya (polar ship)|Zarya]]'', carrying Baron [[Eduard Toll]]'s expedition in 1900-03. In 1922, at the request of [[Norway]], Begichev led a Soviet expedition in search for lost crew members of [[Roald Amundsen]]'s 1918 expedition on ship ''[[Maud (ship)|Maud]]'' [[Peter Tessem and Paul Knutsen]], but he was not successful. In 1923-24.Begichev '''explored the [[Taymyr Peninsula]]''' with [[Nikolay Urvantsev]].[http://www.ivki.ru/kapustin/person/bigichev/bigichev.htm Geographical discoveries of N.A.Begichev on Taymyr] by V.A.Troitsky {{Ru icon}}William Barr, ''The Last Journey of Peter Tessem and Paul Knutsen'', 1919

[[Bolshoy Begichev Island]] and [[Maliy Begichev Island]], explored by Begichev, have been named after him. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2BB.PNG|thumb|center|120px|[[Maliy Begichev Island|Maliy Begichev]] and [[Bolshoy Begichev Island|Bolshoy Begichev]] islands in the [[Khatanga Gulf]] of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Beketov monument Chita.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Pyotr Beketov]]'''
(c. 1600 â c. 1661)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[voevoda]], explorer of [[Zabaykalye]] and [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]]'''
(a monument in [[Chita, Zabaykalsky Krai|Chita]]) |Beketov, initially a [[strelets]], was appointed [[Enisei]] [[voevoda]] in [[Siberia]] after 1627. He successfully carried out the voyage to collect taxes from [[Zabaykalye]] [[Buryats]], becoming '''the first Russian to step in [[Republic of Buryatia|Buryatia]]'''. He founded there the first Russian settlement, Rybinsky [[Ostrog (fortress)|ostrog]]. Beketov was sent to the [[Lena River]] in 1631, where in 1632 he '''founded [[Yakutsk]]''', a startpoint of further Russian expeditions eastward. He sent his Cossacks to explore [[Aldan River|Aldan]] and [[Kolyma River|Kolyma]] rivers, to found new fortresses, and to collect taxes. In 1652 he launched another voyage to Buryatia, and in 1653 Beketov's Cossacks '''founded follow-up [[Chita, Zabaykalsky Krai|Chita]]''' and then future [[Nerchinsk]] in 1654.[http://oldchita.megalink.ru/ History of Chita] {{Ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Y-ostrog.jpg|thumb|center|120px|A tower of [[Yakutsk]]y [[Ostrog (fortress)|ostrog]].]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Alexander Cherkassky Bekovich.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Alexander Bekovich-Cherkassky]]'''
(?â1717)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
([[Circassia]]n origin)

'''Russian officer, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |Bekovich-Cherkassky, a [[Circassia]]n [[Muslim]] converted into [[Christianity]], was made by [[Tsar]] [[Peter I (Russia)|Peter I]] '''the leader of the first Russian military expeditions into [[Central Asia]]''' in 1714-17, with the aim to conquer the [[Khanate of Khiva]] and the golden sands of the [[Oxus]] River. Bekovich received these orders in [[Astrakhan]], where he '''was engaged in preparing the first Russian map of the [[Caspian Sea]]'''. He commanded a preliminary expedition to Turkmenistan and '''set up the forts in [[Krasnovodsk]]''' and Alexandrovsk. In 1717 he won the battle against [[Khiva]]n Khan, but was tricked into separating his men, betrayed by Khan, defeated and killed.{{cite book|title=Central Asia, 130 Years of Russian Dominance|first=Edward|last=Allworth|publisher=Duke University Press|year=1994|isbn=978-0-8223-1521-6|page=9}} |align=center|[[File:Caspianseamap.png|120px|center|thumb|The [[Caucasus]], [[Caspian Sea]] and [[Turkmenistan]]]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen]]'''
(1778â1852)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, circumnavigator, [[Antarctic]] and [[Pacific]] explorer''' |Bellingshausen took part in the [[first Russian circumnavigation]] under [[Ivan Krusenstern]] on ''[[Russian warship Nadezhda|Nadezhda]]'' in 1803-06. He led himself another Russian circumnavigation in 1819-21 on the corvette ''[[Vostok Station|Vostok]]'', together with [[Mikhail Petrovich Lazarev|Mikhail Lazarev]] on ''[[Mirny Station|Mirny]]'' â this expedition was '''the first to discover the contenent of [[Antarctica]]''' on January 28, 1820 ([[New Style]]). They also discovered and named [[Peter I Island]], [[Zavodovski Island|Zavodovski]], [[Leskov Island|Leskov]] and [[Visokoi Island]]s, [[Antarctic peninsula]] mainland and [[Alexander Island]] (Alexander Coast), and made some discoveries in the tropical waters of the [[Pacific]].[http://www.70south.com/resources/history/explorers/bellingshausen 70South - information on Fabian von Bellingshausen] {{dead link|date=June 2011}}[http://www.aari.nw.ru/projects/Antarctic/persons/bell/bell_ru.html Bellingshausen's biography] {{Ru icon}}

[[Bellingshausen Island]] in the [[Atlantic]], [[Bellingshausen Sea]], [[Bellingshausen Station]], [[Motu One (Society Islands)|Bellinshausen Island]] in the [[Pacific]], [[Faddey Islands]] in the [[Arctic]], ancient [[Bellingshausen Plate]], [[Bellinsgauzen (crater)|Bellinsgauzen crater]] ([[Moon]]) and [[minor planet]] [[3659 Bellingshausen]] are named in honor of Bellinsgausen. |align=center|[[File:Location Antarctica.svg|120px|center|thumb|[[Antarctica]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Levberg.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Lev Berg]]'''
(1876â1950)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, biologist, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |Berg '''studied and determined the depth of the lakes of [[Central Asia]], including [[Balkhash Lake]] and [[Issyk Kul]]'''. He researched the [[ichthyology]] of [[Central Asia]] and [[European Russia]]. He developed [[Dokuchaev]]'s doctrine of [[biome]]s and [[climatology]] and was one of the founders of the Geographical Institute, now a Faculty of Geography of the [[Saint Petersburg University]]. In 1940-50 Berg '''was the President of the [[Soviet Geographical Society]]'''.[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9078737 Lev Berg - article in the Encyclopedia Britannica] |align=center|[[File:LakeBalkhash-EO.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Balkhash Lake]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Vitus Bering 1681-1741.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vitus Bering]]'''
(1681â1741)
{{flag|Denmark}}
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, captain-komandor, explorer of [[Siberia]], the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Alaska]]''' |Returning from the [[East Indies]], Bering joined the [[Russian Navy]] in 1703. He became '''the main organiser of the [[Great Northern Expedition]]''' to explore the northern Asia. In 1725, Bering went overland to [[Okhotsk]], crossed to [[Kamchatka]], and aboard ''[[St. Gabriel|Sviatoi Gavriil]]'' '''mapped some 3500 km of the [[Bering Sea]] coast''' and passed [[Bering Strait]] in 1728-29. Later, [[Ivan Fyodorov (navigator)|Ivan Fyodorov]] and [[Mikhail Gvozdev]] aboard the same ''Sv. Gavriil'' sighted [[Alaska]] shore in 1732. Having organised a major [[Second Kamchatka expedition]], Bering and [[Aleksei Chirikov]] sailed from [[Okhotsk]] in 1740 aboard ''[[St. Peter|Sv. Piotr]]'' and ''[[Paul of Tarsus|Sv. Pavel]]'', '''founded [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky|Petropavlovsk]] in Kamchatka''', and headed together to [[North America]] in 1741, until separated by storm. Bering '''discovered the southern coast of [[Alaska]]''', landed near [[Kayak Island|Kayak]] and '''discovered the [[Aleutian Islands]]'''. [[Aleksei Chirikov|Chirikov]] discovered the shores of America near [[Aleksander Archipelago]] and safely returned to Asia. Bering, however, became very ill and his ship was driven to an uninhabited follow-up [[Bering Island]] of the [[Commander Islands|Commander]] group. Bering died there, along with part of his crew. The rest built a vessel out of the wreckage of ''Sv. Piotr'' and escaped to [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky|Petropavlovsk]].[[EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica Eleventh Edition]][http://www.pbs.org/edens/kamchatka/bering.html PBS story of Bering's expedition][http://beringisland.ru/history/peoples/bering.shtm Bering, Vitus]{{Ru icon}}

The [[Bering Strait]], the [[Bering Sea]], [[Bering Island]], [[Bering Glacier]] and the [[Bering Land Bridge]] bear the Bering's name. |align=center|[[File:Vitus-bering-parken-2005.jpg|120px|center|thumb|A plaque in [[Denmark|Danish]] Vitus Bering Park with Bering's voyages etched]][[File:1966. ÐÑÐºÑÑÑÐ¸Ðµ ÐÐ¾Ð¼Ð°Ð½Ð´Ð¾ÑÑÐºÐ¸Ñ Ð¾ÑÑÑÐ¾Ð²Ð¾Ð².jpg|120px|center|thumb|Soviet postage stamp depicting the discovery of the [[Commander Islands]] and [[Alaska]].]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Joseph Billings]]'''
(c. 1758â1806)
{{flag|United Kingdom}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Royal Navy]] and [[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] and [[Alaska]]''' |In 1785-95 Billings, previously an English officer who had sailed with [[Captain Cook]], led a Russian expedition in search for the [[Northeast Passage]], with [[Gavril Sarychev]] as his deputy. They '''made accurate maps of the [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]], the west coast of [[Alaska]], and the [[Aleutian Islands]]'''. They landed on [[Kodiak Island]], examined the area of [[Prince William Sound]] and compiled a census of the native population of the [[Aleutian Islands]]. Billings '''crossed [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] on [[reindeer]] and made the first elaborate description of the [[Chukchi people]].'''[http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=2267 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online'']

[[Cape Billings]], a bay and a settlement in [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] have been named after Billings. |align=center|[[File:Siberia CBL.png|120px|center|thumb|Location of [[Cape Billings]] in [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Brusilov Georgy.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Georgy Brusilov]]'''
(1884â1914?)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] captain, [[Arctic]] explorer |In 1910-11, Brusilov took part in a hydrographic expedition on the icebreakers ''[[Icebreaker Taymyr|Taymyr]]'' and ''[[Icebreaker Vaygach|Vaygach]]'' to the [[Chukchi Sea|Chukchi]] and [[East Siberian Sea|East Siberian]] seas. In 1912-14 he '''led an expedition on the brig'' [[Svyataya Anna|St.Anna]]'', which aimed to travel by the [[Northern Sea Route]]''' from the [[Atlantic]] to the [[Pacific]]. ''St.Anna'' became icebound west of [[Yamal Peninsula|Yamal]] and drifted to the [[North Pole]] since 1913. Brusilov became ill and many of the crew succumbed to scurvy. In 1914 a group led by lieutenant [[Valerian Albanov]] abandoned the ship and walked south over the drifting ice. Only Albanov and [[Alexander Konrad]] managed to reach [[Franz Joseph Land]], where they were rescued by [[Georgy Sedov]]'s ''St. Foka''. The efforts to find ''St. Anna'' were unsuccessful.

Brusilov and his ship are among the prototypes for the novel ''[[The Two Captains]]'' by [[Veniamin Kaverin]], where the fictional ''St. Maria'' repeats the drift of ''St. Anna''. |align=center|[[File:Kara Sea map.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center|[[File:Bulatovich.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Alexander Bulatovich]]'''
(1870â1919)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian military]] officer, explorer of [[Africa]], writer, hieromonk (tonsured Father Antony)''' |In 1897 Bulatovich was a member of the Russian mission of the [[Red Cross]] in [[Ethiopia]], where he became a confidant of Negus [[Menelek II of Ethiopia]] and his military aide in the war with [[Italy]] and the southern tribes. He became '''the first European to provide a description of the [[Kaffa Province, Ethiopia|Kaffa province]]''' (conquered by Menelek II with Bulatovich's help) and '''among the first to reach the mouth of the [[Omo River]]'''. Among the places named by Bulatovich was the [[Nicholas II]] Mountain range. Back in Russia, he became a monk and one of the leaders of the [[imiaslavie]] [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox]] movement; later he distinguished himself during [[World War I]].[http://www.ortho-rus.ru/cgi-bin/ps_file.cgi?3_4917 Article about Bulatovich on the site of Russian orthodox Church]{{Ru icon}}[http://www.geografia.ru/emp1.html Article on the site geographia.ru]{{Ru icon}}

Bulatovich was a prototype for the grotesque Schema-Hussar Alexei Bulanovich in the novel ''[[The Twelve Chairs]]'' by [[Ilf and Petrov]]; he was the hero of [[Valentin Pikul]]'s story ''The Hussar on a Camel'' and the hero of ''The Name of Hero'' by [[Richard Seltzer]]. |align=center|[[File:Ethiopia_shaded_relief_map_1999,_CIA.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Ethiopia]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Alexander von Bunge.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Alexander Bunge]]'''
(1803â1890)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''botanist, explorer of [[European Russia]], [[Siberia]], [[China]] and [[Persia]] ''' |In 1825-29 Bunge '''studied the flora of [[Siberia]] and [[Altai Mountains]]'''. In 1830 he made research in [[China]] and in 1832-33 again on [[Altai Mountains|Altai]]. In 1835 he researched [[Volga]] [[steppe]]s and [[Astrakhan]] region. In 1857-59 he '''traveled in [[Persia]]''', exploring little known territories and collecting plants.''ÐÐ»ÐµÐºÑÐ°Ð½Ð´Ñ ÐÐ½Ð´ÑÐµÐµÐ²Ð¸Ñ ÐÑÐ½Ð³Ðµ'' - Ð.Ð. Ð¡ÑÑÐ¸Ð½ ; Ð¾ÑÐ². ÑÐµÐ´. Ð .Ð. ÐÐ°Ð¼ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ð½.âÐ. : ÐÐ°ÑÐºÐ°, 2006.âISBN 978-5-02-035310-7 {{Ru icon}}

A crater on [[Mars]] and more than a hundred of plants are named after Bunge. |align=center|[[File:Katun.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Altai Mountains]]]] |} ===C=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:RR5111-0030R.gif|120px]] |'''[[Semion Chelyuskin]]'''
(c. 1700â1764)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Arctic]] explorer'''

([[Stepan Malygin|Malygin]], [[Dmitry Ovtsyn|Ovtsyn]], '''Chelyuskin''', [[Khariton Laptev|K.Laptev]] and [[Dmitry Laptev|D.Laptev]] on a modern commemorative coin) |Chelyuskin participated in the [[Great Northern Expedition]] in 1733-43. He traveled in the groups led by [[Vasily Pronchischev]] and [[Khariton Laptev]]. In 1741 he led an own voyage from the [[Khatanga River]] to the [[Pyasina River]] by land. He '''explored and described the western coastline of [[Taimyr Peninsula]]''' and the mouths of Pyasina and [[Yenisei River]]s. In 1741-42, he traveled from [[Turukhansk]] to the mouth of the Khatanga and '''described the northern coastline of Taimyr''' from the Cape Faddey in the east to the mouth of the [[Taimyra River]] in the west. Chelyuskin '''discovered the northern extremity of [[Asia]], [[Cape Chelyuskin]]'''.[http://ivki.ru/kapustin/person/cheluskin/cheluskin.htm Vasily Pronchishev and Semion Chelyuskin] {{Ru icon}}

[[Cape Chelyuskin]] (the northernmost cape of [[Eurasia]]), Chelyuskin Peninsula (northern tip of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]]), Chelyuskin Island near [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]], famous Soviet [[Chelyuskin steamship]] and some streets and settlements have been named after Chelyuskin. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2CC.PNG|thumb|center|120px|[[Cape Chelyuskin]], the northernmost tip of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]] and [[Eurasia]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Jan Czerski.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Ivan Chersky]]'''
(1845â1892)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[Belorussian people|Belorussian]] and [[Polish people|Polish]] descent)

'''paleontologist, geologist, geographer, explorer of [[Siberia]]''' |Exiled to [[Transbaikalia]] for participation in the [[January Uprising]] and pardoned only in 1883, Chersky became a self-taught scientist in [[Siberia]]. He traveled to [[Sayan Mountains]], [[Irkut River]] Valley and [[Lower Tunguska]]. During four expeditions in 1877-81 Chersky '''explored [[Selenga]] river'''. He '''explained the origin of [[Lake Baikal]]''', made the first geological map of its coast and described the geological structure of [[East Siberia]]. He analysed the [[tectonic]]s of Inner Asia and '''pioneered the [[geomorphology|geomorphological]] evolution theory'''. He collected over 2,500 of ancient bones. In 1892 he '''explored [[Kolyma River|Kolyma]], [[Yana River|Yana]] and [[Indigirka River]]s''' and died from illness there.John J. Stephan, ''The Russian Far East: A History'', Stanford University Press, 1994, ISBN 978-0-8047-2701-3, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Jce4rBWjG5wC&pg=PA315&dq=Jan+Czerski&lr=&as_brr=3&sig=6jZjgslYNUd-_RISjdN4fIcE6lI Google Print, p.315]

[[Chersky Range|Chersky Mountain Range]], [[Chersky (settlement)]] in [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]], another mountain range in [[Chita Oblast]], Chersky Mountain (highest peak of the [[Baikal Range]]), a pass and a peak in the [[Chamar-Daban]], Chersky Stone (a peak in near [[Listvyanka, Irkutsk Oblast]]), a valley and a plateau in the [[Sayan Mountains]], a [[waterfall]] near Baikal, an inactive volcano, a site near [[Irkutsk]] with ancient human remains and a number of species have been named after Chersky. |align=center|[[File:DEM Baikal lake.png|thumb|center|120px|Digital elevation model of [[Baikal]] area]][[File:Selengerivermap.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Selenga]] watershed]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Chichagov.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vasili Chichagov]]'''
(1726â1809)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], [[Arctic]] explorer |In 1764-66 Chichagov '''led two expeditions to find the [[Northeast Passage]]''' between the [[Atlantic]] and the [[Pacific]] along the northern coast of [[Siberia]], a project of [[Mikhail Lomonosov]]. Although he sailed past [[Svalbard]], reached 80Â°26'N in 1765 and 80Â°30'N in 1766, and made valuable research, both expeditions failed to find the route. Later he distinguished himself as victorious Commander-in-chief of the [[Baltic Fleet]] in the [[Russo-Swedish War (1788â1790)]].A. Sokolov. ''Lomonosov's Project and Chichagov's Expedition''. SPb, 1854

Islands near [[Novaya Zemlya]], [[Chichagof Island]] in the [[Alexander Archipelago]] near [[Alaska]], a bay and a cape of [[Nuka Hiva]] in [[French Polynesia]], and a mountain at [[Svalbard]] are named after Chichagov. |align=center|[[File:Barents Sea map.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Barents Sea|Barents]] and [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] seas, where Chichagov explored and fought]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Pjotr Alexandrowitsch Tschichatschow.jpeg|90px]] |'''[[Pyotr Chikhachyov]]'''
(1808â1890)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''naturalist, geologist, explorer of [[Central Asia]] and [[Asia Minor]]''' |In 1839-41 Chikhachyov researched geology of Italy. In 1842 he led an expedition to '''the unknown territories of the Altai and [[Sayan Mountains]]'''. He '''discovered [[Kuznetsk Coal Basin]]''', reached the sources of the rivers [[Abakan]], [[Chu River|Chu]] and [[Chulyshman]], and entered [[Tuva]]. In 1845 he published works on geology of [[Altai Mountains|Altai]] and [[Xinjiang]]. In 1848-63 he led eight expeditions in [[Asia Minor]], [[Armenia]], [[Kurdistan]] and [[East Thrace]]. In 1853-69 he '''conducted a major study of [[Asia Minor]]''', while being the attachÃ© of the Russian embassy in [[Constantinople]]. In 1878, at the age of 71, he visited Algeria and Tunis. He published many works in geography, natural history and politics of the [[Eastern Question]].[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_ch/chihachev_pa.html Biography of Chikhachyov] at hrono.ru {{Ru icon}}

A mountain range in [[Altai Mountains|Altai]] is named after Chikhachyov. |align=center|[[File:Altay-Sayan map en.png|thumb|center|120px|Mountains of [[Central Asia]]]][[File:Turkey topo.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Asia Minor]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Chilingarov Arh.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Artur Chilingarov]]'''
(born 1939)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''[[Arctic]], [[Antarctic]] and [[Deep-sea exploration|deep-sea]] explorer, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Hero of the Russian Federation]], politician''' |In 1969 Chilingarov became the head of the research station â[[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|North Pole-19]]â and in 1971 the head of [[Bellingshausen Station]] during the 17-th [[Soviet Antarctic Expedition]]. In 1985 he successfully '''led the mission to rescue the research vessel ''[[Mikhail Somov]]'',''' which had been ice-blocked in the [[Southern Ocean]]. During the Russian [[Arktika 2007]] expedition, Chilingarov, accompanied by other explorers from different countries, '''descended to the seabed 13,980 feet below the [[North Pole]]''' in order to plant there the [[Russian flag]] and gather the specimens of the bottom ground, using [[MIR (submersible)|MIR submersibles]]. In 2008 he took part in the expedition which on MIRs to descend one mile to the bottom of [[Lake Baikal]].[http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=8452 Chilingarov at Heroes of the Country] {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Mir front.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[MIR (submersible)|MIR submersible]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Tschirikow.jpg|120px]] |'''[[Aleksei Chirikov]]'''
(1703â1748)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, captain, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Alaska]]''' |In 1725-30 and in 1733-43, Chirikov was [[Vitus Bering]]'s deputy during the 1st and the 2nd [[Kamchatka]] expeditions. On July 15, 1741 Chirikov, the captain of ''[[Paul of Tarsus|Sv. Pavel]]'', became '''the first European to land on the northwestern coast of [[North America]]''' near [[Alexander Archipelago]]. Thereafter he '''discovered some of the [[Aleutian Islands]]'''. In 1742 Chirikov specified the location of the [[Attu Island]] during the search for the lost [[Vitus Bering|Bering]]'s ship. In 1746 Chirikov took part in creating the final map of the Russian discoveries in the northern [[Pacific Ocean]].[http://beringisland.ru/history/peoples/chirikov.shtm Biography of Chirikov]{{ru icon}}

Capes of the [[KyÅ«shÅ«]] and [[Attu Island|Attu]] islands, capes in [[Anadyr Bay]] and Tauyskaya Bay, and an underwater mountain in the [[Pacific]] bear Chirikov's name. |align=center|[[File:Alexander archipelago.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Alexander Archipelago]] area of [[North America]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Chkalov 1937.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Valery Chkalov]]'''
(1904â1938)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''aircraft test pilot, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]''' |Chkalov developed several new figures of [[aerobatics]]. He was involved in a number of [[Soviet]] ultralong flights. In 1936 Chkalov, [[Georgiy Baidukov]] and A.V.Belyakov on [[ANT-25]] '''flew 9,374 km from [[Moscow]] through the [[North Pole]] to follow-up [[Chkalov Island]] in [[Okhotsk Sea]]''', which took 56 h 20 min. In 1937, also on ANT-25, the same crew '''flew 8,504 km from Moscow through the [[North Pole]] to [[Vancouver, Washington]]''', which was '''the first transpolar flight between [[Europe]] and [[North America]] on [[airplane]]''', rather than on [[dirigible]].[http://www.nnov.fio.ru/works/stream26/Chkalov/bio.htm Chkalov on the site "Heroes of the country"] {{Ru icon}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}}

[[Chkalovsk, Russia|Chkalovsk]] city, [[Chkalov Island]] in the [[Okhotsk Sea]] and a number of streets and metro stations are named after Chkalov. |align=center|[[File:URSS ANT-25 N025 in flight.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[ANT-25]] flying]] |} ===D=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Semyon Dezhnyov by Brodsky.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Semyon Dezhnyov]]'''
(c. 1605â1672)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] leader, explorer of [[Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1638 Dezhnyov came to [[Yakutsk]] and then to the [[Indigirka River]] where he served under [[Mikhail Stadukhin]]. Together they '''discovered [[Kolyma River]] and founded [[Srednekolymsk]]''' there in 1643. [[Fedot Alekseyev Popov|Fedot Popov]] organized the further expedition eastward, and Dezhnyov became a captain of one [[Koch (boat)|koch]]. In 1648 they sailed from [[Srednekolymsk]] down to the [[Arctic]] and after some time they rounded a'' '[[Cape Dezhnyov|great rocky projection]]', ''thus becoming '''the first to pass through the [[Bering Strait]] and to discover [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] and [[Bering Sea]]'''. All their kochs and most of their men (including Popov himself) were lost in storms and clashes with the natives. A small group led by Dezhnyov reached the mouth of [[Anadyr River]] and sailed up it in 1649, having built new boats of the wreckage. They '''founded [[Anadyrsk]]''' and were stranded there, until Stadukhin found them, coming from Kolyma by land.Raymond H Fisher, The Voyage of Semen Dezhnev in 1648, The Hakluyt Society, 1981

A mountain ridge in [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]], a bay of the [[Bering Sea]], a settlement on [[Amur River]], and [[Cape Dezhnyov]] (the easternmost cape of [[Eurasia]]) are named after Dezhnyov. |align=center|[[File:Anadyrrivermap.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Bering Strait]] and the [[Anadyr River]]]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Dokuchaev2.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vasily Dokuchaev]]'''
(1846â1903)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geographer, geologist, [[Pedology (soil study)|pedologist]], explorer of [[European Russia]]''' |Dokuchaev '''led numerous expeditions to study [[soil]]s and geology of [[European Russia]]'''. In 1871-77 he traveled through [[Finland]] and Northern and Central Russia, and in 1877-81 through [[Chernozem Region]]. In 1897-1900 he traveled to the [[Caucasus]], [[Bessarabia]] and [[Central Asia]]. As a result of his long research of Russian soils, he '''founded the modern [[soil science]]''', developed the conception of [[biome]]s and proposed ways to improve soil productivity.

[[Dokuchaevsk]] town and a village in [[Ukraine]], a number of streets and soil research institutions have been named after Dokuchaev. |align=center|[[File:Global soil regions.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Global [[Soil classification|soil regions]]]] |} ===E=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Adolf Etolin]]'''
(1799â1876)
{{flag|Sweden}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Finland]])

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of [[Alaska]], governor of [[Russian America]]''' |Etolin sailed to [[Alaska]] with [[Vasily Golovnin]] on ''[[Russian frigate Kamchatka|Kamchatka]]'' and entered the service of the [[Russian-American Company]]. He was part of a group that surveyed the [[Aleutian Islands]] in 1822-24. In 1833 he '''explored the [[Gulf of Alaska]]'''. Etolin was '''the governor of [[Russian America]]''' in 1840-45, and continued to explore Alaska and [[Bering Sea]].[http://www.loc.gov/rr/european/FinnsAmer/finchro.html The Finns in America] by Taru Spiegel, Reference Librarian. The Library of Congress

[[Etolin Island]], [[Etolin Strait]], a cape and a bay at [[Nunivak Island]], a mountain in [[Alaska]] and a cape on [[Urup Island]] are named after Etolin. |align=center|[[File:Aleuten Lage.png|120px|thumb|center|Location of [[Aleutian Islands]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Eduard Eversmann.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Eduard Friedrich Eversmann|Eduard Eversmann]]'''
(1794â1860)
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[naturalist]], explorer of Southern [[Urals]] and [[Central Asia]]''' |In 1817 Eversmann came to Russia and started his travels in the southern [[Urals]] to collect specimens. In 1820 he '''traveled to [[Bukhara]] disguised as a merchant''' and in 1825 '''traveled with a military expedition to [[Khiva]]'''. In 1828 he became a professor of [[zoology]] and [[botany]] at the [[university of Kazan]]. He wrote numerous publications and '''pioneered the research of the flora and fauna of the southeast steppes of Russia''' between [[Volga]] and [[Urals]].Mearns and Mearns - Biographies for Birdwatchers ISBN 978-0-12-487422-0

A number of birds, such as [[Eversmann's Redstart]], butterflies, such as [[Eversmann's Parnassian]], and moths, such as [[Eversmann's Rustic]] are named after Eversmann. |align=center|[[File:KhivaWalls.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Walls of [[Itchan Kala]] in [[Khiva]]]] |} ===F=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Alexei Fedchenko.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Alexei Pavlovich Fedchenko|Alexei Fedchenko]]'''
(1844â1873)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[naturalist]], explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |In 1868 Fedchenko traveled through [[Turkestan]], including [[Samarkand]], [[Panjkent]] and the upper [[Zarafshan River]] valley. In 1870 he explored the Fan Mountains south of the Zarafshan. In 1871 he reached the [[Alay Valley]] at [[Daroot-Korgan]] and '''explored the northern [[Pamir Mountains]]''' but was unable to penetrate southward. He perished on [[Mont Blanc]] while engaged in an exploring tour in [[France]].Robert Middleton and Huw Thomas, "Tajikistan and the High Pamirs", Odyssey Guides, 2008

[[Fedchenko Glacier]] in the [[Pamir Mountains]] and the asteroid [[3195 Fedchenko]] are named after Fedchenko. |align=center|[[File:Location map Pamir mhn.svg|120px|thumb|center|[[Pamir Mountains]] in [[Central Asia]]]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Alexander E. Fersman (timbre soviÃ©tique).jpg|100px]] |'''[[Alexander Fersman]]'''
(1883â1945)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geologist, [[geochemist]], explorer of [[European Russia]]''' |Fersman '''founded [[geochemistry]]''', the science about [[chemical]] composition of the [[Earth]]. He led numerous expeditions in [[Crimea]], [[Kola Peninsula]] and the [[Urals]]. He '''discovered [[copper]] and [[nickel]] in [[Monchegorsk]], [[apatite]] reserves in [[Khibiny]] and [[sulfur]] in [[Central Asia]]'''.[http://www.minsocam.org/msa/collectors_corner/arc/fersman.htm Fersman Memorial]

A pass and a mountain in [[Murmansk Oblast]], a settlement in [[Crimea]], the [[Fersman Mineralogical Museum]] in the [[Urals]], the [[mineral]]s fersmite and fersmanite, a [[Fersman (crater)|crater]] on the [[Moon]], and a number of streets are named after Fersman. |align=center|[[File:Khibiny North Rischorr Pass 1.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Khibiny]] Mountains]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Ivan Fyodorov (navigator)|Ivan Fyodorov]]'''
(?â1733)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, navigator, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Alaska]]''' |Fyodorov, a navigator, took part in the 1st [[Kamchatka]] expedition of [[Vitus Bering]] in 1725-30. In 1732 Fyodorov and geodesist [[Mikhail Gvozdev]] aboard ''[[St. Gabriel|Sviatoi Gavriil]]'' (Bering's ship) sailed to [[Cape Dezhnyov]], the easternmost point of [[Asia]]. From there they sailed east and soon '''discovered [[Alaska]] mainland near the [[Cape Prince of Wales]]''', the westernmost point of [[North America]]. They '''charted the north-western coast of Alaska'''. By doing this, Fyodorov and Gvozdev '''completed the discovery of the [[Bering Strait]]''', once started by [[Semyon Dezhnyov]] and [[Fedot Alekseyev Popov]] and continued by Bering. Their expedition also discovered three previously unknown islands.[http://www.ivki.ru/kapustin/person/fedorov/fedorov.htm Fyodorov biography at Kapustin library] {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Seward peninsula.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Seward Peninsula]] on [[Alaska]], where the [[Cape Prince of Wales]] is located]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Hampus-Furuhjelm-1859.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Johan Hampus Furuhjelm]]'''
(1821â1909)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Finland]], [[Swedish people|Swedish]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Vice-Admiral]], Governor of the [[Russian Far East]], [[Taganrog]] and [[Russian America]], explorer of [[Alaska]]'''

(on photo with his wife Anna) |In 1850 Furuhjelm became a commander of [[Novoarkhangelsk]] port (now [[Sitka]], [[Alaska]]) and in 1854 of [[Ayan (rural locality)|Ayan]] port. In 1858-64 he '''was the Governor of [[Russian America]]'''. He improved relations with natives, once using the [[Christopher Columbus|Columbus]]-like trick with an eclipse of the moon to impress the Indians. In 1865-72 Furuhjelm served as military governor of [[Primorsky Krai]] and chief of Russian seaports on [[Pacific]], where he contributed a lot to development and exploration of the whole region.[http://www.genealogia.fi/place/placeake.htm Finnish Place Names - Alaska]

[[Mount Furuhelm]] in [[Alexander Archipelago]], [[Furugelm Island]] in the [[Sea of Japan]], Furuhelm Street in [[Sitka]] ([[Alaska]]) were named after Ivan Furuhjelm. Furugelm point and Furugelm island near [[Sakhalin]] in the [[Sea of Japan]] were named for Carl Furuhjelm, brother of Ivan Furuhjelm. |align=center|[[File:1860-russian-america.jpg|120px|center|thumb|1860 map of [[Alaska]] ([[Russian America]]) and [[Bering Strait]]]] |} ===G=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:Gagarin in Sweden.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Yury Gagarin]]'''
(1934â1968)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Soviet Air Force]] pilot, [[cosmonaut]], the [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]''' |On [[Cosmonautics Day|12 April 1961]], Gagarin became '''the first ever human to travel into [[space]]''', launching to orbit aboard the [[Vostok program|Vostok 3KA-3]] ([[Vostok 1]]).[http://www.ispyspace.com/Yuri_Gagarin.html Yuri Gagarin - The First to Fly]

[[Gagarin, Russia|Gagarin]] town near the place of Gagarin's birth, [[Gagarin, Armenia|Gagarin]] town in Armenia, [[Gagarin (crater)|Gagarin crater]] on the far side of the [[Moon]], asteroid [[1772 Gagarin]], a scientific ship ''[[Kosmonaut Yuri Gagarin]]'', a vast number of settlements, streets, squares and other places in the [[Soviet Union]] and [[Russia]], along with many other objects ranging from bars and clubs to [[Gagarin Cup]], are named in honor of [[Yury Gagarin]]. [[Cosmonautics Day]] aka [[Yuri's Night]] is a yearly held celebration of Gagarin's flight on 12 April. |align=center|[[File:Convert ru kosmos080.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Gagarin on a Soviet postage stamp]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Yakov Gakkel]]'''
(1901â1965)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[oceanographer]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Gakkel was a director of the geography department of the [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]]. He participated in numerous [[Arctic]] expeditions, including the ones on the icebreakers [[Icebreaker Sibiryakov|''Sibiryakov'']] in 1932 and [[Chelyuskin steamship|Chelyuskin]] in 1934. He was '''the first to create a [[bathymetric]] map of the [[Arctic Ocean|Arctic basin]]'''.

In 1966, the [[Gakkel Ridge]], a [[mid-oceanic ridge]] in the [[Arctic Ocean]], was named after Gakkel. |align=center|[[File:IBCAO betamap.jpg|120px|thumb|center|A [[bathymetric]] map of the [[Arctic Ocean]] with [[Gakkel Ridge]] on it]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Matvei Gedenschtrom]]'''
(1780â1845)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''public servant, writer, [[explorer]] of [[Arctic]] and [[Siberia]]''' |Gedenschtrom was sent to serve in [[Siberia]] for connection with a [[smuggling]] affair at [[Tallinn]] [[customs]]. In 1809-10 together with [[Yakov Sannikov]] he led the [[cartographic]] expedition to the [[Arctic]] shores of [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]]. They '''explored and named the [[New Siberian Islands]]''' (earlier discovered by [[Yakov Permyakov]]). This expedition '''established a theory about the existence of the legendary ''[[Sannikov Land]]'' '''somewhere northwest of the [[Kotelny Island]]. Gedenschtrom '''discovered the presence of ''[[Siberian polynya]]'' '''(patches of open water at the edge of the [[drifting ice]] and continental [[fast ice]]). He charted the coastline between the [[Yana (river)|Yana]] and [[Kolyma River]]s. He made numerous trips across [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]] and the areas east of [[Lake Baikal]]. |align=center|[[File:New Siberian Islands map.png|120px|thumb|center|[[New Siberian Islands]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Georgi Johann Gottlied 1729-1803.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Johann Gottlieb Georgi]]'''
(1729â1802)
{{flag|Prussia}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geographer, naturalist, ethnographer, physician, chemist, explorer of [[European Russia]] and [[Siberia]]''' |Georgi accompanied both [[Johann Peter Falck]] and [[Peter Simon Pallas]] on their respective journeys through [[European Russia]] and [[Siberia]]. In 1772 he '''mapped [[Lake Baikal]] and was the first to describe [[omul]] fish''', as well as other fauna and flora of Baikal region. He amassed a large collection of minerals and in 1776-80 '''published the first comprehensive work on ethnography of [[indigenous peoples of Russia]]'''.[http://www.rulex.ru/01041005.htm Biography of Georgi]{{ru icon}}

[[Dahlia|Georgia]] flower was named after Georgi. |align=center|[[File:Thymallus baikalensis, Baikal-Museum, Listvyanka, Irkutsk Oblast, Russia - 20080405.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Omul]] in an aquarium in the [[Baikal]]-Museum in [[Listvyanka, Irkutsk Oblast|Listvyanka]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Gmelin Johann Georg 1709-1755.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Johann Georg Gmelin]]'''
(1709â1755)
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''naturalist, botanist, geographer, explorer of [[European Russia]] and [[Siberia]]''' |In 1733-43 Gmelin participated in the [[Great Northern Expedition]] and '''made a number of journeys through [[Siberia]], covering more than 34,000 km''' in the total. He '''discovered that the [[Caspian Sea]] lies below the ocean level'''. He published two major works about his travels in Russia and the flora of Siberia, and '''described more than 500 previously unknown plants'''.[http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/brokgauz_efron/30144 Gmelins family]{{ru icon}}

The settlement of Gmelinka, ''[[Gmelina]]'' plant genus, ''[[Larix gmelinii]]'' tree and other plants are named after Gmelin. |align=center|[[File:Flowering at Canopy I IMG 3456.jpg|thumb|center|120px|''[[Gmelina arborea]]'']] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:GolovninB&W.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vasily Golovnin]]'''
(1776â1831)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Vice Admiral]], circumnavigator, explorer of the [[Far East]]''' |He made two [[circumnavigation]]s on the sloop ''Diana'' (1807â09) and the frigate ''[[Russian frigate Kamchatka|Kamchatka]]'' (1817â19). In 1811 Golovnin '''described and mapped part of the [[Kuril Islands]]'''. At that time he was taken prisoner for two years by the Japanese. He described in books his years in captivity, life in [[Japan]], and his voyages around the world. Later he was athe General [[Quartermaster]] of Russian Navy and supervised the building of the first Russian [[steamship]]s. He tutored [[Fyodor Petrovich Litke|Fyodor Litke]], [[Ferdinand von Wrangel]] and other famous seafarers.[http://books.google.co.th/books?isbn=0395984157 How Sloop Diana, commanded by Lieutenant Vasilii M. Golovnin, eluded the British fleet at Simon's Bay] {{dead link|date=June 2011}}

The village of [[Golovin, Alaska]], a cape in the west of [[North America]], a bay in the [[Bering Sea]], a strait between two of the [[Kuril Islands]], a volcano on [[Kunashir Island]], mountains on [[Novaya Zemlya]] and on [[Franz Josef Land]] are named after Golovnin. He is a character in [[Patrick O'Brian|Patrick O'Brian's]] ''[[The Mauritius Command]]''. |align=center|[[File:Golovninmap.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Golovnin's [[circumnavigation]]s]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Bronislaw Grabczewski.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Bronislav Gromchevsky]]'''
(1855â1926)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
([[Polish people|Polish]] descent)

'''[[Imperial Russian Army]] officer, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |Gromchevsky participated in the Russian conquest of [[Central Asia]] and then led reconnaissance expeditions in the surrounding regions. In 1885-86 he '''explored [[Kashgar]] and [[Tian Shan]]'''. In 1888-89 he '''explored the [[Pamirs]], [[Kafiristan]], [[Kashmir]] and northwestern [[Tibet]]''' and went as far as into the [[British India]]. He is regarded as the Russian counterpart to the British military-explorer [[Francis Younghusband]]. The two [[The Great Game|Great Game]] rivals famously met in 1889 when they were exploring the [[Hunza Valley]] for their respective governments. In 1900 Gromchevsky explored North Eastern [[China]].Peter Hopkirk. ''The Great Game'' |align=center|[[File:Kashmir region 2004.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Kashmir]] region]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:GrumGrshmailo.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Grigory Grumm-Grzhimaylo]]'''
(1860â1936)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''zoologist, entomologist, ethnographer, geographer, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |In 1884 Grumm-Grzhimaylo started his first Pamir expedition on which he '''explored the [[Alai Mountains]] and reached as far as [[Karakul (Tajikistan)|Lake Karakul]]'''. In 1885-87 he '''extensively traveled through [[Central Asia]]''', reaching the [[Silk Road|Great Silk Route]], [[Chatyr-Kul|Lake Chatyr-Kul]] and [[Kashgar]]. In this expedition he collected tens of thousands of insects and other specimens. In 1889-90 he '''discovered the [[Ayding Lake]], the [[Table of elevation extremes by country|second lowest land point]] on Earth''', at 130 m below the sea level. He obtained two [[Przewalski's Horse]]s and more than 1000 bird specimens during 8600 km long travel. In 1903 he explored [[Mongolia]] and [[Tuva]] and later traveled in the [[Far East]].

A pass in [[Sikhote-Alin]] Mountains, a glacier he discovered in the [[Pamirs]] and a glacier in [[Bogd Khan Uul|Bogdo Ula]] are named after Grumm-Grzhimaylo. |align=center|[[File:Aydingkol1.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Stele at the [[Ayding Lake]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Mikhail Gvozdev]]'''
(1700-04 â after 1759)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''military [[geodesist]], explorer of the [[Far East]], co-discoverer of [[Alaska]]''' |Gvozdev took part in the 1st [[Kamchatka]] expedition of [[Vitus Bering]]. In 1732 together with [[Ivan Fedorov (navigator)|Ivan Fedorov]] aboard ''Sviatoi Gavriil'' (Bering's ship) they reached [[Dezhnev Cape]] (the easternmost point of [[Asia]]), sailed east and soon '''discovered [[Alaska]] mainland near the [[Cape Prince of Wales]]''' (the westernmost point of [[North America]]). They charted the part of Alaska coast and discovered three new islands. Thus they '''completed the discovery of the [[Bering Strait]]''', once started by [[Semyon Dezhnyov]] and [[Fedot Alekseyev Popov]] and continued by Bering. Subsequently in 1741-42 Gvozdev participated in the expedition led by Alexey Shelting and '''mapped most of the western and southern shores of the [[Okhotsk Sea]], and the eastern shore of [[Sakhalin]].'''[http://www.ivki.ru/kapustin/person/fedorov/fedorov.htm Gvozdev biography at Kapustin library]{{ru icon}}[http://www.kamchatsky-krai.ru/lichnosti/biografii/gvozdev.htm Gvozdev biography at the site of [[Kamchatka Krai]]]{{ru icon}}

A cape on [[Sakhalin]] island is named after Gvozdev. |align=center|[[File:Sea of Okhotsk map.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Sea of Okhotsk]], [[Kamchatka]] and [[Alaska]] in the [[North Pacific]]]] |} ===H=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Gagemester.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Ludwig von Hagemeister]]'''
(1780â1833)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Latvia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] captain, governor of [[Russian America]], circumnavigator, explorer of the [[Pacific]] and [[Alaska]] |After taking part in [[Napoleonic Wars]], at which point his abilities were praised by admiral [[Nelson, Horatio, Viscount Nelson|Nelson]], in 1806-07 Hagemeister journeyed to [[Russian America]] on his ship ''[[Neva]]''. In 1808-09, he explored the shores of [[Alaska]] and waters of the [[North Pacific]]. In 1812-15 he '''supervised the building of the first [[tall ship]]s to sail on [[Lake Baikal]]'''. In 1816-19 he was in charge of ''Kutuzov'', on which he made his first full [[circumnavigation]] of the globe, with a stop in [[Alaska]], where he '''was a governor of [[Russian America]]''' in 1818-19. In 1828-29, Hagemeister made his second circumnavigation aboard ''Krotky''. Among other islands he surveyed the [[Kwajalein|Menshikov Atoll (Kwajalein)]] in the [[Marshall Islands]] group.[http://www.npacific.ru/np/library/encicl/4/0013.htm Hagemeister biography]

[[Hagemeister Island]] and a strait in [[Alaska]], a mountain in [[Alexander Archipelago]] and an atoll group in the [[Pacific]] were named after Hagemeister. |align=center|[[File:Mapgagenmester.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Hagemeister's [[circumnavigation|sea voyages]]]] |} ===I=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Kurbat Ivanov]]'''
(?â1666)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]][[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberia]]n [[Cossack]] [[voevoda]], explorer of [[East Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |Initially Kurbat Ivanov was a [[Yenisey]]an [[Cossack]]. In 1642, on the basis of explorations made by [[Ivan Moskvitin]], he '''made the earliest known map of the [[Russian Far East]]'''. In 1643 With a group of Cossacks he sailed up [[Lena River]] from Verkholensky [[Ostrog (fortress)|ostrog]], having decided to check the rumors of large body of water to the south. They crossed [[Baikal Mountains]] by foot, descended down the [[Sarma River]] and '''discovered [[Lake Baikal]] and visited its [[Olkhon Island]]'''. Ivanov '''made the first chart and description of [[Baikal]]'''. In 1659-65 Ivanov was the next head of [[Anadyrsk]]y ostrog after [[Semyon Dezhnyov]]. In 1660 he sailed from [[Anadyr Bay]] to [[Cape Dezhnyov]]. He is credited with creation of the early map of [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] and [[Bering Strait]], which was '''the first to show on paper (very schematically) the yet undiscovered [[Wrangel Island]], both [[Diomede Islands]] and [[Alaska]]'''.[http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/enc_biography/43700/%D0%98%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2 Ivanov, Kurbat] {{ru icon}}[http://www.sbaikal.ru/rus/region/history.html Ð¢ÑÐ¾Ð¿Ð¾Ñ Ð·ÐµÐ¼Ð»ÐµÐ¿ÑÐ¾ÑÐ¾Ð´ÑÐµÐ²] {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Lena watershed.png|center|120px|thumb|[[Lena River]] and [[Lake Baikal]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Gerasim Izmailov]]'''
(c. 1745 â after 1795)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of [[Alaska]]''' |In 1771 Izmailov was caught up in the [[Benevsky mutiny]] while serving on [[Kamchatka]]. After an attempt to break away from the mutineers he was marooned on [[Simushir]], an uninhabited isle in the [[Kurils]]. For a year he lived as [[Robinson Crusoe|Robinson]] there before being rescued, tried on charges of mutiny and cleared. Starting in 1775 he '''created the first detailed map of the [[Aleutian Islands]]'''. In 1778 he met with Captain [[James Cook]] in [[Unalaska]]. In 1783-85 Izmaylov and [[Grigory Shelikhov]] '''founded the first permanent Russian settlement in [[North America]]''' on [[Kodiak Island]]. In 1789 Izmaylov became '''the first to explore and map the [[Kenai Peninsula]]'''. Later he helped [[Alexander Andreyevich Baranov|Alexander Baranov]] to fight off the [[Tlingit people|Tlingit]] natives and saved a lost crew of a Russian ship from [[Saint Paul Island, Alaska|Saint Paul Island]].[http://www.npacific.ru/np/library/encicl/9/0010.htm Biographical Dictionary of the Russian Far East and Russian America]{{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Mapa Hipsometryczna-Aleuty i RÃ³w Aleucki.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Aleutian Islands]]]] |} ===J=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center|[[File:Yunker vv.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Wilhelm Junker]]'''
(1840â1892)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[German people|German]] descent)

'''physician, etnographer, explorer of [[Africa]]''' |Born in a rich family of [[Moscow]] banker, Junker journeyed to [[Iceland]], [[Tunis]] and [[Lower Egypt]] for his own money. Then he '''carried out a major exploration of [[Eastern Africa|Eastern]] and [[Equatorial Africa]]''' in 1875-86, with [[Khartoum]] and then [[Lado, Sudan|Lado]] as bases for his expeditions. He researched [[African peoples]], including [[Azande]] from [[Niam-Niam]], and collected plant and animal specimens. He '''explored the [[Nile]]-[[Congo River|Congo]] watershed''', where he '''established the identity of the [[Uele River|Uele]] and [[Ubangi]] rivers'''. The [[Mahdist]] rising prevented his return to Europe through the [[Sudan]], and in 1884-86 he went south, traveled through [[Uganda]] and [[Tabora]], reached [[Zanzibar]] and finally returned to [[St. Petersburg]]. |align=center|[[File:CongoLualaba watershed topo.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Congo River]] basin]] |} ===K=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Johann K E Kegel.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Johann Karl Ehrenfried Kegel]]'''
(1784â1863)
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[agronomist]], explorer of [[Kamchatka]]''' |1841 Kegel was sent to [[Kamchatka Peninsula]] to investigate possibilities of agriculture and mining. In 1841-47 he '''traveled extensively through Kamchatka''', crossed it several times and subsequently wrote the most detailed account of Kamchatka's nature and ethnography at that time.Werner Friedrich GÃ¼lden (editor): ''Forschungsreise nach Kamtschatka â Reisen und Erlebnisse des Johann Karl Ehrenfried Kegel von 1841 bis 1847'', BÃ¶hlau-Verlag, 1992, ISBN 978-3-412-11091-8 {{de icon}} |align=center|[[File:Avachinsky Volcano.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Avachinsky]] Volcano in [[Kamchatka]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Monument to Yerofey Khabarov, Siberia and Amur pioneer.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Yerofey Khabarov]]'''
(1603 â after 1671)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]][[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[ataman]], explorer of [[East Siberia]] and [[Amur River]] region |A manager for the merchants [[Stroganovs]], Khabarov went to Siberia and in 1641 founded a settlement and [[saltworks]] on the [[Lena River]]. In 1649-50 he became '''the second Russian to explore the [[Amur river]]''' (after [[Vassili Poyarkov]]). Through [[Olyokma]], [[Tungur]] and [[Shilka River]]s he reached Amur ([[Dauria]]), returned to [[Yakutsk]] and then back to Amur with a larger force. This time he [[Russian-Manchu border conflicts|was met with armed resistance]]. He built winter quarters at [[Albazin]], then sailed down Amur and '''found Achansk, which preceded the present-day [[Khabarovsk]]''', defeating or evading large armies of [[Dauria]]n [[Manchu]] [[China|Chinese]] and [[Koreans]] on his way. There was a mutiny against him, then he mutined himself when a nobleman Dimitry Zinoviev appeared with new reinforcements and demanded full command. Zinoviev was unable to deal with the [[Manchus]], and finally withdrew, leaving [[Onufriy Stepanov]] in charge. Khabarov was sent to Moscow, acquitted and returned to Siberia. He charted the Amur in his ''Draft of the Amur river''.Basil Dymytryshyn, 'Russia's Conquest of Siberia', 1985[http://www.rulex.ru/01220001.htm Khabarov's biography] {{ru icon}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}}

The major city of [[Khabarovsk]], a town and a railway station Yerofey Pavlovich on the [[Trans-Siberian railroad]] in [[Amur Oblast]] bear Khabarov's name. |align=center|[[File:Amurrivermap.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Amur River]] basin]][[File:Albazin.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Qing Dynasty|Qing]] troops besieging [[Albazin]] in 1686]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" | |'''[[Maria Klenova]]'''
(1898â1976)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[marine geology|marine geologist]], [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] explorer''' |Klenova was '''one of the founders of [[marine geology]]'''. She began her career in 1925 aboard the [[Soviet]] research vessel ''Persey'' in the [[Barents Sea]], visiting [[Novaya Zemlya]], [[Spitsbergen]] and [[Franz Josef Land]]. In 1933 Klenova '''made the first complete seabed map of the Barents Sea'''. Her later work included the research of seabed geology in the [[Atlantic]] and the [[Antarctic]], and in the [[Caspian sea|Caspian]] and [[White Sea]]s. She was '''one of the earliest women explorers of [[Antarctic]]'''.{{cite web| title=Sixteenth Meeting of the GEBCO Subcommittee on Undersea Feature Names| publisher=International Hydrographic Organization| month=April| year=2002| url=http://www.gebco.net/about_us/meetings_and_minutes/documents/gebco_scufn_16_report.pdf| accessdate=2007-11-15}}

The Klenova Valley in the [[Arctic]] and a [[List of craters on Venus|crater on Venus]] are named after Klenova. |align=center|[[File:Barents Sea in Bloom.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Barents Sea]] as seen from space]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Kolchak.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Aleksandr Kolchak]]'''
(1874â1920)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Kolchak joined the expedition of [[Eduard Toll]] on ship ''[[Zarya (polar ship)|Zarya]]'' in 1900 as a hydrologist. He took part in two further [[Arctic]] expeditions and '''explored the shores of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]]'''. For a while was [[nickname]]d "Kolchak-Poliarnyi" ("Kolchak the Polar"). Then he distinguished himself in the [[Russo-Japanese War]] and in [[World War I]], and during the [[Russian Civil War]] he was one of the main leaders of the [[White movement]]. He published a number of important works on [[Arctic ice]].[http://www.hrono.info/biograf/bio_k/kolchak_pasha.html Hrono.info]

[[Kolchak Island]], discovered and explored by Kolchak is named after him. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2TA.PNG|120px|center|thumb|Location of [[Kolchak Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:NNKolomeitsev.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolai Kolomeitsev]]'''
(1867â1944)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|France}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |After several expeditions in the [[Arctic]], Kolomeitsev became '''a commander of [[Eduard Toll]]'s ''[[Zarya (polar ship)|Zarya]]'' during ''Russian Polar Expedition'' '''in 1900. They aimed to explore the area north of the [[New Siberian Islands]] and to find the [[Sannikov Land]]. There was a disagreement between Kolomeitsev and Toll over the treatment of the crew, and finally [[Fyodor Matisen]] was made captain, while Kolomeitsev was sent with [[Stepan Rastorguyev]] to organize coal depots and carry the post to the mainland. They '''made a number of discoveries on the 800 km long sledge trip over [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]]'''. Later he became a hero of the [[Russo-Japanese War]].[[William Barr (Arctic historian)|William Barr]], ''Baron Eduard von Toll's Last Expedition: The Russian Polar Expedition, 1900-1903. 1980''

[[Kolomeitsev Islands]], a bay and a strait in the [[Kara Sea]], a river on [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]], a mountain and a Soviet ship have been named after Kolomeitsev. |align=center|[[File:Russian schooner Zarya, 1910.jpg|120px|center|thumb|Polar ship ''[[Zarya (polar ship)|Zarya]]'']] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Alexander Konrad]]'''
(?â1940)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''sailor in the [[Russian Imperial Navy]] and the [[Soviet Navy]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Konrad was '''one of the only two survivors of the ill-fated 1912-14 [[Georgy Brusilov|Brusilov expedition]]''', the other being lieutenant [[Valerian Albanov]]. They left ice-bound ship ''[[Svyataya Anna|St. Anna]]'' and by [[ski]], [[sledge]], and [[kayak]] crossed the [[Kara Sea]], reached [[Franz Josef Land]] and finally were rescued by [[Georgy Sedov]]'s ''Saint Foka''. The data about ice drift of ''St. Anna'', provided by Albanov, '''helped [[Vladimir Vize]] to calculate the coordinates of previously unknown [[Vize Island]]'''. In 1939, serving on a [[Soviet]] ship, Konrad completed the full passage of the [[Northern Sea Route]], which had been the main goal of ''St. Anna''.

A glacier in [[Severnaya Zemlya]] is named after Albanov. Either Albanov or Konrad is a prototype fora hero in the novel ''[[The Two Captains]]'' by [[Veniamin Kaverin]]. |align=center|[[File:S S Yacht Blencathra.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Svyataya Anna|St. Anna]] vessel]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" | |'''[[Fyodor Konyukhov]]'''
(born 1951)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''yacht captain, traveler, painter, writer''' |By the age of 50 Konyukhov '''has made more than 40 unique trips and climbs''' expressing his vision of the world in more than 3000 paintings and 9 books. He '''set a record of crossing the [[Atlantic]] on a single row-boat''' in 46 days. He also crossed 800 km for record 15 days and 22 hours during a Trans-[[Greenland]] dog sleigh ride. He was '''the first Russian to complete the [[Three Poles Challenge]] and [[Explorers Grand Slam]]'''. He is '''the first and so far the only person in the world to have reached the five extreme [[Geographical pole|Poles]] of the planet''': [[North Pole]] (3 times), [[South Pole]], [[Pole of inaccessibility]] in the [[Arctic Ocean]], [[Mt. Everest]] ([[Alpinist]]s pole) and [[Cape Horn]] ([[Yachtsmen]] pole). He '''set a record for the solo yacht circumnavigation of [[Antarctica]]''' in 2008, making it in 102 days.[http://konyukhov.ru/eng/biografia/index.shtml Biography at Konyukhov's official site][http://www.antarcticacup.com/ Antarctica Cup site] |align=center|[[File:Seven+Summits+Elevation+World+Map.png|120px|center|thumb|The [[Seven Summits]] on an elevation world map]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Korzhenevky N L.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Nikolai Korzhenevskiy]]'''
(1879â1958)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Army]] officer, geographer, glaciologist, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |In 1903-28 Korzhenevskiy '''organized eleven expeditions to explore the [[Pamir Mountains]]'''. He discovered a number of glaciers and the highest peaks in the [[Pamirs]], including [[Peak Korzhenevskaya]] which he named after his wife Evgeniya. He '''discovered and called [[Akademiya Nauk Range]]''' (in honor of the [[Academy of Sciences of the USSR]]) and '''made a catalogue of all glaciers in [[Central Asia]], himself having discovered 70 of them'''.

Three glaciers in different [[Central Asia]] mountain ridges and a peak in the [[Pamirs]] have been named after Korzhenevskiy. |align=center|[[File:Peak Korzhenevskoi Pamir from Borodkina ridge at sunset.jpg|90px|thumb|center|[[Peak Korzhenevskaya]] in the [[Pamirs]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Otto von Kotzebue.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Otto von Kotzebue]]'''
(1787â1846)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, circumnavigator, explorer of [[Arctic]], [[Alaska]] and [[Pacific]]''' |Kotzebue accompanied [[Ivan Krusenstern]] in the [[first Russian circumnavigation]] in 1803-06. On the brig ''[[Rurik]]'' he himself led another Russian circumnavigation in 1815-18. Proceeding via [[Cape Horn]], he '''discovered the Romanzov Islands, Rurik Islands and [[Tuamotus|Krusenstern Islands]]''' (today [[Tikehau]]) in [[Pacific]], then made for [[Kamchatka Peninsula]] and proceeded along the north-west coast of [[North America]] to the [[Chukchi Sea]]. He '''discovered and named [[Kotzebue Sound]] and [[Cape Krusenstern]]'''. Returning south he '''discovered the [[Mejit Island|New Year Island]]''' in [[Pacific]]. In 1823-26 he made another world cruise on the sloop "Enterprise"making several discoveries.

[[Kotzebue Sound]] and the city of [[Kotzebue, Alaska]] are named after Otto von Kotzebue. |align=center|[[File:Kozebuemap.jpg|120px|center|thumb|Kotzebue's [[circumnavigation]]s]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Kozlov 01.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Pyotr Kozlov]]'''
(1863â1935)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Army]] officer, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |Kozlov started travelling in the [[Central Asia]] with [[Nikolai Przhevalsky]], and after the death of his mentor he continued his work. From 1899 to 1901 he '''explored the upper reaches of [[Huang He]], [[Yangtze]], and [[Mekong]] rivers'''. Kozlov rivalled [[Sven Hedin]] and [[Aurel Stein]] as '''the foremost researcher of [[Xinjiang]]''' at the historical peak of [[the Great Game]]. In 1907 he visited the [[Dalai Lama]] in [[Ulan Bator|Urga]]. In 1907-09, Kozlov '''explored the [[Gobi Desert]] and discovered remains of the ancient [[Tibetan people|Tangut]] city of [[Khara-Khoto]]'''. He excavated the site and uncovered no less than 2,000 books in [[Tangut language]]. In 1923-26 he '''explored [[Mongolia]] and [[Tibet]] and discovered an unprecedented number of [[Xiongnu]] royal burials at [[Noin-Ula]]'''.[http://www.orientalstudies.ru/eng/index.php?option=com_personalities&Itemid=74&person=29 Kozlov's biography]{{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Mahasthamaprapta.jpg|thumb|center|70px|A [[silk]] painting from [[Khara-Khoto]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Stepan Krasheninnikov.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Stepan Krasheninnikov]]'''
(1711â1755)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]][[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geographer and explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Kamchatka]]''' |Krashennikov was a classmate of [[Mikhail Lomonosov]]. He embarked upon a major [[Second Kamchatka Expedition]], organised by [[Vitus Bering]]. Krashennikov traveled in [[Siberia]] in 1733-36 and on [[Kamchatka Peninsula]] in 1737-41. He '''gave the first full description of [[Kamchatka]]''' in his book ''An Account of the Land of Kamchatka'', with detailed report of the plants and animals of the region, and also the language and culture of the indigenous [[Itelmen]] and [[Koryaks|Koryak]] peoples.[http://beringisland.ru/history/peoples/krasheninnikov.shtm Krasheninnikov's biography] {{ru icon}}

The Krasheninnikov Volcano on [[Kamchatka]] and more than 20 species are named after Krasheninnikov. |align=center|[[File:Der Berg Kamtschatka (aus Krascheninnikow, Opisanie Zemli Kamcatki).jpg|thumb|center|120px|''[[Volcanoes of Kamchatka|Fire-breathing mountain on Kamchatka]]'' from Krasheninnikov's book]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Pyotr Krenitsyn]]'''
(1728â1770)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of [[Alaska]] and [[Pacific]]''' |In 1766-70 Krenitsyn '''led the "secret" expedition to the [[North Pacific]]''' together with [[Mikhail Levashev|Mikhail Levashov]], as ordered by [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II]]. They '''explored the [[Aleutian Islands]] and part of [[Alaska]]''' shore, discovering good haven in [[Unalaska]] and many features of [[Alaska]]n coast. Krenitsyn died drowning in [[Kamchatka River]]. On the basis of his explorations the first general map of the [[Aleutian Islands]] was created.

The [[Krenitzin Islands]] in [[Aleutian Islands|Aleutian chain]], a strait between [[Onekotan]] and [[Kharimkotan]] islands in the [[Kurils]], the highest volcano on Onekotan, a cape and a volcano on Kharimkotan and a cape in [[Bristol Bay]] of the [[Bering Sea]] are named after Krenitsyn. |align=center|[[File:USA Alaska location map.svg|120px|center|thumb|[[Alaska]] and the [[Aleutian Islands]]]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:Sergei Konstantinovich Krikalev.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Sergei Krikalyov]]'''
(born 1958)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}
