'''[[cosmonaut]] and [[mechanical engineer]], [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Hero of the Russian Federation]] |Krikalyov '''has spent in [[space]] a record 803 days and 9 hours and 39 minutes during his six spaceflights'''. As a [[Soviet]] cosmonaut he traveled in space and back aboard ''[[Soyuz TM-7]]'' in 1988 and then launched upon ''[[Soyuz TM-12]]'' in 1991, both times working on the Soviet [[Space Station]] ''[[Mir]]''. ''"The last Citizen of the [[USSR]]"'', Krikalev landed back on [[Earth]] aboard [[Soyuz TM-13]] in 1992 to turn into a [[Russia]]n cosmonaut. He became the first Russian to travel on the [[USA|American]] [[Space Shuttle]] during [[STS-60]] mission to ''[[Mir]]'' in 1994, and then he made another Shuttle flight [[STS-88]], which was the first Shuttle mission to [[International Space Station]]. He again traveled to [[ISS]] on [[Soyuz TM-31]] in 2000 and returned back on [[STS-102]] in 2001. And yet again he traveled to ISS and back on [[Soyuz TMA-6]] in 2005.[http://www11.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/krikalev.html NASA biography of S. Krikalyov] |align=center|[[File:Mir on 12 June 1998edit1.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Mir]] [[space station]].]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Peter Kropotkin circa 1900.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Pyotr Kropotkin]]'''
(1842â1921)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Army]] officer, geographer, zoologist, [[anarchist]], explorer of [[Siberia]], the [[Far East]] and the [[Northern Europe]]''' |While serving in [[Siberia]], in 1864 Kropotkin '''led survey expedition crossing North [[Manchuria]] from [[Transbaikalia]] to the [[Amur River]]'''. Subsequently he took part in the expedition which '''proceeded up the [[Sungari River]] into central [[Manchuria]]''', yielding valuable geographical results. In 1871 he explored the glacial deposits of [[Finland]] and [[Sweden]]. He published several important works on geography of Asia. Kropotkin was also one of the most prominent Russian [[anarchist]]s and [[revolutionary|revolutionaries]].[http://vivovoco.rsl.ru/VV/BOOKS/KROPOTKIN/INTRO.HTM ''Pyotr Kropotkin''] by N.M.Pirumova {{ru icon}}

The town of [[Kropotkin, Krasnodar Krai]], a settlement in [[Irkutsk Oblast]], an inactive volcano in [[Republic of Buryatia|Buryatia]], [[Kropotkinskaya]] station of [[Moscow metro]] and many streets in Soviet and Russian cities have been named after Kropotkin. |align=center|[[File:Stielers Handatlas 1891 62 NE.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Manchuria]] in 1892]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Kruzenshtern I F.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Adam Johann von Krusenstern]]'''
(1770â1846)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, circumnavigator, explorer of [[Pacific]]''' |In 1803-06, under the patronage of Tsar [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] and Baron [[Nikolai Rezanov]], Krusenstern '''led the [[first Russian circumnavigation]] of the world''' aboard ''[[Nadezhda (Russian warship)|Nadezhda]]'' together with [[Yuri Lisianski]] on ''[[Neva (Russian warship)|Neva]]''. The purpose of the expedition was to establish trade with [[China]] and [[Japan]], and examine [[California]] for a possible colony. They sailed from [[Kronstadt, Russia|Kronstadt]], rounded [[Cape Horn]], and reached the northern [[Pacific]]. Krusenstern's account of his journey was published in Russia and many European countries. He made an atlas of the [[Pacific]], receiving an honorary membership in the [[Russian Academy of Science]]s for that.

The Russian [[training ship|training]] [[tall ship]] ''[[Kruzenshtern (ship)|Kruzenshtern]]'', crater [[Krusenstern (crater)|Krusenstern]] on the [[Moon]], [[Ailuk Atoll|Krusenstern Island]] in the [[Marshall Islands]], [[Tikehau|Krusenstern Island]] in the [[Tuamotus]], [[Little Diomede Island|Krusenstern Island]] in the [[Bering Strait]], as well as Krusenstern Islands in the [[Kara Sea]] have been named after Krusenstern. |align=center|[[File:Kruzenshtern at Sail Bremerhaven (1).jpg|120px|center|thumb|Modern ship ''[[Kruzenshtern (ship)|Kruzenshtern]]'' repeating the journey of ''[[Nadezhda (Russian warship)|Nadezhda]]'' on its 200th anniversary]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Aleksandr kuchin.PNG|100px]] |'''[[Alexander Kuchin]]'''
(1888â1913?)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, oceanographer, [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] explorer''' |Kuchin's life was bound with [[Norway]]: he started as a seaman on a Norwegian ship, created a ''Small Russian-Norwegian dictionary'', studied [[oceanography]] from [[Bjorn Helland-Hansen]], '''participated in [[Amundsen]]âs expedition to the [[South Pole]] on the ''[[Fram]]'', '''and married Aslaug Poulson, a Norwegian. In 1912-13 he took part in '''[[Vladimir Rusanov]]âs expedition to [[Svalbard]]''' as the captain of their ship ''[[Hercules|Gerkules]]''. After the successful research of the coal reserves on Svalbard, without consultation with the Russian authorities they made an incredibly rash attempt to pass via the [[Northern Sea Route]], and were lost in the [[Kara Sea]]. Relics of ''Gerkules'' were found near [[Kolosovykh Islands]].'' Aleksandr Stepanovich Kuchin: The Russian who went South with Amundsen'' by [[William Barr (Arctic historian)|William Barr]]

Two islets off [[Salisbury Island (Russia)|Salisbury Island]] in [[Franz Josef Land]] have been named after Kuchin. |align=center|[[File:Sv-map.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Svalbard]] ([[Spitsbergen]])]] |} ===L=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center|[[File:Grigori-langsdorff.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Grigori Ivanovitch Langsdorff|Grigory Langsdorff]]'''
(1774â1852)
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''physician, naturalist, [[consul]] general of Russia in [[Rio de Janeiro]], explorer of the [[Aleutian Islands]] and [[Brazil]]''' |Langsdorff participated as naturalist and physician in the [[first Russian circumnavigation]] commanded by [[Ivan Kruzenshtern]] in 1803-05. Independently, he '''explored the [[Aleutians]], [[Kodiak Island|Kodiak]] and [[Sitka]]''' in 1805-07. In 1813 he was nominated [[consul]] general of Russia in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]. There he '''explored the flora, fauna and geography of the province of [[Minas Gerais]]''' with French naturalist [[Augustin Saint-Hilaire]] in 1813-20. In 1821-22 he '''led an exploratory and scientific expedition from [[SÃ£o Paulo]] to [[ParÃ¡]] in the [[Amazon Rainforest|Amazon]]''' via a fluvial route, accompanied by an international team of scientists. In 1826-29 he '''led a 6000 km long expedition from [[Porto Feliz]] to [[Amazon River]] and back'''. As a consequence of the tropical fever, he became insane and went to Europe for healing. Still he and his companions were able to emass huge scientific collections now deposited in [[Kunstkamera]], [[St. Petersburg]], including much valuable material on Brazilian nature and ethnography.[http://reports.travel.ru/reports/2002/180702.html Still Amazing Amazonia] {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Brazil State MinasGerais.svg|thumb|center|120px|[[Minas Gerais]] province in [[Brazil]].]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:RR5111-0030R.gif|120px]] |'''[[Dmitry Laptev]]'''

([[Stepan Malygin|Malygin]], [[Dmitry Ovtsyn|Ovtsyn]], [[Semion Chelyuskin|Chelyuskin]], K.Laptev and '''D.Laptev''' on a modern commemorative coin) |A cousine of [[Khariton Laptev]], Dmitry Laptev led one of the parties of the [[Great Northern Expedition]] in 1739-42. He '''described the sea coastline from the mouth of the [[Lena River]] to the Cape Bolshoy Baranov east of the mouth of [[Kolyma River|Kolyma]]''', the basin and the mouth of the [[Anadyr River]], and land route from the Anadyr fortress to the [[Penzhin Bay]]. In 1741-42, Laptev surveyed the rivers of [[Bolshoy Anyuy River|Bolshoy Anyuy]] and Anadyr. Later he continued his service in the [[Baltic Fleet]] and became [[Vice Admiral]].[http://vluki.library.ru/region/famous_people/laptev.php The cousins Dmitry Yakovlevich and Khariton Prokofyevich Laptev]{{ru icon}}

A cape in the delta of the Lena River and a strait between the [[Bolshoy Lyakhovsky Island]] and [[Siberia]]n mainland bear Dmitry Laptev's name. (1700â1763)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Arctic]]'''

([[Stepan Malygin|Malygin]], [[Dmitry Ovtsyn|Ovtsyn]], [[Semion Chelyuskin|Chelyuskin]], '''K.Laptev''' and D.Laptev on a modern commemorative coin) |A cousine of [[Dmitry Laptev]], Khariton Laptev led one of the parties of the [[Great Northern Expedition]] in 1739-42. Together with [[Semion Chelyuskin]], N. Chekin, and G. Medvedev, Laptev '''described the [[Taimyr Peninsula]] from the mouth of the [[Khatanga River]] to the mouth of the [[Pyasina]] river''' and discovered several islands. He participated in the creation of the ''"General Map of the [[Siberia]]n and [[Kamchatka]] Coast"'', and then continued his service in the [[Baltic Fleet]].

The sea coastline of the Taimyr Peninsula, a cape on the [[Cape Chelyuskin|Chelyuskin]] Peninsula and other landmarks bear Khariton Laptev's name. The [[Laptev Sea]] is named after Dmitry Laptev and Khariton Laptev. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2TY.PNG|thumb|center|120px|Location of the [[Taimyr Peninsula]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Lavrov.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Mikhail Lavrov]]'''

In 1821-24 he '''participated in the expedition of [[Fyodor Litke]] to [[Novaya Zemlya]], making description of its shores''' and the coastline near [[Murmansk]]. In 1825-27, he sailed around the world on board of sloop ''Krotkiy'' led by [[Ferdinand Wrangel]], visiting [[Kamchatka]] and [[Russian America]]. Later he became Rear Admiral for his feats of arms.

A cape to in the [[Arctic]] and an island in [[Severnaya Zemlya]] were named after Lavrov. |align=center|[[File:Novaya Zemlya.svg|thumb|center|100px|[[Novaya Zemlya]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Adam Laxman]]'''
(1766â1806?)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[Swedish-speaking Finns|Finland-Swedish]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Army]] officer, diplomat, explorer of [[Japan]]''' |Son of [[Erik Laxman|Kirill Laxman]], Adam Laxman '''was sent to [[Japan]] on a diplomatic mission in 1791-92''', with the aim to return [[Daikokuya KÅdayÅ«]] and another Japanese castaway in exchange for trade concessions from [[Tokugawa shogunate]]. He made valuable observations, but returned to Russia essentially empty-handed, though he possibly obtained the first official Japanese documents granting very limited permission to trade, to a nation other than China or the Netherlands.George Alexander Lensen, âEarly Russo-Japanese Relationsâ, The Far Eastern Quarterly, vol.10, no.1, November 1950, pp.2-37, n.b. pp.17-22 |align=center|[[File:Daikokoya Kodayu - Landkarte von Japan.jpg|120px|center|thumb|Map of [[Japan]] drawn by [[Daikokuya KÅdayÅ«]] in 1789 with place names in both [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[Russian language|Russian]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Erik Laxman|Kirill Laxman]]'''
(1737â1796)
{{flag|Sweden}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[Swedish-speaking Finns|Finland-Swedish]] origin)

'''clergyman, naturalist, explorer of [[Northern Europe]] and [[Siberia]]''' |Kirill Laxman became a priest first in [[St. Petersburg]] and then in [[Siberia]]n town of [[Barnaul]]. In 1764-68 he '''explored Siberia, reaching [[Irkutsk]], [[Baikal]], [[Kiakhta]] and the border with [[China]]''' and researching the Siberian flora and fauna. In 1782 he '''founded the oldest museum in Siberia''' in Irkutsk, where he settled earlier and was a business partner of [[Alexander Andreyevich Baranov|Alexander Baranov]] (the future governor of [[Russian America]]). Laxman '''was engaged in attempts to establish relationships between Russia and [[Japan]]'''. He brought [[Daikokuya KÅdayÅ«]], a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] castaway, to the court of empress [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II]], and after that his son [[Adam Laxman]] was sent with KÅdayÅ« to Japan.

A number of plant species have been named after Laxman. |align=center|[[File:Irkutskmap.png|120px|center|thumb|Location of [[Irkutsk]] near [[Lake Baikal]]]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" |align=center|[[File:ÐÐ¸ÑÐ°Ð¸Ð» ÐÐµÑÑÐ¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ ÐÐ°Ð·Ð°ÑÐµÐ².jpg|100px]] |'''[[Mikhail Petrovich Lazarev|Mikhail Lazarev]]'''
(1788â1851)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], circumnavigator, [[Antarctic]] and [[Pacific]] explorer''' |Lazarev '''thrice circumnavigated the globe'''. He led 1813-16 [[circumnavigation]] aboard the vessel ''[[Suvorov]]'' and discovered [[Suwarrow|Suvorov Atoll]]. He commanded ''[[Mirny Station|Mirny]]'', the second ship in the Russian circumnavigation of 1819-21 under the leadership of [[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen]] aboard ''[[Vostok Station|Vostok]]'' â this expedition was '''the first to discover the contenent of [[Antarctica]]''' on January 28, 1820 ([[New Style]]). They also discovered and named [[Peter I Island]], [[Zavodovski Island|Zavodovski]], [[Leskov Island|Leskov]] and [[Visokoi Island]]s, [[Antarctic peninsula]] mainland and [[Alexander Island]] (Alexander Coast), and made some discoveries in the tropical waters of the [[Pacific]]. In 1822-25 Lazarev sailed around the globe for the third time on his [[frigate]] ''Kreyser''. Lazarev was a hero of the [[Battle of Navarino]], the commander of the [[Russian Black Sea Fleet]] for 20 years and the tutor of famous Admirals and war heroes [[Pavel Nakhimov]], [[Vladimir Kornilov]] and [[Vladimir Istomin]].{{Find a Grave|11969}}

[[Lazarev Mountains]], Lazarev and [[Novolazarevskaya Station]]s in Antarctic, Lazarev Atoll in the Pacific [[Tuamotus|Russian Islands]], capes in the [[Amur Liman]] and on the [[Unimak Island]], an island in the [[Aral Sea]], a bay and a port in the [[Sea of Japan]], [[Lazarevskoye]] settlement near Sochi and other locations, a number of streets and vessels, and [[minor planet]] [[3660 Lazarev]] are named in honor of Lazarev. |align=center|[[File:Lazarevmap1.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Mikhail Lazarev|Lazarev]]'s [[world cruise]] on ''Suvorov'']][[File:Location Antarctica.svg|120px|center|thumb|[[Antarctica]]]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:Leonov Alexei.png|100px]] |'''[[Alexei Leonov]]'''
(born 1934)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''[[cosmonaut]] and [[Soviet Air Force]] [[General]], twice the [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], painter, writer''' |On March 18, 1965, connected to the spacecraft [[Voskhod 2]] by a 5.35 meter tether, Leonov became '''the first person to make a spacewalk''', or [[extra-vehicular activity]]. He was in the open space for 12 min 9 sec. At the end of the spacewalk, Leonov's [[spacesuit]] had inflated in the vacuum to the point where he could not reenter the airlock. He opened a valve to allow some of the suit's pressure to bleed off, and was barely able to get back inside the capsule, where his companion [[Pavel Belyayev]] assisted him. Subsequently Leonov made a second [[spaceflight]] on [[Soyuz 19]] spacecraft, a part of [[ApolloâSoyuz Test Project]] in 1975. Thus Leonov '''participated in the first joint flight of the [[U.S.]] and [[Soviet]] [[space program]]s'''. He published several books and albums of paintings, some of which he created in space.{{Cite book |last=Scott |first=David |authorlink=David Scott |coauthors=Alexei Leonov |others=with Christine Toomey |title=Two Sides of the Moon: Our Story of the Cold War Space Race |year=2006 |publisher=St. Martin's Griffin |location= |isbn=978-0-312-30866-7}}

[[Arthur C. Clarke]]'s book [[2010: Odyssey Two]] was dedicated to Leonov and [[Andrei Sakharov]]; the fictional spaceship ''[[List of spacecraft from the Space Odyssey series|Cosmonaut Alexei Leonov]]'' in the book was named after him. |align=center| |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Mikhail Levashev|Mikhail Levashov]]'''
(c. 1738â1774-76)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of [[Alaska]] and [[Pacific]]''' |In 1766-70 Levashov was second-in-command in '''the "secret" expedition to the [[North Pacific]]''' led by [[Pyotr Krenitsyn]], as ordered by [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II]]. They '''explored the [[Aleutian Islands]] and part of [[Alaska]]''' shore, discovering good haven in [[Unalaska]] and many features of [[Alaska]]n coast. Levashov also '''explored and described the [[Commander Islands]]'''. On the basis of their explorations the first general map of the [[Aleutian Islands]] was created.[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_l/levashov_mih.html Levashov's biography] {{ru icon}}

Port Levashef (the harbor in [[Unalaska]]), one of the straits between [[Kuril Islands]], a cape and a volcano on [[Paramushir Island]], and a cape in the west of [[Kamchatka]] have been named after Levashov. |align=center|[[File:Commander Islands Map - Russian.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Kamchatka]] and the [[Commander Islands]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Yuriy Lisyansky portrait by Vladimir Borovikovsky.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Yuri Lisyansky]]'''
(1773â1837)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, circumnavigator, explorer of the [[Pacific]]''' |In 1803-06 Lisyansky aboard ''[[Neva (Russian warship)|Neva]]'' together with [[Ivan Krusenstern]] on ''[[Nadezhda (Russian warship)|Nadezhda]]'' '''led the [[first Russian circumnavigation]] of the world'''. The purpose of the expedition was to establish trade with [[China]] and [[Japan]] and examine [[California]] for a possible colony. They sailed from [[Kronstadt, Russia|Kronstadt]], rounded [[Cape Horn]], and reached the northern [[Pacific]]. The ships split near [[Hawaii]] and Lisyanski headed to [[Russian Alaska]], where ''Neva'' became essential in defeating the [[Tlingit people|Tlingit]] in the [[Battle of Sitka]]. Lisyansky was the first to describe the [[Hawaiian monk seal]] on the island which now bears his name. He met Krusenstern again in [[Macau]], but they soon separated. Eventually, Lisyansky was the first to return to Kronstadt.[http://www.krugosvet.ru/enc/istoriya/LISYANSKI_YURI_FEDOROVICH.html Biography of Lisyansky]{{ru icon}}

[[Lisianski Island]] in the [[Northwestern Hawaiian Islands]], a peninsula of the [[Baranof Island]] near [[Alaska]], a bay, a strait, a river, a cape in [[North America]], an undersea mountain in [[Okhotsk Sea]] and a peninsula there have been named after Lisyansky. |align=center|[[File:Russian Sloop-of-War Neva.jpg|120px|center|thumb|''[[Neva (Russian warship)|Neva]]'' visiting [[Kodiak, Alaska|Kodiak]], [[Alaska]]]][[File:Lisianski1.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Lisianski Island]] of [[Hawaiian Islands|Hawaiian]] group]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Litkefp.jpeg|120px]] |'''[[Fyodor Petrovich Litke|Fyodor Litke]]'''
(1797â1882)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], circumnavigator, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Litke took part in [[Vasily Golovnin]]'s [[world cruise]] on the ship ''[[Kamchatka]]'' in 1817-19. In 1821-24, Litke '''explored the coastline of [[Novaya Zemlya]]''', the [[White Sea]], and the eastern [[Barents Sea]]. In 1826-29, he led the circumnavigation on the ship ''[[Russian battleship Admiral Senyavin|Senyavin]]'' and accompanied by Mikhail Staniukovich on the sloop ''Moller''. During this voyage they '''explored the [[Bering Sea]] (including [[Pribilof Islands]], [[St. Matthew Island]] and the [[Commander Islands]]), the [[Bonin Islands]] off [[Japan]], and the [[Caroline Islands|Carolines]]''', discovering 12 new islands. Litke was a co-fouder and '''the president of the [[Russian Geographic Society]]''' in 1845-50 and 1857-72. He was '''the president of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]''' in 1864-82, and occupied a number of major military and state offices.[http://qwercus.narod.ru/lithke_bio.htm Biography of Litke] by B.P.Orlov {{ru icon}}

Litke gold medal of the [[Russian Geographical Society]], [[Cape Lutke, Alaska]], [[Litke Strait]] between [[Kamchatka Peninsula|Kamchatka]] and [[Karaginsky Island]], a cape, a peninsula, a mountain and a bay in [[Novaya Zemlya]], a number of islands in the [[Franz Josef Land]], [[Baydaratskaya Bay]], and [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]], as well as a Russian [[icebreaker]] [[Icebreaker Feodor Litke|''Feodor Litke'']] have been named after Litke. |align=center|[[File:Litkemap.jpg|thumb|center|120px|Litke's [[circumnavigation]] on ''Senyavin'']][[File:Cape Promontory Cape Lutkes, Alaska. {{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''cartographer, geodesist, explorer of [[Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1719-1721, together [[Ivan Yevreinov]], Luzhin '''made the first instrumental mapping of [[Kamchatka]] and the first map of the [[Kuril Islands]]''' during the "secret expedition", as ordered by [[Peter I of Russia]]. In 1723-24 he made [[surveying|surveys]] of different parts of [[East Siberia]] near [[Irkutsk]]. In 1725-27, Luzhin participated in the 1st Kamchatka Expedition led by [[Vitus Bering]].[http://www.npacific.ru/np/library/encicl/12/0011.htm Biography of Luzhin]{{ru icon}}

[[Luzhin Strait]] which separates [[Paramushir]] and [[Antsiferov Island]]s in the [[Kurils]], and a cape in [[Taui Bay]] of [[Okhotsk Sea]] are named after Luzhin. |align=center|[[File:Kuril islands.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Kuril Islands]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Ivan Lyakhov]]'''
(? â c. 1800)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''merchant, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Lyakhov, a merchant, '''investigated the [[New Siberian Islands]]''' in three expeditions on [[dogsled]]s in 1770, 1773â74 and 1775. He hoped to find [[mammoth]] ivory there as he believed the islands were mainly formed by a substratum of bones and tusks of mammoths. He explored the follow-up [[Lyakhovsky Islands]], crossed the [[Sannikov Strait]] and '''discovered [[Kotelny Island]]'''.D. Gath Whitley: The Ivory Islands in the Arctic Ocean, Journal of the Philosophical Society of Great Britain XII, 1910

[[Lyakhovsky Islands]] group in the south of [[New Siberian Islands]] are named after Lyakhov. |align=center|[[File:New Siberian Islands map.png|thumb|center|120px|[[New Siberian Islands]]]] |} ===M=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Maak.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Richard Maack]]'''
(1825â1886)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]])

'''naturalist, geographer, anthropologist, explorer of [[East Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |Maack participated in the first expedition to describe the orography, geology and population of the [[Vilyuy River]] basin in 1853-55. He '''explored the [[Amur River]] and the [[Ussuri River]]''' in 1855-56 and in 1859 correspondingly. He discovered a number if unknown species and wrote some of the first scientific descriptions of remote Siberia regions.[http://www.npacific.ru/np/library/encicl/13/0031.htm Maack's biography] {{ru icon}}

[[Maackia amurensis]], [[Lonicera maackii]], [[Prunus maackii]] and other plant species have been named after Maack. |align=center|[[File:Ravenstein-p376-Maack-Interior-of-a-Mangun-House.png|120px|thumb|center|''Interior of a [[Ulchs|Mangun]] house'' by Maack]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:SO Makarov 01.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Stepan Makarov]]'''
(1849â1904)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, vice-Admiral, oceanographer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Makarov was highly decorated for his service as a captain of the Russian [[torpedo boat tender]] ''[[Velikiy Knyaz Konstantin (ship)|Velikiy Knyaz Konstantin]]'' in the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1877â78|Russo-Turkish War of 1877â78]]. On January 16, 1877 he was the first in the world to successfully launch [[torpedo]]es (against the [[Turkey|Turkish]] armed ship ''Intibah''). He was one of the developers of Russian [[Flag semaphore]] system. Makarov '''directed two round-the-world oceanographic expeditions''' on the [[corvette]] ''[[Russian corvette Vityaz (1862)|Vityaz]]'' in 1886â89 and in 1894â96. He '''proposed the idea and oversaw the construction of ''[[Icebreaker Yermak|Yermak]]'', the world's first true [[icebreaker]],''' which was able to ride over and crash [[pack ice]]. He commanded ''Yermak'' in two [[Arctic]] expeditions in 1899 and in 1901. Promoted to Commander of the [[Pacific Ocean Fleet (Russia)|Russian Pacific Fleet]], Admiral Makarov was killed in action during the [[Russo-Japanese War]] of 1904â05 on the battleship ''[[Russian battleship Petropavlovsk (1897)|Petropavlovsk]]'' after his ship struck a [[naval mine|mine]].[http://www.peoples.ru/military/admiral/makarov/ Makarov's biography] at peoples.ru {{ru icon}}

An island in the Tsivolk group of the [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]], a town on [[Sakhalin]], a number of naval institutions, an embankment in [[St. Petersburg]] and other places were named after Stepan Makarov, as well as number of ships called ''Admiral Makarov''. |align=center|[[File:Vityaz'1883-1893.jpg|thumb|120px|center|[[Corvette]] ''[[Russian corvette Vityaz (1862)|Vityaz]]'']][[File:Yermak icebreaker.jpg|thumb|120px|center|[[Icebreaker]] ''[[Icebreaker Yermak|Yermak]]'']] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:RR5111-0030R.gif|120px]] |'''[[Stepan Malygin]]'''
(?â1764)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, navigator, captain, cartographer, [[Arctic]] explorer'''

('''Malygin''', [[Dmitry Ovtsyn|Ovtsyn]], [[Semion Chelyuskin|Chelyuskin]], [[Khariton Laptev|K.Laptev]] and [[Dmitry Laptev|D.Laptev]] on a modern commemorative coin) |Malygin was '''the first one to write a manual on [[navigation]] in [[Russian language]]''' in 1733. In the early 1736, he was appointed leader of the western unit of the [[Great Northern Expedition]]. In 1736-37, two boats ''Perviy'' (First) and ''Vtoroy'' (Second) under the command of Malygin and A. Skuratov undertook a voyage from the [[Dolgiy Island]] in the [[Barents Sea]] to the mouth of the [[Ob River]]. During this trip, Malygin for the first time '''described and mapped the part of the [[Russian Arctic]] coastline between the [[Pechora River|Pechora]] and [[Ob River]]s'''. Later he commanded ships on the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]], prepared navigators for the [[Russian Navy]], and was in charge of [[Riga]] port during the [[Seven Years War]].[http://www.polarmuseum.ru/bio/polarex/bio_smal/bio_smal.htm Malygin's biography] at polarmuseum.ru {{ru icon}}

Malygin Strait between [[Yamal Peninsula]] and [[Bely Island]], a number of ships (including icebreaker ''[[Icebreaker Malygin (1912)|Malygin]]'') and several streets bear Malygin's name. |align=center|[[File:Bely Island.PNG|thumb|100px|center|[[Bely Island]] and Malygin Strait]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Fyodor Matisen]]'''
(1872â1921)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, hydrographer, [[Arctic]] explorer'''

 |Matisen replaced [[Nikolai Kolomeitsev]] as '''a commander of [[Eduard Toll]]'s ''[[Zarya (polar ship)|Zarya]]'' during ''Russian Polar Expedition'' '''in 1900-03. He was '''the first to make a thorough geographical survey of the [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]]''', exploring it on [[Dog sled|dogsled]] and discovering and naming 40 of its islands. Subsequently Toll and Matisen led ''Zarya'' across the [[Laptev Sea]] to the [[New Siberian Islands]]. The ship was trapped in fast ice, and Toll and three companions went in search of the elusive [[Sannikov Land]] on foot and kayaks, and were lost. When ''Zarya'' became able to set sail, Matisen made it towards the [[Lena River|Lena]] river delta.

A strait in the [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]] and a coastal survey ship bear Matisen's name. |align=center|[[File:Nordenshelda2w.PNG|thumb|120px|center|[[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Matyushkin 01.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Fyodor Matyushkin]]'''
(1799â1872)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], circumnavigator, [[Arctic]] explorer'''

 |Matyushkin studied in [[Tsarskoselskiy College]] together with [[Alexander Pushkin]]. He participated in [[Vassili Golovnin]]'s [[world cruise]] aboard ''[[Kamchatka]]'' in 1817-19. In 1820-24 he took part in [[Ferdinand Wrangel]]'s [[Arctic]] expedition to the [[East Siberian Sea]] and the [[Chukchi Sea]]. They '''explored and mapped the [[Medvyezhi Islands]]'''. Following this survey, Matyushkin on his own '''explored a vast [[tundra]] area east of the [[Kolyma]] river'''. In 1825-27, he joined Wrangel in his world cruise aboard ''Krotky''. Later he took part in the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1828-1829]] and became [[Admiral]].[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=11241 Fyodor Fyodorovich Matyushkin] at findagrave.com |align=center|[[File:Larix gmelinii0.jpg|thumb|100px|center|[[Kolyma]] region nature]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Middendorff1.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Alexander von Middendorff|Alexander Middendorff]]'''
(1815â1894)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[Baltic German]] descent)

'''zoologist, botanist, geographer, explorer of the [[Northern Europe]], [[Siberia]], [[Arctic]], the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Central Asia]]''' |In 1840 Middendorff took part in [[Karl Baer]]'s expedition to the [[Kola Peninsula]] and [[Lapland (region)|Lapland]]. In 1843-45 he '''pioneered the scientific exploration of the [[Taimyr Peninsula]] and discovered [[Putorana Plateau]] in the [[Central Siberian Plateau|Central Siberia]]'''. Then he traveled along the coast of the [[Sea of Okhotsk]] and entered the lower [[Amur River]] valley. He studied the ethnography of Siberian peoples, the climate, animals and plants of Siberia. He was a '''founder of the [[permafrost]] science''' and '''the Vice President of the [[Russian Geographical Society]]'''. He '''determined the southern border of [[permafrost]] and explained the high [[sinuosity]] of the northern boundary of [[taiga]] zone.''' In 1870 he accompanied [[Grand Duke Alexei Alexandrovich]] to [[Novaya Zemlya]] and '''discovered the [[North Cape, Norway|North Cape sea current]]''' (a part of [[Norwegian Current]]). In 1870 he also explored the [[Baraba steppe]], and in 1878 he travelled in [[Fergana Valley]]. He was also a prominent [[Hippology|hippologist]] and contributed in the development of agriculture in Russia.[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_m/middendorf.html Middendorff's biography] at hrono.ru {{ru icon}}

Cape Middendorff in [[Novaya Zemlya]], [[Middendorff Bay]] ([[Taymyr Peninsula]]), [[Middendorff's Grasshopper Warbler]], Ursus arctos middendorffi ([[Kodiak Bear]]) and some other species are named after Middendorff. |align=center|[[File:Location Putoran Mountains.PNG|thumb|120px|center|[[Putorana Plateau]] location in [[Siberia]].]][[File:Circum-Arctic Map of Permafrost and Ground Ice Conditions.png|thumb|120px|center|[[Permafrost]] in the [[Northern Hemisphere]].]] |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center|[[File:Miklukho-Maklai.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nicholas Miklouho-Maclay]]'''
(1846â1888)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[Ukrainian people|Ukrainian]], [[German people|German]] and [[Polish people|Polish]] descent)

'''[[ethnologist]], [[anthropologist]] and [[biologist]], explorer of [[Australia]], [[New Guinea]] and [[Oceania]]''' |Miklouho-Maclay '''visited the north-eastern [[New Guinea]], [[Philippines]], [[Indonesia]] and [[Melanesia]]''' on a number of occasions starting from 1870, and for a long time he '''lived amongst the native [[Oceania]]n tribes, writing a comprehensive treatise on their way of life and customs'''. One of the earliest followers of [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]], he was a [[humanism|humanist]] scholar who, on the basis of comparative anatomical research, was among the first to refute the then prevailing view that the different '[[Race (classification of human beings)|races]]' of mankind belonged to different species. He arrived to [[Sydney]] in 1878 and organised a zoological centre known as the ''Marine Biological Station'', the first marine biological research institute in [[Australia]]. He married a daughter of the [[Premier of New South Wales]], [[John Robertson (New South Wales Premier)|John Robertson]], and returned to Russia. Being in poor health after the trip he died, and left his skull to the St. Petersburg Military and Medical Academy.Ogloblin, A. K. (1998) 'Commemorating N.N. Miklukho-Maclay (Recent Russian publications)', in ''Perspectives on the Bird's Head of Irian Jaya, Indonesia: Proceedings of the Conference'', pages.487â502. 1998. ISBN 978-90-420-0644-7. [http://books.google.com/books?id=sIsIpnAjT9YC Partial view] on [[Google Books]]

Maclay Coast is still used as the name for the North-East of [[Papua New Guinea]]. A street in [[Papua New Guinea]]n [[Madang]] not far from where the explorer stayed, plant species ''Pouteria maclayana'', [[Australia]]n Miklouho-Maclay Prize and [[Macleay Museum]], [[N. N. Miklukho-Maklai Institute of Ethnology and Anthropology|Miklukho-Maklai Institute of Ethnology and Anthropology]] and a street in South-West [[Moscow]] (near the [[Peoples' Friendship University of Russia]]) are named after Miklukho-Maklai. |align=center|[[File:New Guinea Topography.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Papua New Guinea]]]][[File:Nicholai Miklukho-Maklai-1880.jpg|110px|thumb|center|Miklukho-Maklai in [[Australia]] with [[Eucalyptus]] leaves]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Spafarii stamp.jpg|140px]] |'''[[Nicolae Milescu]]'''
(1636â1708)
{{flag|Moldavia}}
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''writer, traveler, geographer, diplomat, explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[China]]''' |Born in [[Moldavia]]n noble family, Milescu traveled extensively through [[Europe]] and [[Ottoman Empire]], first on education purposes and then as diplomat serving for Moldavia and [[Wallachia]]. In 1671 he went to live in Russia, working for its foreign ministry. He wrote several important works there, including the first [[arithmetics]] textbook in [[Russian language]], ''Arithmologion''. He '''led Russian diplomatic mission to [[China]] in 1675-78''', for the first time among Russian ambassadors travelling to [[Beijing]] through the [[East Siberia]] rather than through [[Mongolia]]. After his assistant Ignatiy Milovanov (sent beforehand) Milescu was the first known European to cross the [[Amur River]] from north and reach Beijing by that way. Milescu '''made the first detailed description of [[Lake Baikal]]''' and all the rivers feeding the lake, and he was '''the first to point out Baikal's unfathomable depth'''. His travel notes also contain valuable descriptions of major Siberian rivers and the first ever [[orthographic projection (cartography)|orthographic]] scheme of the [[East Siberia]].Ð£ÑÑÑÐ» Ð. Moscow: Mysl, 1980. {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Spafarii trip stamp.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Milescue and his trip from [[Moscow]] to [[China]] on an old map]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Fyodor Minin]]'''
(c. 1709 â after 1742)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1730s, Minin participated in the [[Great Northern Expedition]]. In 1736, he joined the unit led by [[Dmitry Ovtsyn]]. In 1738 together with Dmitry Sterlegov he led the group that '''charted the [[Arctic]] coastline east of the [[Yenisei]] river''' for some 250 km. In 1738-42, Minin made several vain attempts to sail around the [[Taimyr Peninsula]]. He also '''mapped and described [[Dikson Island]]'''.[http://www.polarmuseum.ru/bio/polarex/bio_min/bio_min.htm Minin's biography]{{ru icon}}

A cape at [[Khalmyer Bay]], the [[Minina Skerries]] in the [[Kara Sea]], a gulf, a bay, a cape and a mountain on the shores of the [[Taimyr Peninsula]] bear Minin's name. |align=center|[[File:Kara seaMS.PNG|thumb|120px|center|Location of the [[Minina Skerries]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Ivan Moskvitin]]'''
(? â after 1645)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberia]]n [[Cossack]] [[ataman]], explorer of [[East Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |Presumably a native of [[Moscow]], Moskvitin appeared in [[Siberia]] around 1626 in [[Tomsk]]. He accompanied the [[Cossack]] [[ataman]] Dmitry Kopylov to [[Yakutsk]]. In 1638 Kopylov founded a small fort on the [[Aldan River]] and in 1639 dispatched Moskvitin in command of 20 Tomsk Cossacks and 29 [[Krasnoyarsk]] Cossacks to look for silver ore further to the east. Leading this party, Moskvitin became '''the first Russian to reach the [[Pacific Ocean]] and to discover the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]''', building a winter camp on its shore at the [[Ulya River]] mouth. The Cossacks learned from the locals about the proximity of the [[Amur River]]. In 1640 they apparently sailed south, '''explored the south-eastern shores of the Okhotsk Sea and probably reached the mouth of the [[Amur River]]'''. On their way back they '''discovered the [[Shantar Islands]]'''. Based on Moskvitin's account, [[Kurbat Ivanov]] draw the first Russian map of the [[Far East]] in 1642. Moskvitin personally brought the news of the discovery of the eastern ocean to [[Moscow]].[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_m/moskvitin_iyu.html Moskvitin's biography] at hrono.ru {{ru icon}}

A cape in Luzhin Bay of the [[Okhotsk Sea]] is named after Moskvitin. |align=center|[[File:Okhotsk-Japan5SHA.png|120px|thumb|center|Location of the [[Shantar Islands]] in the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Gerhard Friedrich MÃ¼ller.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Gerhard Friedrich MÃ¼ller]]'''
(1705â1783)
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''historian, ethnologist, explorer of [[Siberia]]''' |MÃ¼ller came to [[St. Petersburg]] in 1725 and became '''a co-founder of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]'''. In 1733-43 he '''participated in the academic unit of the [[Great Northern Expedition]] and traveled extensively through [[Siberia]]''', studying Siberian geography and peoples. MÃ¼ller '''is considered to be one of the fathers of [[ethnography]]'''. He collected the vernacular stories and archival documents about Russian explorers of Siberia, including [[Demid Pyanda]], [[Fedot Alekseyev Popov]] and [[Semyon Dezhnyov]]. He was one of the first historians to write a general account of Russian history based on extensive examination of documentary sources. He '''put forth the so-called [[Normanist theory]]''', a controversial accentuation of the role of Scandinavians and Germans in the history of Russia.G.-F. MÃ¼ller and the Imperial Russian Academy, J. L. Black, 1986 |align=center|[[File:Saint Petersburg Kunstkamera view from the front.jpg|122px|thumb|center|[[Kunstkamera]], the first building of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], [[St.Petersburg]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Nikolay-Muravyov-Amursky.png|100px]] |'''[[Nikolay Muravyov-Amursky]]'''
(1809â1881)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''statesman, diplomat, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1847 Nikolay Muravyov was appointed '''the Governor General of Eastern Siberia'''. He '''pursued the Russian exploration and settlement of the territories north of the [[Amur River]]'''. He assisted in organisation of [[Gennady Nevelskoy]]'s expeditions, which led to the Russian presence near Amur estuary and on Sakhalin. In 1854 the military troops sailed down the Amur, and in 1855 the first settlers reached the river mouth. In 1856 the city of [[Blagoveshchensk]] was founded on Amur. During the last expedition of 1858, Muravyov '''concluded the [[Treaty of Aigun]] with [[China]]''', which recognised Amur River as a border between the two countries and granted Russia an easier access to the [[Pacific Ocean]]. The new territories acquired by Russia included [[Priamurye]] and most of the territories of modern [[Primorsky krai|Primorsky]] and [[Khabarovsk Krai]]s. For this achievement Muravyov was granted the title of Count Amursky (i.e., "of the Amur River"). The Treaty of Aigun was confirmed and expanded by the provisions of the [[Convention of Peking|Beijing Treaty]] of 1860, which granted Russia right to the [[Ussuri krai]] and southern parts of [[Primorsky Krai|Primorye]]. To defend the new lands Muravyov created the [[Amur Cossacks]] corps.Vladimir Barayev, "[http://www.peoples.ru/state/politics/muraviev/ ÐÐ¸ÐºÐ¾Ð»Ð°Ð¹ ÐÐ¸ÐºÐ¾Ð»Ð°ÐµÐ²Ð¸Ñ ÐÑÑÐ°Ð²ÑÑÐ²-ÐÐ¼ÑÑÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹]" (Nikolay Nikolayevich Muravyov-Amursky). ''ÐÐ»ÑÐ°Ð²Ð¸Ñ'' (''Alfavit'') newspaper, No. 30, 2000 {{ru icon}}[[Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary]] {{ru icon}}

[[Muravyov-Amursky Peninsula]] has been named after Muravyov-Amursky. |align=center|[[File:Ravenstein-p118-Sverbeyev-View-of-Aigun-1854.png|120px|thumb|center|Boats of Muravyov's first expedition off [[Aigun]]]][[File:Banknote 5000 rubles (1997) front.jpg|thumb|center|120px|Monument to Muravyov in [[Khabarovsk]] (5000 [[ruble]] banknote)]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Ivan Mushketov.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Ivan Mushketov]]'''
(1850â1902)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geologist, geographer, explorer of [[Central Asia]], [[Siberia]], the [[Urals]] and the [[Caucasus]]''' |In 1873-79 Mushketov '''traveled extensively in the [[Central Asia]]''', discovering and cataloguing mineral deposits. He '''produced the first geological map of [[Turkestan]]''' (together with S. Romanovsky). Mushketov also started observations of earthquakes in [[Kazakhstan]], organized regular observation of the glaciers of the [[Caucasus]], and researched the gold mines of the [[Urals]]. He led the team that surveyed the territory for the future [[Circum-Baikal Railway]].[http://www.rulex.ru/01130602.htm Mushketov's biography]{{ru icon}}

A glacier and a mountain in [[Antarctica]], a glacier in the [[Tian Shan]] Mountains, and a mountain in [[Republic of Buryatia|Buryatia]] are named after Mushketov. |align=center|[[File:Central Asia Physical.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Central Asia]]]] |} ===N=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:NagÃ³rski Jan.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Ivan Nagurski]]'''
(1888â1976)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Poland}}

'''engineer, [[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, pioneer of aviation, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Nagurski was among the first [[Aviator|pilots]] of the [[Imperial Russian Navy]]. In 1914 Nagurski was tasked with the difficult mission of locating the expeditions of [[Georgy Sedov]], [[Georgy Brusilov]], and [[Vladimir Rusanov]] in the Russian Arctic. Between August 21 and September 13, 1914, he flew five missions, spending more than ten hours in the air and travelling more than a thousand kilometres over land and the [[Barents Sea]] reaching as far as the [[76th parallel north]]. Nagurski failed to find the expeditions, but he became '''the first polar aviator in history''', and his experience was of much value to the subsequent polar flights. Later Nagurski performed the first ever loop with a flying boat, took part in the [[First World War]] and the [[Russian Civil War]], and was thought dead for several decades until regaining his fame in 1950s.{{cite book|author=A.B. Grigoriev|title=ÐÐ»ÑÐ±Ð°ÑÑÐ¾ÑÑ: ÐÐ· Ð¸ÑÑÐ¾ÑÐ¸Ð¸ Ð³Ð¸Ð´ÑÐ¾Ð°Ð²Ð¸Ð°ÑÐ¸Ð¸ (Albatroses: from the history of hydroaviation)|year=1989|publisher=ÐÐ°ÑÐ¸Ð½Ð¾ÑÑÑÐ¾ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ|location=Moscow|isbn=978-5-217-00604-5|url=http://militera.lib.ru/tw/grigoryev/01.html|page =272}}

''Nagurskoye'' meteorological station in [[Franz Josef Land]] was named after Nagurski. |align=center|[[File:1914. Nevel'skoy. 1989.jpg|120px]] |'''[[Gennady Nevelskoy]]'''
(1813â1876)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], explorer of the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1848 Nevelskoy led the expedition in the [[Russian Far East]], exploring the area of [[Sakhalin]] and the [[Amur Liman]] (which he found possible to sail through on the [[tall ship]]s). He '''proved that the [[Strait of Tartary]] was not a gulf, but indeed a strait''', connected to [[Amur River|Amur]]'s estuary by a narrow section later called [[Nevelskoy Strait]]. Not knowing about the efforts of [[Japan]]ese navigator [[Mamiya Rinzo]] who explored the same area forty years earlier, the Russians took Nevelskoy's report as the first proof that Sakhalin is indeed an island. In 1850 Nevelskoy '''founded [[Nikolayevsk-on-Amur]]''', the first Russian settlement in the lower [[Amur River]] region. He also founded several military posts on [[Sakhalin]]. For that Nevelskoy is credited as one of the key figures in the Russian colonisation of [[Primorsky Krai]] and [[Sakhalin]].[http://www.peoples.ru/military/admiral/nevelskoy/index.html Nevelskoy's biography] at peoples.ru {{ru icon}}

[[Nevelskoy Strait]], a city of [[Nevelsk]] on [[Sakhalin]] and Nevelskoy Marine State University in [[Vladivostok]] have been named after Gennady Nevelskoy. |align=center|[[File:Strait of Tartary.PNG|thumb|center|80px|[[Nevelskoy Strait]] is the narowest section of the [[Strait of Tartary]]]] |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center|[[File:RR5110-0018R.gif|120px]] |'''[[Afanasy Nikitin]]'''
(?â1472)
[[File:Coat of Arms of Tver (Tver oblast).png|20px]] [[Prince of Tver|Principality of Tver]]

'''merchant, early European traveler to [[Persia]] and [[India]]''' |In 1466, Nikitin left his hometown of [[Tver]] on a [[commerce|commercial]] trip to [[India]]. He traveled down the [[Volga River]], reached [[Derbent]], then [[Baku]] and later [[Persian Empire|Persia]] by crossing the [[Caspian Sea]], where he lived for a year. In 1469 Nikitin arrived to [[Ormus]] and then, crossing the [[Arabian Sea]], reached the sultanate of [[Bahmani]], where he lived for 3 years. On his way back, Nikitin visited the [[Africa]]n continent ([[Somalia]]), [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]], [[Trabzon]] and in 1472 arrived at [[Feodosiya]] by crossing the [[Black Sea]]. Thus Nikitin became '''one of the first [[Europe]]ans to travel to and to document his visit to [[India]]'''. He described his trip in a narrative known as''' ''[[A Journey Beyond the Three Seas]]'' '''(''Khozheniye za tri morya''). Nikitin had studied the population of India, its [[social]] system, [[government]], military (he witnessed war-games featuring [[war elephant]]s), its [[Economic system|economy]], [[religion]], lifestyles, and natural resources. Nikitin's book provide a valuable source of information about India at that time.[http://www.kamat.com/kalranga/itihas/nikitin.htm Nikitin - The first Russian traveler to India] by Dr. Jyotsna Kamat

There are monuments to Nikitin in his hometown of [[Tver]] and in [[Revdanda]] near [[Mumbai]] in [[India]]. In 1958, [[Mosfilm]] produced a film ''[[A Journey Beyond the Three Seas]]''. In 2006-07, the Indian organization ''"Adventures & Explorers"'' sponsored the "Nikitin Expedition", in which 14 travellers set out from [[Tver]] to retrace Nikitin's [[A Journey Beyond the Three Seas|journey beyond the three seas]]. |align=center|[[File:Iran topo en.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Iran]] ([[Persia]]) with [[Black Sea|Black]], [[Caspian Sea|Caspian]] and [[Arabian Sea|Arabian]] seas around]][[File:India Geographic Map.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[India]]]] |} ===O=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Vladimir A. Obruchev (timbre soviÃ©tique).jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vladimir Obruchev]]'''
(1863â1956)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[geologist]], geographer, explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Central Asia]], [[science fiction]] author''' |Having graduated from the [[Petersburg Mining Institute]] in 1886, Obruchev went to [[Siberia]]. He studied gold-mining and assisted in constructing [[Central Asian Railway|Central Asian]] and [[Trans-Siberian Railway]]s. In [[Central Asia]] he '''explored the [[Kara Kum]] Desert, the shores of the [[Amu Darya]] River, and the old riverbeds of the [[Uzbois]]'''. In 1892-94 Obruchev took part in the [[Grigory Potanin]]'s expedition to [[Mongolia]] and [[North China]]. He '''explored the [[Transbaikal]] area, [[Dzhungaria]] and [[Altai Mountains]]'''. Having '''spent half a century in exploring Siberia and Inner Asia''', Obruchev summarized his findings in the extensive work ''The Geology of Siberia''. He studied the origins of [[loess]], the [[ice]] formation and [[permafrost]], and the [[tectonics]] of [[Siberia]]. All together, he authored over a thousand scientific works. Obruchev is also known as '''the author of two popular [[science fiction]] novels, ''[[Hollow Earth|Plutonia]]'' (1915) and ''[[Sannikov Land]]'' (1924)'''. These stories, imitating the pattern of [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s ''[[The Lost World (Arthur Conan Doyle)|The Lost World]]'', depict in vivid detail the discovery of an isolated world of prehistoric animals in hitherto unexplored large islands in the [[Arctic]].[http://archivsf.narod.ru/persona/obruchev/obruchev.htm Obruchev's biography] {{ru icon}}

Obruchevite mineral, Akademik Obruchev Range in [[Tuva]], a mountain near the upper [[Vitim River]], an [[oasis]] in [[Antarctica]], [[Obruchev (crater)|Obruchev crater]] on the [[Moon]], the Obruchev Prize for works in the field of [[Siberia]]n geology, ''Vladimir Obruchev'' oil and gas research vessel and many streets and other places have been named after Obruchev. |align=center|[[File:Siberian craton location.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Ancient [[Siberia (continent)|Siberian craton]] in [[Eurasia]]]][[File:Zemli Sannikova.jpg|80px|thumb|center|[[Sannikov Land]] as it is presented in Obruchev's book]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Dmitry Ovtsyn.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Dmitry Ovtsyn]]'''
(? â after 1757)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[hydrographer]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1737-38 Ovtsyn led one of the units of the [[Great Northern Expedition]] that '''charted the coastline of the [[Kara Sea]] east of the [[Ob River]]''', making the first hydrographic description of the large [[Gydan Peninsula]] and part of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]]. In 1741-42 Ovtsyn took part in [[Vitus Bering]]'s voyage to the shores of [[North America]].[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_o/ovcyn_dl.html Ovtsyn's biography]{{ru icon}}

A cape on the [[Taimyr Peninsula]] and a [[strait]] between the islands [[Oleniy]] and [[Sibiryakow Island|Sibiryakov]] bear Ovtsyn's name. |align=center|[[File:Kara seaGY.PNG|120px|thumb|center|Location of the [[Gydan Peninsula]]]] |} ===P=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Pahtusov kronstadt.jpg|120px]] |'''[[Pyotr Pakhtusov]]'''
(1800â1835)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, hydrographer, [[Arctic]] explorer'''

(a monument in [[Kronstadt]]) |A participant of the earlier explorations by [[Fyodor Litke]], Pakhtusov '''led two expeditions to [[Novaya Zemlya]]''' in 1832 and 1835. He twice wintered on the islands and took detailed meteorological observations. Together with fellow explorer and cartographer [[Avgust Tsivolko]], Pakhtusov '''made the first reliable maps of Novaya Zemlya's southern shores'''.[http://www.rulex.ru/01160187.htm Pakhtusov's biography]{{ru icon}}

An island on the eastern shore of [[Novaya Zemlya]] and a group of islands in the [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]] are named after Pakhtusov. |align=center|[[File:Pechora sea4NZ.PNG|thumb|120px|center|Location of [[Novaya Zemlya]]]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Pallas Peter Simon 1741-1811.png|105px]] |'''[[Peter Simon Pallas]]'''
(1741â1811)
{{flag|Prussia}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''naturalist, zoologist and botanist, geographer, explorer of [[European Russia]] and [[Siberia]]''' |Born in [[Berlin]] and educated at German universities, Pallas was ivited by [[Catherine II of Russia]] to became a professor at the [[St Petersburg Academy of Sciences]]. In 1768-74, he '''led an academic expedition to [[Central economic region|central Russian provinces]], [[Povolzhye]], [[Caspian Sea]], [[Urals]], and [[Siberia]]''', reaching as far east as [[Transbaikal]]. The regular reports which Pallas sent to [[St. Petersburg]] covered a wide range of topics, including geology and mineralogy, native peoples and religions, new plants and animals. Pallas became a favourite of Catherine II, and was provided with the specimens collected by other naturalists to compile the ''Flora Rossica'' (publ. 1784-1815) and ''Zoographica Rosso-Asiatica'' (1811â31). He also published an account of [[Johann Anton GÃ¼ldenstÃ¤dt]]'s travels in the Caucasus and journals of [[Georg Wilhelm Steller]] from [[Kamchatka]] and [[Alaska]]. In 1793-94 Pallas '''led an expedition to southern Russia''', visiting the [[Crimea]] and the [[Black Sea]], the [[Caucasus]] and the valley of the [[Dnieper]]. He discovered and described a large number of new specimen and amassed a vast natural history collection.[http://www.free-time.ru/razdels/!anzikl/p_3.html Pallas's biography at free-time.ru/]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}

Streets in Berlin and [[Castrop-Rauxel]], a city of [[Pallasovka]] in [[Volgograd Oblast]], an [[asteroid]] [[21087 Petsimpallas]] were named after Pallas, as well as many animals, including [[Pallas's Cat]], [[Pallas's Squirrel]], [[Pallas's Gull]] and others. |[[File:Krasnojarsk meteorite old.jpg|thumb|120px|center|''[[Krasnojarsk (meteorite)|Krasnojarsk]]'', the first known [[pallasite]] meteorite]][[File:Pallas cat.JPG|thumb|120px|center|[[Pallas's Cat]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Ivan Papanin.jpg|105px]] |'''[[Ivan Papanin]]'''
(1894â1986)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Soviet Navy]] officer, [[Counter Admiral]], twice [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Arctic]] explorer'''

(On photo: a monument to Ivan Papanin on the street of his name in [[Murmansk]]) |In 1931 Papanin took part in the expedition of the [[icebreaker]] ''[[Icebreaker Malygin (1912)|Malygin]]'' to the [[Franz Josef Land]]. In 1932-33 he was the chief of a polar expedition in the [[Hooker Island|Tikhaya Bay]] on the Franz Josef Land. In 1934-35 he was the head of a polar station on the [[Cape Chelyuskin]]. In 1937-38 he was '''the head of the first [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|Soviet manned drifting ice station]] [[North Pole-1]]''', the world's first expedition of such kind. Together with Ernest Krenkel, [[Evgeny Fedorov]] and [[Petr Shirshov]] he landed on to the Arctic drifting ice-floes in an airplane flown by [[Mikhail Vasilyevich Vodopianov|Mikhail Vodopyanov]]. For 234 days the team carried out a wide range of scientific observations in the near-polar zone, until taken back. In 1939-46 Papanin became the head of the ''[[Chief Directorate of the Northern Sea Route|Glavsevmorput']]'', an establishment that oversaw operations on the [[Northern Sea Route]]. In 1940 he organized the expedition that rescued ice-trapped [[icebreaker]] "[[Icebreaker Sedov|Sedov]]", and subsequently he headed various naval institutions.[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_p/papanin_id.php Papanin's biography] at hrono.ru {{ru icon}}

A cape on the [[Taymyr Peninsula]], a mountain in [[Antarctica]], an underwater mountain in the [[Pacific Ocean]], a number of streets and an ice-class cargo and research ship have been named after Papanin. |align=center|[[File:Papanin with flag.jpg|thumb|100px|center|Ivan Papanin on the [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|Polar Station]] [[North Pole-1]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Maksim Perfilyev]]'''
(? â after 1638)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[voevoda]], explorer of [[Eastern Siberia]]''' |In 1618-19 Perfilyev became '''a co-founder of [[Yeniseysk]]y ostrog''', the first Russian fortress at the central [[Yenisey River]] and a major standpoint for further expeditions eastward. In 1618-27 Perfilyev made several journeys on [[Angara River|Angara]], [[Ilim River|Ilim]], [[Lena River|Lena]] and [[Vitim River|Vitim]] rivers, and built several new [[Ostrog (fortress)|ostrogs]]. In 1631 he '''founded [[Bratsk]]y ostrog (follow-up [[Bratsk]])'''. In 1638 he became '''the first Russian to step in [[Transbaikalia]]'''.[http://www.vsp.ru/show_article.php?id=37293 The Perfilyevs family]{{ru icon}}[http://www.sbaikal.ru/rus/region/history.html Ð¢ÑÐ¾Ð¿Ð¾Ñ Ð·ÐµÐ¼Ð»ÐµÐ¿ÑÐ¾ÑÐ¾Ð´ÑÐµÐ²]{{ru icon}}

The Maksimikha Bay at [[Lake Baikal]] (part of [[Barguzin Bay]]), Cape Maksimin and a village Maksimikha there (founded by Perfilyev ans his [[Buryats|Buryat]] wife), as well as the village of Maksimovschina on [[Irkut River]] are named after Maksim Perfilyev. |align=center|[[File:Yeniseirivermap.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Yenisey]] watershed]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Yakov Permyakov]]'''
(? â 1712)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossack]], seafarer, merchant, Arctic explorer''' |In 1710, while sailing from the [[Lena River]] to the [[Kolyma River]], Permyakov '''discovered the [[Medvyezhi Islands]]''', siting them from afar. During the same voyage he also observed the follow-up [[Bolshoy Lyakhovsky]] island, known to the earlier explorers but never reached so far. In 1712, Permyakov and his companion [[Merkury Vagin]] crossed the [[Yana Bay]] from the mouth of the [[Yana River|Yana]] over the ice and '''explored [[Bolshoy Lyakhovsky]] island, the southernmost of the [[New Siberian Islands]]'''. Thus they initiated the exploration of the large New Siberian archipelago. On their way back Permyakov and Vagin were murdered by mutineering expedition members.[http://qwercus.narod.ru/vise_1948.htm Russian polar seafarers of XVII-XVIIIth cc.] by [[Vladimir Vize]] {{ru icon}} |[[File:Medvezhy.PNG|thumb|center|120px|[[Medvyezhi Islands]] in the [[East Siberian Sea]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" | |'''[[Ivan Petlin]]'''
(? â after 1619)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]], diplomat, explorer of [[Central Asia]] and [[China]]''' |Petlin was '''the first Russian to reach [[China]] on an official diplomatic mission''' in 1618-19. His expedition may have been the second European expedition to reach China from the west by an overland route (after that of [[Bento de GÃ³is]]) since the fall of the [[Yuan Dynasty]]. Together with Andrei Mundov and 10 other men, Petlin went south up the [[Ob River]], crossed the [[Abakan Range]], went south to [[Tuva]] and rounding [[Uvs Nuur|Lake Ubsa]] reached the court of the [[Altan Khan of the Khotgoid|Altyn Khan]]. Then they passed through [[Mongolia]] to the [[Great Wall of China]] and [[Peking]]. He was not allowed to see the [[Wanli Emperor]] because of not bringing proper tribute, so he returned back. He brought back a letter in Chinese inviting Russians to open trade, but no one in Russia was able to read it until 1675. A vague but still valuable account of Petlin's expedition was translated into English and published in [[Samuel Purchas]]' ''Pilgrims'' in 1625, and then translated to other European languages.Mark Mancall, Russia and China: Their Diplomatic Relations to 1728, 1971. |align=center|[[File:Russia China Locator.png|thumb|center|120px|Petlin's expedition was the first step to establish [[Russia-China relations]]]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:Valeri Polyakov.jpg|95px]] |'''[[Valeri Polyakov]]'''
(born 1942)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''[[cosmonaut]] and [[physician]], [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Hero of the Russian Federation]] |Polyakov ''' holds the world record for the longest continuous [[spaceflight]] in history, 437 days 18 hours (more than 14 months)''', which he spent aboard ''[[Soyuz TM-18]]'', ''[[Mir]]'' [[space station]] and ''[[Soyuz TM-20]]'' in 1994-95. With his earlier expedition to ''Mir'' on ''[[Soyuz TM-6]]'' and back on ''[[Soyuz TM-7]]'' in 1988-89, his combined space experience is more than 22 months.[http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/31/science/space/31mars.html Staying Put on Earth, Taking a Step to Mars] |align=center|[[File:Mir as seen from Discovery during STS-63.jpg|120px|thumb|center|''[[Mir]]'' [[space station|SS]] with [[Soyuz TM-20]] at the top]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:RR5217-0027R.gif|120px]] |'''[[Fedot Alekseyev Popov|Fedot Popov]]'''
(? â 1648-54)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''merchant, explorer of [[Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |An agent of [[Moscow]] merchant Alexey Usov, Fedot Popov came to [[Srednekolymsk]] in [[Siberia]] in 1645. There he organized an expedition eastward, and carried in [[Semyon Dezhnev]]. In 1648 they sailed down to the [[Arctic]] and became '''the first to pass through the [[Bering Strait]] and to discover [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] and [[Bering Sea]]'''. All their [[koch (boat)|kochs]] and most of their men (including Popov himself) were lost in storms and clashes with the natives. A small group led by Dezhnyov reached the [[Anadyr River]]. In 1653-54, while fighting with [[Koryaks]] near [[Anadyrsk]], Dezhnyov captured Popov's [[Yakuts|Yakut]] wife, who confirmed him dead. When [[Vladimir Atlasov]] came to conquer [[Kamchatka]] in 1697, he heard from the locals about a certain ''Fedotov'', who had lived with his men near [[Kamchatka River]] and had married local women - so the ''Fedotov legend'' appeared. [[Gerhardt Friedrich MÃ¼ller]] thought he was probably Fedot's son, while [[Stepan Krasheninnikov]] thought he was Fedot himself, thus deeming Fedot Popov to be '''the possible discoverer of [[Kamchatka]]'''. |align=center|[[File:Kitchen-21-Russia-Chukotka-2823.jpg|thumb|center|120px|1773 map of [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]], showing the 1648 route of Popov and Dezhnyov]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Posyet.jpg|105px]] |'''[[Konstantin Posyet]]'''
(1819â1899)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], military writer, statesman, diplomat, explorer of [[Pacific]], [[Japan]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1852-54, Possiet '''journeyed on the frigate ''Pallas'' to [[Japan]]''' under the command of admirals [[Yevfimy Putyatin]] and [[Ivan Unkovsky]]. Accompanied also by novelist [[Ivan Goncharov]] and inventor [[Alexander Mozhaisky]], Possiet '''explored and mapped the northern coastline of the [[Sea of Japan]], including [[Possiet Bay]]''', which now bears his name. In 1856 he carried to Japan the news of the ratification of the [[Treaty of Shimoda]]. Possiet's journeys and published observations made an expert on Japan in Russia. In 1875, already a Minister of Ways and Communications of Russia, he negotiated with [[Enomoto Takeaki]] the [[Treaty of Saint Petersburg (1875)|Treaty of Saint Petersburg]], which brought entire [[Sakhalin Island]] into the Russian fold. He prepared the construction of the [[Trans-Siberian Railway]] and was a leading advocate for the restoration of the familiar white-blue-red tricolor as the official [[flag of Russia]] in 1896.[http://funeral-spb.narod.ru/necropols/novodev/tombs/poset/poset.html Posyet's biography] at funeral-spb.narod.ru {{ru icon}}

[[Possiet Bay]] in the [[Sea of Japan]], [[Posyet]] port there, and a street in [[Vladivostok]] are named after Konstantin Posyet. |align=center|[[File:Furugelm sat.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Possiet Bay]] in the [[Russian Far East]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Potanin.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Grigory Potanin]]'''
(1835â1920)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geographer, ethnographer, botanist, explorer of [[Siberia]], [[Central Asia]] and [[China]]''' |Potanin traveled extensively through [[Siberia]], studying its nature and peoples, once accompanied by [[Nikolai Yadrintsev]]. In 1876 and 1879 Potanin '''led two expeditions into Mongolia''', obtaining valuable material in all fields of geography. In 1884-86 Potanin '''explored the Northern [[China]] and [[Tibet]]''', returning to Russia through [[Qilian Mountains]] and Mongolia. They encountered a [[Turkish people]] called the [[Salar people|Salars]] and made other ethnographic and geographic discoveries, including the first account of East and West [[Uighur language]]s. In 1989 Potanin became one of the founders of [[Tomsk University]], the first university in [[Asian Russia]]. In 1892-93 he again explored the Northern [[China]] and [[Sichuan]] accompanied by geologist [[Vladimir Obruchev]]. Before reaching Tibet, Potanin was forced to turn back because of the illness and death of his wife Alexandra, who was the first woman in the [[Russian Geographical Society]]. In 1899 Potanin travelled onto [[Greater Khingan]].[http://www.siberianclub.ru/Rare_Books/Hero/27/5 Potanin's biography] at siberianclub.ru {{ru icon}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}}

A ridge in [[Qilian Mountains]] in [[China]], the [[Potanin Glacier|largest glacier]] in [[Altai Tavan Bogd]] ([[Altai Mountains]]), a number of streets in [[Siberia]]n cities, several dozens of plants and [[9915 Potanin]] asteroid were named after Potanin. |[[File:Tibet Karte Topograpisch.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Tibetan Plateau]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:RR5216-0032R.gif|120px]] |'''[[Vassili Poyarkov]]'''
(? â after 1668)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[ataman]], explorer of [[Eastern Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1643, Poyarkov with 133 men were sent from [[Yakutsk]] to explore new lands south of [[Stanovoy Ridge]]. Having no idea of the proper route, Poyarkov traveled up the rivers [[Lena River|Lena]], [[Aldan River|Aldan]], [[Uchur]], [[Gonam]] and passed over the Stanovoy watershed only by winter, reaching the upper [[Zeya River]] in the country of [[Daur people|Daurs]], who were paying tribute to [[Manchu]] [[China|Chinese]]. After wintering, in 1644 Poyarkov pushed down the Zeya and became ''' the first Russian to reach the [[Amur River]]'''. He reached the [[Nivkh people|Gilyak]] country and '''discovered the mouth of the [[Amur River]]''' from land. Since his Cossacks provoked the enmity of the locals behind, Poyarkov chose different way back. They built boats and in 1645 sailed along the [[Sea of Okhotsk]] coast to the [[Ulia River]] and spent the next winter in the huts that had been built by explorer [[Ivan Moskvitin]] six years earlier. In 1646 they returned to Yakutsk.[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_p/pojarkov_vd.php Poyarkov's biography] at hrono.ru {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Amurrivermap.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Amur River]] watershed]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Gavriil Pribylov]]'''
(? â 1796)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''navigator, explorer of [[Alaska]] and [[Bering Sea]]''' |Pribylov, a commander of the ship ''St. George'', led an expedition funded jointly by [[Grigory Shelikhov]] and [[Pavel Lebedev-Lastochkin]] with an aim to find the lucrative breeding grounds of fur seals, long sought by Siberian merchants. Pribylov '''discovered [[St. George Island (Alaska)|St. George Island]] in the [[Bering Sea]]''' in 1786, by following the sounds of barking [[northern fur seal]]s and possibly hinted by [[Aleutian Island|Aleutian]] natives. Mixed Russian and [[Aleut people|Aleut]] crew of ''St. George'' established the international hunting for northern fur seals (continued for over a century until [[North Pacific Fur Seal Convention of 1911|banned by international treaty in 1911]]). A year later in 1787, Pribylov '''discovered [[Saint Paul Island (Alaska)|St. Paul Island]]''' 50 miles to the north of St. George.{{cite book|last=Black|first=Lydia|title=Russians in Alaska, 1732-1867|location=pg. 104|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NSRxrDm0JYYC&pg=PA102&lpg=PA102&dq=Pribilof+Shelikhov&source=bl&ots=McLg3D1JDd&sig=d9awmbjITx45_TAcCIQ4VvkH4uQ&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA104,M1}} {{cite web|title=Pribilof Islands Restoration Project Historical Overview|publisher=[[NOAA]]|date=November 10, 2005|url=http://response.restoration.noaa.gov/topic_subtopic_entry.php?RECORD_KEY(entry_subtopic_topic)=entry_id,subtopic_id,topic_id&entry_id(entry_subtopic_topic)=180&subtopic_id(entry_subtopic_topic)=12&topic_id(entry_subtopic_topic)=2|accessdate = January 22, 2009}}

[[Pribilof Islands]] ([[St. George Island (Alaska)|St. George Island]] and [[Saint Paul Island (Alaska)|St. Paul Island]]) are named after Pribylov. |align=center|[[File:PribilofIslands.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Pribilof Islands]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Pronchishchev Vasili.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Vasili Pronchishchev]]'''
(1702â1736)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Arctic]] explorer'''
([[forensic]] facial reconstruction) |In 1735-36 Pronchishchev led one of the units of the [[Great Northern Expedition]] that '''discovered and mapped more than 500 of the [[Arctic]] shore to the west of the mouth of [[Lena River]]'''. He took his wife [[Maria Pronchishcheva]] with himself, aboard the [[sloop]] ''Yakutsk''. Despite the difficulties, they reached [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]] in 1736, having '''discovered the follow-up [[Faddey Islands]], [[Komsomolskoy Pravdy Islands]], [[Saint Peter Islands]], and the east of [[Byrranga Mountains]] on Taymyr'''. Pronchishchev and his wife died from illness on the way back and were buried in the mouth of the [[Olenek River]]

A part of the eastern coastline of the [[Taymyr Peninsula]], a lake and a cape in the east of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]], a ridge between the mouths of the [[Olenek]] and [[Anabar River]]s, and [[icebreaker]] ''Vasili Pronchishchev'' bear Pronchishchev's name. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2KP.PNG|120px|thumb|center|[[Komsomolskaya Pravda Islands]] at the northeastern end of the [[Taymyr Peninsula]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Pronchischeva Maria.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Maria Pronchishcheva]]'''
(1710â1736)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''first female [[Arctic]] explorer'''
([[forensic]] facial reconstruction) |Maria Pronchishcheva (or Tatiana according to some sources) accompanied her husband [[Vasili Pronchishchev]] in 1735-36, during the [[Great Northern Expedition]], when they explored the coastline west of the mouth of [[Lena River]], making many discoveries. She '''is considered to be the first female explorer of [[Arctic]]'''. Maria died from illness on the way back, only 14 days after the death of her husband Vasili.

[[Maria Pronchishcheva Bay]] of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]] in the [[Laptev Sea]] is named after Pronchishcheva. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2MP.PNG|120px|thumb|center|Location of [[Maria Pronchishcheva Bay]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Przewalski.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolai Przhevalsky]]'''
(1839â1888)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
([[Polish people|Polish]] descent)

'''[[Imperial Russian Army]] officer, [[Major General]], [[geographer]], [[naturalist]], explorer of [[Central Asia]] and [[China]]''' |In 1867-69 Przhevalsky led an expedition to the basin of [[Ussuri River]] in the [[Russian Far East|Far East]]. Subsequently he '''made a four major journeys to largely unknown parts of [[Central Asia]], in the total covering more than 40,000 km in length'''. In 1870-73 he crossed the [[Gobi]] desert to [[Beijing]], explored the upper [[Yangtze River]], and crossed into [[Tibet]], surveying over 18,000 km2 and collecting some 5,000 plants species, 1000 birds, 3,000 insects, 70 reptiles and the skins of 130 different mammals. The results of this journey were highly appreciated in Russia, both by [[Russian Geographical Society|Geographical Society]] and Russian military. In 1876-77, travelling through [[Eastern Turkestan]] and the [[Tian Shan range]], he visited Lake [[Lop Nor]]. In 1879-80 he traveled via [[Hami City|Hami]] and the [[Qaidam]] basin to Lake [[Koko Nor]]. Passing over [[Tian Shan]] into Tibet, he was short of 260 km from [[Lhasa]] before being turned back by Tibetan officials. In 1883-85 Przhevalsky traveled across [[Gobi]] to [[Alashan, Kyrgyzstan|Alashan]] and Tian Shan, then back to Koko Nor, and westwards to Lake [[Issyk Kul]]. His journeys opened a new era for the study of geography, fauna and flora of Central Asia. He '''was the first to report on the wild population of [[Bactrian Camel]]s, to describe the [[Przewalski's Gazelle]] and the [[Przewalski's Horse]]''' (the only extant [[wild horse]]).[http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_p/przevalski_nm.php Przhevalsky's biography] at hrono.ru {{ru icon}}

[[Przewalski's Gazelle]], [[Przewalski's Horse]] and other species, a ridge in [[Kunlun Mountains|Kunlun]], a glacier in [[Altai Mountains|Altai]], [[Przhevalsk]] town (now [[Karakol]]) in [[Kyrgyzstan]] and his native [[Przhevalskoye]] viilage in near [[Smolensk]] have been named after Przhevalsky. |align=center|[[File:Przewalski's Horse at The Wilds.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Przewalski's Horse]]]][[File:ÐÐ°Ð¼ÑÑÐ½Ð¸Ðº ÐÑÐ¶ÐµÐ²Ð°Ð»ÑÑÐºÐ¾Ð¼Ñ Ð² ÐÐ»ÐµÐºÑÐ°Ð½Ð´ÑÐ¾Ð²ÑÐºÐ¾Ð¼ ÑÐ°Ð´Ñ 2.jpg|thumb|center|100px|Monument in [[St. Petersburg]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Putyatin.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Yevfimy Putyatin]]'''
(1803â1883)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], diplomat, explorer of [[Pacific]], [[Japan]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1822-25 Putyatin sailed with [[Mikhail Lazarev]] around the world aboard ''[[Suvorov]]''. Later he led diplomatic missions to [[Iran]] and the [[Caucasus]]. Together with Admiral [[Ivan Unkovsky]] they '''led a scientific expedition on the frigate ''Pallada'' '''through the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], [[Indian Ocean|Indian]] and [[Pacific Ocean]]s to [[Japan]] in 1852-55. This expedition '''contributed many important discoveries in [[oceanography]]'''. One of the results achieved was the [[Treaty of Shimoda]] between Japan and Russia. In 1857-58 Putyatin twice traveled to both Japan and China and '''explored [[Peter the Great Gulf]], [[Russky Island]], [[Eastern Bosphorus]]''' and other features of the Russian shores of the [[Sea of Japan]].[http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/acd/re/k-rsc/ras/publication/kiyo_en/06/6_05.pdf Frigate ''Pallada'' in Japan and the Friendship Treaty between Japan and Russia] {{dead link|date=June 2011}}

An island in the [[Peter the Great Gulf]] ([[Russian Far East]]), a cape in [[Anadyr Bay]] ([[Bering Sea]]) and a number of ships have been named after Putyatin. |align=center|[[File:Bay of Peter the Great.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Peter the Great Gulf]] in the [[Russian Far East]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Demid Pyanda]]'''
(? â after 1637)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossacks|Siberian Cossack]] [[ataman]], explorer of [[Eastern Siberia]]''' |Coming from [[Mangazeya]], Demid Pyanda was a great hunter for [[Siberia]]n [[fur]]s. Starting his long journey from [[Turukhansk]], in three and a half years from 1620 to 1624 Pyanda '''passed the total of 8000 km of hitherto unknown large Siberian rivers'''. He explored some 2300 km of [[Lower Tunguska]] (Nizhnyaya Tunguska in [[Russian language|Russian]]) and, having reached the upper part of Tunguska, he '''discovered the great Siberian river [[Lena River|Lena]]''' and explored some 2400 km of its length. When doing this, he became '''the first Russian to reach [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]] and meet [[Yakuts]]'''. He returned back up Lena until it became too rocky and shallow, and by land reached [[Angara]]. On this way, Pyanda became '''the first Russian to meet [[Buryats]]'''. He built new boats and '''explored some 1400 km of [[Angara]]''', finally discovering that [[Angara]] (a [[Buryats|Buryat]] name) and [[Upper Tunguska]] (Verkhnyaya Tunguska, as initially known by Russians) are one and the same river.[http://www.randewy.ru/karta/geogr24.html The discovery of Central and Eastern Siberia by Russians] {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Siberiariverroutemap.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Siberian river routes]]]] |} ===R=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Monument to Semyon Remezov.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Semyon Remezov]]'''
(c. 1642 â after 1720)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''cartographer, geographer, historian, explorer of [[Siberia]]'''
(a monument in the [[Tobolsk]] Kremlin) |In 1683-1710 Remezov '''described and mapped the [[Tobolsk]] region''', where he was born. He '''wrote the ''[[Remezov Chronicle]]'', one of the earliest historical accounts of [[Siberia]]''' and its exploration, a part of [[Siberian Chronicles]]. In 1699-1701 he '''created the ''Chart book of Siberia'', the first large format cartographic [[atlas]] of [[Siberia]]'''. Apart from that he made more than two hundreds of charts and maps of eastern Russian regions.[http://www.mmedia.nsu.ru/remezov/vbook/obj8/title.htm The 17th-century Siberia seen by a man of the times. S.U. Remezov and his "Siberian History"], many illustrations {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:IstSib005 3.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Siberian peoples]] as depicted in the [[Remezov Chronicle]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Rezanov np.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolai Rezanov]]'''
(1764â1807)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''statesman, diplomat, explorer of [[Alaska]] and [[North Pacific]]''' |Rezanov was '''one of the founders of [[Russian-American Company]]''' in 1799, formed on the basis of [[Shelikhov-Golikov Company]]. In 1803-06, made an ambassador to [[Japan]] by Emperor [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]], Rezanov '''co-led the [[first Russian circumnavigation]] of the world''', aboard ''[[Nadezhda (Russian warship)|Nadezhda]]'' under the captaincy of [[Ivan Krusenstern]], together with [[Yuri Lisianski]] on ''[[Neva (Russian warship)|Neva]]''. Rezanov was in command as far as [[Kamchatka]]. After his embassy to Japan failed, he was made an inspector of Russian colonies in America. In 1806 he sailed to [[San Francisco]] and managed to open a trade with [[Spanish California]], concluded a treaty and engaged with [[ConcepciÃ³n ArgÃ¼ello]], the daughter of the comandante of San Francisco. Rezanov died in [[Siberia]], however, on journey back to [[St. Petersburg]] carrying the treaty to the capital.* [http://rezanov.kkr.ru/biogr.htm Rezanov online museum] {{ru icon}}
