Rezanov's love affair with [[ConcepciÃ³n ArgÃ¼ello]] inspired a ballad by the [[San Francisco]] author, [[Francis Bret Harte]], and a 1937 novel, ''RezÃ¡nov and DoÃ±a Concha'', by another SF author, [[Gertrude Atherton]], as well as a very successful Russian [[rock opera]] ''[[Juno and Avos (opera)|Juno and Avos]]'' by the composer [[Alexei Rybnikov]] and the poet [[Andrey Voznesensky]] in 1979. |align=center|[[File:Trading post at Old Sitka (1).jpg|100px|center|thumb|A replica of Russian trading post in New Archangel ([[Sitka, Alaska]]).]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Voin Rimsky-Korsakov.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Voin Rimsky-Korsakov]]'''
(1822â1871)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, hydroghafer and geographer, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]]''' |A senior brother of [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]] (famous composer and conductor), Voin Rimsky-Korsakov became a naval officer. In 1839 he took part in the describing of [[Finland]] shores. Later he was the commander of [[schooner]] ''Vostok'' in [[flotilla]] under administration of [[Admiral]] [[Yevfimy Putyatin]]. In 1850s and 1860s Rimsky-Korsakov '''explored the area of the [[Sea of Japan]] near [[Ussuri Krai]]''', including the [[Sakhalin Island]], the [[Amur Liman]] and the [[Strait of Tartary]]. Later he also surveyed the shores of [[Kamchatka]] and [[Kuril Islands]].[http://www.biografija.ru/show_bio.aspx?id=111812 Voin Rimsky-Korsakov's biography] at biografija.ru {{ru icon}}]

[[Rimsky-Korsakov Archipelago]] in the [[Sea of Japan]] has been named after Voin Rimsky-Korsakov. |align=center|[[File:Rimskogo-Korsakova archipelago.png|100px|thumb|center|[[Rimsky-Korsakov Archipelago]] in the [[Sea of Japan]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Helena Roerich 1.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Helena Roerich]]'''
(1879â1955)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|United States}}
{{flag|India}}

'''philosopher, writer, public figure, traveler, explorer of [[Central Asia]], [[China]] and [[India]]''' |Helena Roerich was an organizer and participant of cultural and enlightened creativity in the [[U. S.]], conducted under the guidance of her husband, [[Nicholas Roerich]]. Along with her husband, she '''took part in expedition to the little-investigated regions of [[Central Asia]]''' in 1924-28. She was an Honorary President-Founder of the Institute of Himalayan Studies Â«UrusvatiÂ» in India and co-author of idea of the International Treaty for Protection of Artistic and Scientific Institutions and Historical Monuments ([[Roerichâs Pact]]).[http://www.icr.su/eng International Centre of the Roerichs] (Moscow)

Various institutions, [[minor planet]] [[4426 Roerich]], peak ''Urusvati'' in [[Altai Mountains]] and pass in [[Tian Shan]] were named after Helena Roerich. |[[File:Altai. Peaks and passes named in honor of the family Roerich.jpeg|thumb|120px|center|[[Altai Republic|Altai]], peaks and passes named in honor of the [[Roerich family]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:N Roerich.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nicholas Roerich]]'''
(1874â1947)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|United States}}
{{flag|India}}

'''painter, philosopher, archeologist, writer, public figure, traveler, explorer of [[Central Asia]], [[China]] and [[India]]''' |A famous [[Russian painters|Russian painter]], Roerich emigrated to the [[U. S.]] after [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian Revolution]]. By sale of his paintings and writings, and gain from activity of his cultural and enlightener organizations in America, Roerich was able to collect the finance and '''led a major expedition to [[Central Asia]]''' in 1924-28. The expedition went through [[Sikkim]], [[Kashmir]], [[Ladakh]], [[China]] ([[Xinjiang]]), [[Russia]] (including [[Moscow]]), [[Siberia]], [[Altai Krai|Altai]], [[Mongolia]], [[Tibet]], unstudied areas of the [[Himalayas]]. Archeological and ethnographical investigations were conducted, dozens of new mountain peaks and passes were marked on maps, rarest manuscripts were found, and some of the best series of Roerich's paintings were created. In 1934â35 Roerich '''conducted an expedition in [[Inner Mongolia]], [[Manchuria]] and [[China]]''', collecting nearly 300 species of xerophytes, herbs, manuscript and archeological relics. Roerich was an author and initiator of an international pact for the protection of artistic and academic institutions and historical sites ([[Roerichâs Pact]], 1935) and a founder of an international movement for the defence of culture. He created about 7,000 paintings and founded a number of scientific and cultural institutions in the [[United States]], [[Europe]] and [[India]].L.V.Shaposhnikova. [http://www.icr.su/rus/evolution/cae/index.php From Altai to Himalayas. Along the path of Central-Asian Expedition of N. Roerich.] â Moscow, International Centre of the Roerichs, Master-Bank, 1998.[http://www.icr.su/rus/evolution/cae/more/uchastniki.php Participants, chronology, bibliography of Central-Asian Expedition of N. Roerich are on the website of International Centre of the Roerichs.]

[[Roerichâs Pact]], various institutions, [[minor planet]] [[4426 Roerich]], a peak and a pass in [[Altai Mountains]], two passes and a glacier in [[Tian Shan]] were named after Nicholas Roerich. |align=center|[[File:Song of Shambhala.jpg|thumb|center|120px|''Song of [[Shambhala]]'' by N. Roerich]][[File:Urusvati base.jpg|thumb|center|120px|Institute of [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] studies âUrusvatiâ, founded by Roerichs]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Rusanov vladimir.PNG|100px]] |'''[[Vladimir Rusanov]]'''
(1875â1913?)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geologist, [[Arctic]] explorer |In 1909-11 Rusanov '''carried out explorations in [[Novaya Zemlya]] archipelago'''. In 1912 he '''commanded a government expedition to [[Svalbard]] to investigate its [[coal]] reserves'''. They sailed on a small ship ''[[Herkules]]'' under Captain [[Alexander Kuchin]], [[Roald Amundsen]]'s [[South Pole]] expedition navigator. Concluding the work, part of the expedition members returned to [[Russia]] via [[Norway]], while the rest without consultation with the authorities in [[St. Petersburg]], set off with Rusanov in an incredibly rash attempt at reaching the [[Pacific]] via the [[Northern Sea Route]], and disappeared in the [[Kara Sea]]. The relics of the expedition were found in 1937 in [[Kolosovykh Islands]] group. [[Soviet]] coal mining on [[Svalbard]] began in 1932.[http://www.cprm.gov.br/33IGC/1343811.html Rusanov's biography][http://museum.ru/M635 Webpage of Rusanov's museum in Oryol] {{ru icon}}

A glacier on [[Severnaya Zemlya]], a bay and a peninsula on [[Novaya Zemlya]], a mountain in [[Antarctic]], streets in [[Moscow]], [[Severodvinsk]] and [[Oryol]] (the city of Rusanov's birth) and several ships were named after Rusanov. Rusanov and his expedition are among the prototypes for the novel ''[[The Two Captains]]'' by [[Veniamin Kaverin]], where the search proceedings for fictional captain Tatarinov resemble the search for Rusanov. |align=center|[[File:Hercules schooner Rusanov.jpg|thumb|center|120px|''[[Hercules]]'' [[schooner]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Rybin GN.JPG|100px]] |'''[[Georgy Rybin]]'''
(1901â1974)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Soviet Navy]] officer, hydrographer, explorer of the [[Arctic]] and the [[Baltic Sea]] |In 1922-33 Rybin '''participated in hydrographic works on [[Ob River|Ob]] and [[Yenisey River]]s'''. In 1922 he found the remnants of [[Peter Tessem and Paul Knutsen|Peter Tessem]], a lost member of [[Roald Amundsen|Amundsen's]] expedition on ''[[Maud (ship)|Maud]]''. Since 1933 he '''made hydrographic works on the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]]''', which became especially important during [[World War II]] and the [[Siege of Leningrad]].S.V. Popov "Autographs on the charts"- Arkhangelsk, 1990 ISBN 978-5-85560-153-4

Rybin-yaha River, flowing into the [[Gulf of Ob]] and charted by Rybin, and Rybin seamount in the [[Atlantic]] west of the [[Canary Islands]], are named after Rybin. |align=center|[[File:ÐÐ¸Ð¡Ñ ÐÐ½ÐµÐ¹.jpg|120px|center|thumb|Rybin's ship ''Iney'' in the [[Gulf of Ob]], [[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Alexander Newski.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Alexander Nevsky]]''' ([[Rurikid]])
(1220â1263)
[[File:Christos Acheiropoietos.jpg|23px]] [[Novgorod Republic]]
[[File:Vladimirskaya.jpg|22px]] [[Vladimir-Suzdal]]

'''medieval Grand [[Prince of Novgorod]] and [[Vladimir-Suzdal|Vladimir]], national hero and saint of [[Russia]], traveler to [[Central Asia]]''' |A famous warrior, Russian Prince [[Alexander Nevsky|Alexander Yaroslavich Nevsky]] '''traveled into [[Mongolian Empire|Mongolian]] capital [[Karakorum]] in [[Central Asia]]''', between 1247â49, accompanied by his brother [[Andrey II of Vladimir|Andrey Yaroslavich]]. They were summoned there by [[Genghisid]] [[Khan (title)|Khans]] who had conquered [[Rus' (region)|Rus']] a few years before. Unlike their father [[Yaroslav II of Vladimir]], who had come into Karakorum in 1245-46 and was poisoned by the Mongols, princes Alexander and Andrey were able to get back to Rus', confirmed in power by their new overlords. Russian princes were among the first known Europeans to travel so far into [[Asia]], making their journey around the same time as [[Italia]]n monk [[Plano Carpini]] traveled to [[Mongolia]].[http://www.pereslavl.info/page-id-8.html Alexander Nevsky] at pereslavl.info {{ru icon}}

Multiple churches, monasteries, streets, squares, ships and other objects are named after [[Alexander Nevsky]] in Russia. |align=center|[[File:Alexander Nevsky 1942.jpg|thumb|center|120px|''[[Alexander Nevsky]]'' by [[N. Roerich]]]] |} ===S=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Vladimir Putin 21 February 2008-10.jpg|120px]] |'''[[Anatoly Sagalevich]]'''
(born 1938)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''deepwater explorer, [[Hero of the Russian Federation]]'''

(right on photo with [[Vladimir Putin]]) |Since 1979 Sagalevich is the head of Deepwater Submersibles Laboratory at [[Shirshov Institute of Oceanology]]. He took part in the construction of Pisces VIII, Pisces IX and [[MIR (submersible)|MIR]] [[Deep Submergence Vehicle]]s (DSV) and '''completed more than 300 submersions as the chief pilot of DSVs'''. He '''piloted MIRs during expeditions to [[RMS Titanic|RMS ''Titanic'']]''', German battleship [[German battleship Bismarck|''Bismarck'']], Soviet and Russian submarines ''[[K-278 Komsomolets]]'' and ''[[K-141 Kursk]]'', and Japanese ''[[Japanese submarine I-52 (1943)|I-52]]''. Sagalevich '''holds the world record for the deepest fresh water dive at 1637 m''' in [[Lake Baikal]] aboard a Pisces in 1990. On August 2, 2007, he was the pilot of MIR-1 DSV that '''reached the [[seabed]] at the [[North Pole]]''' during [[Arktika 2007]] expedition.[http://www.deepoceanexpeditions.com/azores9.html Deep Ocean Expeditions] {{dead link|date=June 2011}}[http://www.divingalmanac.com/records_baikal.html DivingAlmanac.com] {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |align=center| |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Rudolf Samoylovich.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Rudolf Samoylovich]]'''
(1881â1940?)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1912 Samoylovich took part in [[Vladimir Rusanov]]'s geological expedition to [[Spitsbergen]]. He was '''one of the initiators and the first director of the [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]]''' in 1920-30 and 1932-38. He was also the founder and the first chairman of the Polar Countries' Department at [[Leningrad State University]]. In 1928 he was '''the head of the rescue party on the [[Krasin (1916 icebreaker)|''Krasin'']] icebreaker, that saved most of the crew of ''[[Airship Italia]]'' ''' of [[Umberto Nobile]]. Also, he '''participated in the polar flight of [[LZ 127 Graf Zeppelin|''Graf Zeppelin'']]''' in 1931 and headed expeditions on icebreakers ''Vladimir Rusanov'' (1932), ''[[Georgy Sedov (icebreaker)|Georgy Sedov]]'' (1934), and [[Icebreaker Sadko|''Sadko'']] (1936 and 1937â38).[http://www.aari.nw.ru/docs/dates/samaylovich.html Samoylovich's biography] {{ru icon}}

A strait and a glacier top on [[Franz Josef Land]], a bay on [[Novaya Zemlya]], an island in [[Severnaya Zemlya]], a mountain and a peninsula in the [[Antarctica]] bear Rudolf Samoylovich's name. |align=center|[[File:Krasin ice.PNG|120px|center|thumb|Icebreaker [[Krasin (1916 icebreaker)|''Krasin'']] among the ice floes in the Arctic]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Yakov Sannikov]]'''
(1780 â after 1812)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''merchant, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Sannikov is known for his explorations of the [[New Siberian Islands]]. In 1800, he '''discovered and charted [[Stolbovoy Island]], and then [[Faddeyevsky Island]]''' in 1805. In 1809-1810, he took part in the expedition led by [[Matvei Gedenschtrom]]. During this expedition, in 1810, Sannikov crossed the island of [[New Siberia]] and a year later explored Faddeyevsky Island. He also '''discovered [[Bunge Land]]'''. He suggested that there was a vast land north of the [[Kotelny Island]]. Thus he '''introduced a theory about the existence of the legendary [[Sannikov Land]]'''.[http://www.peoples.ru/science/travellers/yakov_sannikov/index.html Sannikov's biography] {{ru icon}}

The legendary [[Sannikov Land]], the [[Sannikov Strait]] strait between [[Lyakhovsky Islands|Maly Lyakhovsky]] and [[Kotelny Island|Kotelny]] islands and a street in [[Moscow]] bear Sannikov's name. |align=center|[[File:Siberia DL.png|thumb|center|120px|Location of the [[De Long Islands]], beyond which the [[Sannikov Land]] was deemed to exist.]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Gavriil Sarychev.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Gavril Sarychev|Gavriil Sarychev]]'''
(1763â1831)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, navigator, [[Admiral]], cartographer, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Alaska]]''' |In 1785-94 Sarychev took part in the expedition sponsored by [[Catherine II of Russia]] and led by [[Joseph Billings]]. Sarychev, a commander of ship ''Slava Rossii'' (Glory of Russia), '''described and mapped the coastline of the [[Sea of Okhotsk]] from [[Okhotsk]] to [[Aldoma]] and many of the [[Aleutian Islands]]''' (especially [[Unalaska]]). He also described the islands of [[Pribilof Islands|Pribylov]], [[St. Matthew Island]], [[St. Lawrence Island]], [[Diomede Islands|Gvozdev]], and [[King Island, Alaska|King Island]]. In 1802-06, Sarychev led the hydrographic expedition on the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]]. He was also in charge of hydrographic research in [[Russia]] since 1808 and led the compilation of the ''Atlas of the Northern Part of the [[Pacific Ocean]]'' in 1826.[http://www.npacific.ru/np/library/encicl/18/0031.htm Sarychev's biography] at npacific.ru {{ru icon}}

[[Sarychev Peak]] of [[Matua Island]] in the [[Kuril Islands]], as well as [[Cape Sarichef Airport|Cape Sarichef]], Sarichef Strait and [[Sarichef Island]] in [[Alaska]] were named after Gavril Sarychev. The [[Soviet]] ship ''Gavril Sarychev'' also was named after this explorer. |align=center|[[File:Unalaska church.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Russian Orthodox]] [[Church of the Holy Ascension]] in [[Unalaska]]]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:USSR Stamp 1983 SouzT7 Salyut7 SouzT5 Cosmonauts.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Svetlana Savitskaya]]'''
(born 1948)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''female [[cosmonaut]], aviator, twice the [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], politician'''

([[Svetlana Savitskaya|Savitskaya]] with her 1982 crew fellows [[Leonid Popov|Popov]] and [[Aleksandr Serebrov|Serebrov]]) |Savitskaya was '''the second woman in [[outer space|space]]''' (after [[Valentina Tereshkova]]) and the '''first woman to conduct an [[extra-vehicular activity]]'''. She achieved this during the two successful expeditions to [[Salyut 7]] [[space station]] in 1982 and 1984, making her spacewalk on July 25, 1984.[http://www.astronaut.ru/as_rusia/energia/text/savitskaya.htm?reload_coolmenus Biography of Savitskaya] at astronaut.ru {{ru icon}}

Two [[minor planet]]s â 4118 ''Sveta'' and â 4303 ''Savitskaya'' have been named after Svetlana Savitskaya. |align=center| |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Otto shmidt.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Otto Schmidt]]'''
(1891â1956)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''mathematician, astronomer, geophysicist, statesman, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1932-39 Schmidt was '''the head of [[Chief Directorate of the Northern Sea Route]]'''. In 1929-30, travelling on the [[icebreaker]] ''[[Georgy Sedov (icebreaker)|Georgy Sedov]]'', he established the first research station on the [[Franz Josef Land]], '''explored the northwestern [[Kara Sea]] and western [[Severnaya Zemlya]]''', discovering a few islands. In 1932 his expedition on the icebreaker ''[[Icebreaker Sibiryakov|Sibiryakov]]'' with [[Captain Vladimir Voronin]] '''made first non-stop voyage through the [[Northern Sea Route]]''' from [[Arkhangelsk]] to the [[Pacific Ocean]] without wintering. In 1933-34 Schmidt and Voronin led the voyage on the [[steamship]] ''[[Cheliuskin (ship)|Cheliuskin]]'', that resulted in the loss of the ship and evacuation of the crew. In 1937 Schmidt '''supervised an airborne expedition that established a [[drift-ice station]] ''[[North Pole-1]]''''', and in 1938 he was in charge of evacuating its personnel from the ice.[http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=806 Otto Schmidt at the Heroes of the Country]{{ru icon}}

An island in the [[Kara Sea]], a cape on in the [[Chukchi Sea]], [[minor planet]] [[2108 Otto Schmidt]], an icebreaker, a number of scientific institutions and streets bear Schmidt's name. |align=center|[[File:Northernsearoute.PNG|120px|center|thumb|[[Northern Sea Route]] between [[Europe]] and the [[Pacific]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Leopold von Schrenck.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Leopold von Schrenck]]'''
(1826â1894)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''zoologist, geographer, ethnographer, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]]''' |On behalf of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], Schrenck '''explored fauna of the [[Russian Far East]]''', in [[Amurland]] between 1853â54, and on [[Sakhalin]] in 1854-55, discovering a number of animals. Later he turned to the study of native peoples of Russia. He coined the term ''[[Paleo-Asiatic]] peoples'' and was a director of [[Peter the Great Museum of Anthropology and Ethnography]] in [[St Petersburg]].

A mountain ridge on the [[Sakhalin]] and a number of animals including [[Amur sturgeon]], [[Manchurian Black Water Snake]] and [[Manchurian Black Water Snake]] are named after Schrenck. |align=center|[[File:Schrenki.JPG|thumb|center|120px|[[Manchurian Black Water Snake]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Sedow georgy.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Georgiy Sedov]]'''
(1877â1914)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1902-03, Sedov took part in a [[hydrography|hydrographic]] expedition in the [[Arctic]]. In 1909, he led the expedition that '''described the mouth of the [[Kolyma]] river'''. In 1910 he '''explored the Krestovaya Bay on [[Novaya Zemlya]]'''. He suggested a [[sleigh]] expedition to the [[North Pole]] and found the independent sponsors, as the government refused in the finance. In 1912 Sedov's ship ''"Svyatoy Muchenik Foka" (Saint Martyr Foka)'' sailed north but had to stay for the winter near [[Novaya Zemlya]] because of impassable ice. ''Sv. Foka'' reached [[Franz Josef Land]], but had to stop for another winter due to lack of coal. In early 1914, Sedov, sick with [[scurvy]], with two companions set off for the [[North Pole]] with the draft dogs. Near [[Rudolf Island]] Sedov died and was buried there, at Cape Auk. On the way back, at Franz Josef Land, the ''Sv. Foka'' rescued two survivors of the [[Georgy Brusilov]] expedition, [[Valerian Albanov]] and [[Alexander Konrad]].

Two [[Headlands and bays|gulfs]] and a [[mountain|peak]] on [[Novaya Zemlya]], a [[glacier]] and a cape on [[Franz Josef Land]], an island in the [[Barents Sea]], a cape in [[Antarctica]] and a steam [[icebreaker]] ''[[Icebreaker Sedov|Sedov]]'' were named after Sedov. He and his last expedition are among the prototypes for the novel ''[[The Two Captains]]'' by [[Veniamin Kaverin]], where the fictional captain Tatarinov has Sedov-like appearance and shares his passion for [[Arctic]] exploration. |align=center|[[File:1912. Sedov Foka Arkhangelsk.jpg|120px|center|thumb|Sedov amid the crew of ''St. Foka'']][[File:Kara sea ZFJ.PNG|120px|center|thumb|[[Franz Josef Land]] in the [[Arctic]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Portrait of P. Semenov-Tien-Shansky.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Pyotr Semyonov-Tyan-Shansky]]'''
(1827â1914)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geographer, statistician, entomologist, explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |Semyonov is known for his explorations of the then largely unknown mountains of the [[Tian Shan]]. In 1856-57 he passed through the [[Altay Mountains]], visited the [[Issyk Kul]] and came to the Tian Shan. Semyonov '''was the first European to see the peak of [[Khan Tengri]]'''. He disproved [[Alexander Humboldt|Humboldt]]'s earlier claims about Tian Shan's supposed volcanic origins. The next year, he '''published the first systematic description of the [[Tian Shan]]'''. The reputation of this monograph was such that half a century later [[Nicholas II of Russia]] authorized him to add the epithet "Tian-Shansky" (that is, "of Tian Shan") to his last name. For many years Semyonov served as Chairman of the Russia's Central Committee for Statistics. It was largely due to his efforts that the first [[census]] of the [[Russian Empire]] was held in 1897. Semyonov amassed a large collection of old Dutch masters, which now belongs to the [[Hermitage Museum]] as well as insect collection of ca. 700,000 specimens. He was a member of 53 [[learned societies]] and '''headed the [[Russian Geographical Society]] for 40 years''' from 1873 until his death, using this position to encourage the exploration of inland [[Asia]], notably by [[Nikolai Przhevalsky]] and [[Pyotr Kozlov]].[http://www.biografia.ru/cgi-bin/search.pl?oaction=show&id=1186 Semyonov's biography] at biografia.ru {{ru icon}}

More than 100 plant and animal species as well as a number of geographical objects in [[Central Asia]], [[Alaska]], the [[Caucasus]] and [[Svalbard]] were named after Semyonov. |align=center|[[File:Seidenstrasse GMT Ausschintt Zentralasien.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Tian Shan]] and the ancient [[Silk Road]]]][[File:Peak of Khan Tengri at sunset.jpg|100px|thumb|center|[[Khan Tengri]] at sunset]] |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center| |'''[[Yuri Senkevich]]'''
(1937â2003)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''physician, scientist, traveler, TV anchorman'''
(photo of Senkevich on the cover of his memoirs ''A Lifelong Travel'') |Senkevich, being a [[Soviet]] military physician, participated in the 12th Soviet Antarctic expedition at [[Vostok, Antarctica|Vostok]] station in 1966-67. In 1969 Senkevich '''sailed with [[Thor Heyerdahl]] on the ''Ra'' [[papyrus]] boat, and later on the ''[[Ra II]]'' across the [[Atlantic Ocean]]''' in 1970. He also '''sailed with Heyerdahl on another [[Reed (plant)|reed]] boat ''[[Thor Heyerdahl#The Tigris|Tigris]]'' across the [[Indian Ocean]]''' in 1978. In 1973-2003, Senkevich '''was a host of the ''"Travelers' Club"'' show on the [[Soviet Television]] for the record 30 years''', making it into the [[Guinness Book of Records]]. He visited more than 200 countries as a journalist and TV anchorman.[http://www.planetguide.ru/mediacenter/avtory/stanislavpoktovskij/klubkinoputeshestvij/klub2j/ Senkevich's biography] at planetguide.ru {{ru icon}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} |align=center|[[File:RaII.InMuseum.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Ra II]] boat in the [[Thor Heyerdahl]]'s [[Kon-Tiki Museum]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Severtzov ru WP.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolai Severtzov]]'''
(1827â1885)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[naturalist]], explorer of [[Central Asia]]''' |Severtzov started as [[naturalist]] in his native [[Voronezh]] [[gubernia]]. In 1857-58, on an expedition to the [[Syr Darya]] in [[Central Asia]], he was captured by [[Khanate of Kokand|Kokand]] bandits and severely wounded. He was freed after a month by the Russian military and continued his studies. In 1865-68 he '''explored the [[Tian Shan]] and Lake [[Issyk Kul]]'''. In 1877-78 he '''explored the unknown areas of [[Pamir Mountains]]''' following a route close to the current [[Pamir Highway]] as far as Lake Yashil Kul on the Ghunt River. Severtzov wrote a major study of [[Turkestan]] zoology called ''Vertical and horizontal distribution of Turkestan wildlife'' (1873), which included the first description of a number of animals.

The Severtzov [[Argali]] (a wild sheep) has been named after Severtzov. |align=center|[[File:Argali.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Argali]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Grigory Shelikov.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Grigory Shelikhov]]'''
(1747â1795)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''seafarer, merchant, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Alaska]]''' |Shelikhov organized commercial trips of the merchant ships to the [[Kuril Islands]] and the [[Aleutian Islands]] starting from 1775. Together with Ivan Golikov, Shelikhov '''founded the precursor of [[Russian-American Company]]''' (this name appeared in 1799 after Shelikhov death). In 1783-86, he led an expedition to the shores of [[Russian America]], during which he '''founded the first permanent Russian settlements in [[North America]]'''. In 1784 Shelikhov arrived in [[Three Saints Bay]] on [[Kodiak Island]]. Having established the authority there, he founded the first permanent Russian settlement in [[Alaska]]. In 1790, Shelikhov, back in Russia, hired [[Alexander Andreyevich Baranov|Aleksandr Baranov]] to manage his fur enterprise in Russian America.[http://taina.aib.ru/biography/grigorij-shelihov.htm Shelikhov's biography] {{ru icon}}

[[Shelikhov Bay]] in the [[Sea of Okhotsk]], a [[Shelikhov Strait|strait]] between [[Alaska]] and [[Kodiak Island]], and a town [[Shelekhov]] in [[Irkutsk Oblast]] in [[Russia]] bear Shelikhov's name. |align=center|[[File:Shelikhov settlement.jpg|120px|thumb|center|The settlement of Shelikhov on [[Kodiak Island|Kodiak]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center| |'''[[Pyotr Shirshov]]'''
(1905â1953)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[oceanographer]], [[Hydrobiology|hydrobiologist]], statesman, academician, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Shirshov participated in numerous Arctic expeditions, including the famous ones on icebreakers [[Icebreaker Sibiryakov|''Sibiryakov'']] (1932) and [[Chelyuskin steamship|''Chelyuskin'']] (1934). He '''was among the crew of the [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|drifting ice station ''North Pole-1'']]''' in 1937-38. In 1942-48, Shirshov was a Maritime Minister of the Soviet Union. In 1946-53, he became '''the founder and the first director of the [[Shirshov Institute of Oceanology|Institute of Oceanology of the Soviet Academy of Sciences]]'''. He wrote numerous works about [[plankton]] in the polar regions and '''proved that there is life in high latitudes of the [[Arctic Ocean]]'''.

A bay and a lake in the [[Franz Josef Land]], an underwater range in the [[Bering Sea]], a street in [[Dnepropetrovsk]] (the native city of Shirshov), two scientific vessels and [[Shirshov Institute of Oceanology]] bear Shirshov's name. |align=center|[[File:Arctic Ocean - en.png|120px|center|thumb|[[Arctic Ocean]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Gleb Shishmaryov]]'''
(1781â1835)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, circumnavigator, explorer of the [[Alaska]]''' |In 1815-18 Shishmaryov accompanied [[Otto von Kotzebue]] on his circumnavigation, including the visit to [[Alaska]]. During this voyage a new-discovered inlet on Chukotka was named after Shishmaryov. In 1820 he returned to Alaska in command of ship ''Blagonamierennie'', accompanied by Lt. [[Ensign Mikhail Vasiliev|Mikhail Vasiliev]] on ship ''Otkrietie''. Shishmaref and Vasiliev entered the [[Chukchi Sea]] and '''explored the coast of Alaska from [[Kotzebue Sound]] to [[Icy Cape, Alaska|Icy Cape]] and later from [[Norton Sound]] to Cape Newenham'''. [[St. Lawrence Island]] was mapped on the return way.

The town of [[Shishmaref, Alaska]], and the [[Shishmaref Inlet]] in [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]] bear Shishmaryov's name. |align=center|[[File:Map of Alaska highlighting Savonga.png|120px|thumb|center|Location of [[St. Lawrence Island]] near [[Alaska]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Shkot n y.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolay Shkot]]'''
(1829â1870)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]]''' |After being wounded in the [[Siege of Sevastopol (1854â1855)|Siege of Sevastopol]] during the [[Crimean War]], Shkot served on the [[Far East]]. In 1956-63 he '''explored [[Sakhalin]] (especially the [[Moneron Island]]) and the coast of [[Primorsky Krai]]''' in the area of [[Peter the Great Gulf]] and [[Nakhodka Bay]], making a number of discoveries. He '''founded [[hydrograph]]ic post on a place of modern [[Nakhodka]]''', and was '''one of the founders of [[Vladivostok]]''' in 1860.[http://www.pgpb.ru/cd/primor/first/shkot.htm Shkot's biography] {{ru icon}}

[[Shkot Island]] in the [[Sea of Japan]], [[Shkotovo]] village and [[Shkotovka River]] in [[Primorsky Krai]], and a cape in [[Olga Bay]] are named after Shkot. |align=center|[[File:Rusia - Vladivostok - Ussuriisk - Najodka.PNG|thumb|center|120px|[[Vladivostok]] and [[Nakhodka]] on the [[Russian Far East]]]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Szokalski.gif|100px]] |'''[[Yuly Shokalsky]]'''
(1856â1940)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
'''[[Imperial Russian Navy]] officer, oceanographer, meteorologist, cartographer, geographer, explorer of [[European Russia]]''' |In 1897-1901 Shokalsky '''researched [[Lake Ladoga]]'''. Since 1907 he supervised all [[oceanographic]] works in Russia. He coined the term ''[[World Ocean]]''. In 1919 he headed the commission that set up [[Time in Russia|time zones in Russia]]. In 1918-31 he was '''the head of [[Russian Geographical Society]]''' and contributed a lot to the [[Arctic]] exploration on this post.[http://geo.1september.ru/article.php?ID=200302907 Biography of Shokalsky] {{ru icon}}

[[Shokalsky Strait]] in the [[Severnaya Zemlya]], [[Shokalskogo Island|Shokalsky Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]], two islands in the [[Kara Strait]], a lake on [[Kanin Peninsula]], a glacier in [[Novaya Zemlya]] and an [[ocean current]] around [[Svalbard]] are named after Shokalsky. |align=center|[[File:Russian Empire Map 1912.jpg|120px|thumb|center|A 1912 map of the [[Russian Empire]] by Shokalsky]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Martin Shpanberg]]'''
(?â1761)
{{flag|Denmark}}
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, navigator, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Japan]]''' |Shpanberg was born in [[Denmark]] and like [[Vitus Bering]] (another [[Denmark|Danish]]) he joined the [[Russian Imperial Navy|Russian Navy]]. He took part in the Russian exploration efforts in the Northern [[Pacific]] during the first [[Kamchatka]] expedition of [[Vitus Bering]] (1725â30). During the [[Second Kamchatka Expedition]], also organised by Bering, Shpanberg was made a leader of expedition to find a sea route to Japan. In 1738-39 '''he explored and mapped most of [[Kuril islands]] and reached [[Japan]]''', however he failed to establish the relations with Japanese and soon returned back.[http://www.kamchatsky-krai.ru/lichnosti/biografii/shpanberg.htm Shpanberg's biography] at kamchatsky-krai.ru {{ru icon}} |align=center|[[File:Sea of Okhotsk map.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Japan]], [[Kuril islands]] and [[Kamchatka]] in the [[North Pacific]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Alexander Sibiriakoff.jpg|110px]] |'''[[Alexander Sibiryakov]]'''
(1849â1933)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|France}}

'''[[gold mine]] owner, explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Arctic]], sponsor of many expeditions''' |A rich [[gold mine]] owner from an ancient family of [[Siberian]] merchants, Sibiryakov '''financed the polar expeditions of [[Adolf Erik NordenskiÃ¶ld]] and A.V.Grigoriev'''. He also sponsored the publication of works on Siberia's history. In 1880, he made an attempt to enter the [[Yenisei]] [[estuary]] through the [[Kara Sea]] on a [[schooner]]. In 1884, Sibiryakov reached the [[Pechora River|Pechora]] estuary on the [[Steamboat|steamer]] "NordenskiÃ¶ld" and proceeded up the [[river]]. He also '''crossed the [[Urals]] using [[reindeer]]s''' and reached [[Tobolsk]] by the [[Tobol River]]. Sibiryakov contributed significantly to Siberia's economic development.Yurii Semenov. ''Siberia: Its Conquest and Development.'' (Translated from the German by J.R. Foster). Helicon Press, Baltimore, 1963.

[[Sibiryakow Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]] near the mouth of the [[Yenisey]], Sibiryakov Island in the [[Sea of Japan]], Russian [[icebreaker]]s ''[[icebreaker Sibiryakov|Alexander Sibiryakov]]'' (the first to pass the [[Northern Sea Route]] in one navigation) and ''Sibiryakov'' have been named after Alexander Sibiryakov. |align=center|[[File:Kara seaSB.PNG|thumb|center|120px|[[Sibiryakov Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:Anatoly Solovyev portraitlike.jpeg|100px]] |'''[[Anatoly Solovyev]]'''
(born 1948)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''[[cosmonaut]], aviator, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]''' |Solovyev '''holds the [[List of cumulative spacewalk records|world record]] on the number of [[extra-vehicular activity|spacewalks]] (16), and accumulated time spent spacewalking (over 82 hours)''', which he performed during his five spaceflights. In 1988 he traveled on ''[[Soyuz TM-5]]'' to ''[[Mir]]'' [[space station]] and back on ''[[Soyuz TM-4]]''. In 1990 he again traveled to ''Mir'' and back on ''[[Soyuz TM-9]]'', and in 1990 made the similar journey on ''[[Soyuz TM-15]]''. In 1995 he got to ''Mir'' on [[Space Shuttle]] ''[[STS-71]]'' and went back on ''[[Soyuz TM-21]]'', and in 1997-98 again traveled to ''Mir'' and back on ''[[Soyuz TM-26]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/astros/solovyov.htm |title=Solovyev web page|accessdate=January 12, 2009|last=Wade|first=Mark|year=2008|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica}}[http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/solovyev.html NASA Biography of Anatoly Solovyev]

 |align=center|[[File:SolovyevEVA.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Anatoly Solovyev]] performing an [[extra-vehicular activity|EVA]]]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" | |'''[[Mikhail Somov]]'''
(1908â1973)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, [[oceanologist]], [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] explorer''' |Mikhail Somov graduated from the Moscow Hydrometeorological Institute in 1937. In 1939, he was appointed senior researcher at the [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]]. In 1950-51, Mikhail Somov '''headed a second [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|Soviet drifting ice station]] ''North Pole-2''. '''In 1955-57, he '''became a leader of the [[1st Soviet Antarctic Expedition]]''' on [[icebreaker]]s ''[[Ob River|Ob]]'' and ''[[Lena River|Lena]]''. The expedition '''established the first Soviet Antarctic station, [[Mirny Station|Mirny]]''', performed some observations and reconnaissance, and researched oceanography of the [[Indian ocean]]. Somov was also the first Soviet delegate to the international Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research.[http://www.aari.nw.ru/projects/Antarctic/persons/somov/somov_ru.html Somov's biography] at aari.nw.ru {{ru icon}}

A [[glacier]] in [[East Antarctica]] ([[Queen Maud Land]]), a scientific [[icebreaker]] and a [[minor planet]] [[3334 Somov]] bear Somov's name. |align=center|[[File:LakeVostok-Location.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Vostok Station]] location in [[Antarctica]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Mikhail Stadukhin]]'''
(?â1666)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberia]]n [[cossack]] leader, explorer of the north-eastern [[Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1633 Stadukhin came to the [[Lena River]] and then to [[Indigirka]]. With [[Semyon Dezhnyov]] he led a group to the [[Arctic]] coast and then to the east. They '''discovered [[Kolyma River]] and founded [[Srednekolymsk]]''' there in 1643. In 1649 he followed by [[Arctic Ocean]] the traces of Dezhnyov's and [[Fedot Alekseyev Popov|Fedot Alekseyev]]'s expedition to the east, which started earlier in 1648 (and reached the [[Bering Strait]]). He learned from the captive natives that two of Dezhnyov's [[koch (boat)|koches]] had been wrecked and the crews killed by the natives. Facing shortages in provision, Stadukhin returned to [[Srednekolymsk]]. Later he found the connection of [[Kolyma]] watershed to that of [[Anadyr River|Anadyr]] and thus '''explored the land way to [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]]'''. On [[Anadyr River|Anadyr]] he found Dezhnyov in 1650. In 1651 he set off south and '''discovered the [[Penzhin Bay]] of northern [[Okhotsk Sea]]'''. He also may have explored the western shores of [[Kamchatka]]. |align=center|[[File:Kolymarivermap.png|120px|center|thumb|Location of [[Kolyma River]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" | |'''[[Georg Wilhelm Steller]]'''
(1709â1746)
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''botanist, zoologist, physician, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Alaska]]''' |In 1734 Steller, a naturalist, moved from [[Bavaria]] to Russia to work at the [[Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences]]. Steller traveled trough Siberia, researching its nature, and in 1740 reached [[Okhotsk]] and [[Kamchatka]]. He '''joined [[Vitus Bering]] on the voyage to [[North America]]'''. The expedition landed in [[Alaska]] at [[Kayak Island]] in 1741, staying only long enough to take on fresh water. During this time Steller '''became the first European naturalist to describe a number of North American plants and animals''', including the [[Steller's Jay]]. On the return journey the expedition was shipwrecked on [[Bering Island]]. Here Bering died, and almost half of the crew perished from [[scurvy]]. Despite the hardships, Steller studied the flora and fauna of the island in great detail. He '''collected the only existing detailed observations of the now extinct [[Steller sea cow]]''', a large [[sirenian]] mammal. In the spring the crew constructed a new vessel and returned to [[Kamchatka]], where Steller continued his research. He died on the journey to St. Petersburg, but his journals were published by [[Peter Simon Pallas]] and were later used by other explorers, including [[Captain Cook]].[http://beringisland.ru/history/peoples/steller.shtm Steller's biography] at beringisland.ru {{ru icon}} {{WebCite|url=http://www.webcitation.org/5nE2ZiPV0|date =2010-02-01}}

[[Steller's Jay]], [[Steller's Sea Lion|Steller's (or Northern) Sea Lion]], [[Steller's Sea Cow]], [[Steller's Eider]], the marine [[cryptid]] [[Steller's Sea Ape]] (never sighted by anyone but Steller), [[Steller's Sea Eagle]] and other animals have been named after Steller. |align=center|[[File:Stellers jay - natures pics.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Stellers Jay]]]][[File:Extanstellersseacowea.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Extinct [[Steller's Sea Cow]] drawn by Steller]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" | |'''[[Anikey Stroganov]]'''
(1488â1570)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]][[Grand Duchy of Moscow]]
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''rich merchant and landowner, colonizer of [[Perm Krai]] and [[Urals]]''' |Anikey Stroganov '''was a progenitor of the famous [[Stroganovs]] family''' of highly successful Russian [[merchant]]s, [[industrialist]]s, [[landowner]]s, and [[statesmen]]. He was a founder of numerous [[saltern]]s in [[Solvychegodsk]], [[Kola Peninsula]] and [[Perm]]. He '''colonized the [[Drainage basin|basin]] of the [[Kama River|Kama]] and [[Chusovaya River]]s'''. In the beginning of the reign of [[Tsar]] [[Ivan IV]] he received the right to control the trade with [[England|English]] merchants, traveling from [[Arkhangelsk]] to [[Moscow]]. Stroganov '''established trade routes with [[Siberia]]n tribes'''. Tsar Ivan granted large estates near the [[Urals]] as well as tax privileges to Stroganovs, and they organized large scale migration to their new lands. They developed [[farming]], [[hunting]], saltworks, [[fishing]], and ore [[mining]]. They built new towns and [[fortress]]es and annexed new lands in the [[Urals]] and [[Siberia]] in favor of [[Russia]]. |align=center|[[File:W W Chusovaya Kama crossing.png|thumb|center|120px|Crossing of the rivers [[Chusovaya River|Chusovaya]] (tributary) and [[Kama]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Semyon Stroganov]]'''
(?â1586)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]][[Grand Duchy of Moscow]]
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''rich merchant and landowner, coloniser of the [[Urals]] and [[Siberia]]''' |Semyon was the younger son of [[Anikey Stroganov]]. After the death of his father in 1570, Semyon quarreled with his brothers. Initially he was deprived of family wealth, however after the deaths of his brothers he received an appropriate part. He is most famous for the fact that together with his nephews he '''sponsored and prepared [[Yermak]]'s expedition to conquer [[Siberia Khanate]]''' in 1581-85. After the success of Yermak and his followers, the [[Tsar]] granted new [[Siberian]] lands to the Stroganovs. |align=center|[[File:Surikov Pokoreniye Sibiri Yermakom.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Yermak]]'s [[Russian conquest of Siberia|Conquest of Siberia]] was sponsored by the [[Stroganovs]]]] |} ===T=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Tatishchev.png|110px]] |'''[[Vasily Tatishchev]]'''
(1686â1750)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''statesman, geographer, [[ethnographer]], historian, explorer of [[European Russia]] and the [[Urals]]''' |In the service of [[Peter I of Russia|Peter the Great]] Tatishchev was sent to the [[Urals]] and there '''supervised the works on general geographical description of Russia'''. Subsequently new Empress Anna entrusted him with a lucrative office of the management of [[Ural (region)|Ural]] factories. At that post he '''founded the cities of [[Perm]] and [[Yekaterinburg]]''', which have since grown into the veritable capitals of Ural. Tatischev finished his career as a governor of [[Astrakhan]] (1741â44) and dedicated himself to Russian geography and [[historiography]]. He discovered and published several documents of great interest, e.g., [[Russkaya Pravda]] and [[Sudebnik]] of 1550. His [[Masterpiece|magnum opus]] was the first sketch of Russian history, entitled ''Russian History Dating Back to the Most Ancient Times''. He also compiled the first encyclopedic [[dictionary]] of the [[Russian language]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_t/tatishev_vn.php|title={{lang|ru|Ð¢Ð°ÑÐ¸ÑÐµÐ² ÐÐ°ÑÐ¸Ð»Ð¸Ð¹ ÐÐ¸ÐºÐ¸ÑÐ¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Vasily Nikitich Tatishchev|publisher=hrono.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-19}}

A settlement and a [[Tatishchevsky District|district]] was named in his honour in [[Saratov Oblast]]. |align=center|[[File:Monument of Tatishchev in Perm (close-up).jpg|thumb|center|120px|Monument to Tatischev in [[Perm]]]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center| |'''[[Mikhail Tebenkov]]'''
(1802â1872)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Vice Admiral]], hydrographer, explorer of [[Alaska]]''' |Tebenkov surveyed [[Norton Sound]] on behalf of the Russian Imperial Hydrographic Service in 1831 and was the first European to sight the bay that now bears his name. In 1845-50 he was the director of the [[Russian American Company]] and '''the governor of [[Russian America]]'''. Tebenkov '''created a detailed atlas of the western shores of [[Alaska]]''', published in 1852.{{cite web|url=http://explorenorth.com/library/history/geodic-ak-1902-T.html|publisher=ExplorationNorth|title=The Naming of Alaska|accessdate=2011-04-19}}

A bay, a glacier, a mount and a point on [[Alaska]] have been named after Tebenkov. |align=center|[[File:Tebenkov-sitka9.png|120px|thumb|center|Section of Tebenkov's [[Sitka]] Island chart]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:Tereshkova Heureka2.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Valentina Tereshkova]]'''
(born 1937)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''female [[cosmonaut]], [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Major General]], politician and public figure''' |Aboard [[Vostok 6]] on 16 June 1963 Tereshkova became '''the first woman as well as the first civilian to travel into space'''. On this mission, lasting almost three days in space, she performed various tests on herself to collect data on the female body's reaction to spaceflight. She also maintained a flight log and took photographs of the [[horizon]], which were later used to identify [[aerosol]] layers within the [[atmosphere]].{{cite web|url=http://www.adm.yar.ru/english/section.aspx?section_id=74|title=Biography of Tereshkova|accessdate=2011-04-19|publisher=Administration of the Yaroslavl Region}}

[[Tereshkova (crater)|Tereshkova crater]] on the far side of the [[Moon]] and [[minor planet]] 1671 Chaika (her call sign in the flight, meaning ''[[seagull]]''), as well as many streets and other places have been named after Valentina Tereshkova. |align=center|[[File:Soviet Union-1963-stamp-Valentina Vladimirovna Tereshkova.jpg|thumb|center|120px|A Soviet postage stamp dedicated to [[Vostok 6]] and Tereshkova]] |- style="background:#fff8e7;" |align=center|[[File:Tillo Alexej Andreevitch.jpg|130px]] |'''[[Aleksey Tillo]]'''
(1839â1900)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''geographer, cartographer, land surveyor, [[lieutenant general]] of the [[Russian Imperial Army]], explorer of [[European Russia]]''' |Tillo '''created the first correct [[Cartographic relief depiction|hypsometric]] map of [[European Russia]]''', published in 1889. He is known to have coined the term ''[[Central Russian Upland]]''. Also, he '''measured the length of the main [[Russian rivers]]''' and '''conducted work on level difference of [[Caspian Sea]] and [[Sea of Aral]]'''. He authored a number of works on [[geomagnetism]] and [[meteorology]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vehi.net/brokgauz/index.html|language=Russian|title={{lang|ru|Ð¢Ð¸Ð»Ð»Ð¾ ÐÐ»ÐµÐºÑÐµÐ¹ ÐÐ½Ð´ÑÐµÐµÐ²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Aleksey Andreyevich Tillo|publisher=Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary|accessdate=2011-04-19}}

The [[Tillo Islands]] in the [[Kara Sea]] and an island near [[Wilczek Land]] in [[Franz Josef Land]], were named after Tillo. |align=center|[[File:Lagekarte Mittelrussische Platte.png|thumb|center|120px|Location of [[Central Russian Upland]] in [[Europe]]]] |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" |align=center|[[File:RU072 10.jpg|120px]] |'''[[Gherman Titov]]'''
(1935â2000)
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}

'''[[cosmonaut]], [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]''' |Aboard [[Vostok 2]] on August 6, 1961, Titov became the fourth man in space after [[Yury Gagarin]], [[Alan Shepard]] and [[Gus Grissom]], and '''the second man to orbit the Earth, the first to do it multiple times''' (a total of 17), '''the first to spent more than a day in space''', and '''the first person to drive a spaceship manually'''. He also was '''the first person to sleep in space''' and to suffer from [[space sickness]]. He '''made the first manual photographs from orbit''', thus setting a record for modern [[space photography]]. A month short of 26 years old at launch, until this day he remains '''the youngest person to fly in space'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=638|publisher=ÐÐµÑÐ¾Ð¸ Ð¡ÑÑÐ°Ð½Ñ|title={{lang|ru|Ð¢Ð¸ÑÐ¾Ð² ÐÐµÑÐ¼Ð°Ð½ Ð¡ÑÐµÐ¿Ð°Ð½Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Gherman Stepanovich Titov|accessdate=2011-04-19|language=Russian}}

A [[Titov (crater)|crater]] on the [[Far side (Moon)|far side of the Moon]] and an island in [[Halong Bay]] are named after Titov. |align=center|[[File:K.Kut.Monument to Titov G. S.jpg|thumb|center|120px|A monument on the place of Titov's landing near [[Saratov]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Eduard Toll.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Eduard Toll]]'''
(1858â1902)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''zoologist, paleontologist, geologist, [[Siberia]] and [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1885â86, Baron Toll took part in an expedition of [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] to the [[New Siberian Islands]] led by [[Alexander Bunge]]. In 1893 Toll '''led a major academic expedition to [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]]''' and explored the region between lower [[Lena River|Lena]] and [[Khatanga River|Khatanga]], the basins of [[Yana River|Yana]], [[Indigirka]], and [[Kolyma River|Kolyma]], the [[plateau]] between the [[Anabar River|Anabar]] and [[Popigay River]]s, and the [[Vasily Pronchischev]] mountain ridge (named by Toll) between [[Olenek River|Olenek]] and Anabar. In 1899, Toll took part in a voyage of the [[icebreaker Yermak]] to [[Spitsbergen]], led by [[Stepan Makarov]]. In 1900â02, Toll '''led an expedition on ship ''[[Zarya (polar ship)|Zarya]]'' to find the legendary [[Sannikov Land]]'''. Due to severe ice conditions the expedition was forced to spend two winters in the [[Arctic]]. Toll traveled to [[Bennett Island]] by sledge and kayak with three companions, and they were lost. In 1903 the search led by [[Mikhail Brusnev]] and [[Aleksandr Kolchak]] brought out only the diaries and the collections of Toll's party.

A bay at the north-west of [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taymyr]], Tollievaya River, a cape on [[Kolosovykh Islands|Tsirkul Island]], mountains in [[Novaya Zemlya]], the northern cape at [[Stolbovoy Island]], the strait and a plateau at [[Kotelny Island]], the central ice cap of [[Bennett Island]], and many specimens of fauna and flora are named after Baron Eduard Von Toll. |align=center|[[File:Carte-Sakha.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]]]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" | |'''[[Yevgeny Tolstikov]]'''
(1913â1987)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, [[Hero of the Soviet Union]], [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] explorer''' |Tolstikov was involved in defending the [[Northern Sea Route]] during [[World War II]]. In 1954 he was '''the head of the [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|drifting ice station]] North Pole-3 in the [[Arctic Ocean]]'''. In 1957-59 he became '''the leader of the [[3rd Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] and the founder of [[Sovetskaya (Antarctic Research Station)|Sovetskaya]] and [[Pole of inaccessibility (Antarctic research station)|Pole of inaccessibility]] research stations'''. This expedition '''discovered [[Gamburtsev Mountain Range]]''' and other features of [[Antarctica]] relief under the ice. He was '''the chief editor of the general atlas of [[Antarctic]]'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=4737|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-19|publisher=ÐÐµÑÐ¾Ð¸ Ð¡ÑÑÐ°Ð½Ñ|title={{lang|ru|Ð¢Ð¾Ð»ÑÑÐ¸ÐºÐ¾Ð² ÐÐ²Ð³ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¹ ÐÐ²Ð°Ð½Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Yevgeny Ivanovich Tolstikov}}

A [[minor planet]] [[3357 Tolstikov]] is named after Tolstikov. |align=center|[[File:Southern Pol of Inaccessibility Henry Cookson team n2i.JPG|120px|center|thumb|The [[Pole of inaccessibility (Antarctic research station)|Pole of inaccessibility]] [[Antarctic]] station]] |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Graf f tolstoy.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Fyodor Ivanovich Tolstoy]]'''
(1782â1846)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''nobleman, adventurer, traveler to [[Alaska]] and around the world''' |A count from the well-known [[Tolstoy]] family, Fyodor Tolstoy was famous for his unusual temper, gambling and passion for duels. In 1803 Tolstoy '''took part in the first Russian circumnavigation of the world''' on [[sloop-of-war|sloop]] ''Nadezhda'' , captained by [[Ivan Krusenstern]]. However, multiple quarrels with other members of the team and very bad behaviour, including the successful teaching a pet [[orangutan]] of how to cover the captain's longbook in ink, caused Tolstoy to be abandoned on a stop in [[Kamchatka]] with aforementioned ape, whose later fate is unknown. On a different ship Tolstoy managed to get into [[Sitka, Alaska]], where he spent several months among Alaskan natives of the Tlinkit tribe and acquired multiple [[tattoo]]s. Finally he returned to [[St Petersburg]] via Kamchatka and [[Siberia]]. His voyage to [[North America]] earned him nickname ''the American'' and a legendary celebrity due to the tales and gossip of his adventures.{{cite web|url=http://magazines.russ.ru/slovo/2004/43/vv4.html|publisher=Ð ÑÑÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ Ð¶ÑÑÐ½Ð°Ð»|title={{lang|ru|Ð¤.Ð. Ð¢ÐÐÐ¡Ð¢ÐÐ - ÐÐÐÐ ÐÐÐÐÐÐ¦}}|trans_title=F.I. Tolstoy â American|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-19}}

Tolstoy served as a prototype for a number of characters in the [[Russian literature]], including the duellist Zaretsky in [[Eugene Onegin]] of [[Aleksandr Pushkin]]. |align=center|[[File:Pongo pygmaeus (orangutang).jpg|100px|thumb|center|An [[orangutan]]]] |- style="background:#ffdfff;" | |'''[[Alexey Tryoshnikov]]'''
(1914â1991)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, [[oceanologist]], [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] explorer''' |Tryoshnikov was involved in defending the [[Northern Sea Route]] during [[World War II]] and participated in the 1948 Soviet expedition to the [[North Pole]]. In 1954-55, he was '''the leader of the [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|drifting ice station]] North Pole-3 in the [[Arctic Ocean]]'''. In 1956-58 he was '''a leader of the [[2nd Soviet Antarctic Expedition|2nd]] and in 1967-69 he led the [[13th Soviet Antarctic Expedition]]'''. During the latter expedition [[Bellingshausen Station]] was founded. Tryoshnikov took part in the creation of the general atlas of [[Antarctic]] and then he was the main editor of the atlas of [[Arctic]]. He also was '''the president of the [[Russian Geographical Society|Geographical Society of the USSR]]''' since 1977 and '''the director of the [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]]''' of the [[Soviet Union]] in 1960-81.{{cite web|url=http://www.aari.nw.ru/projects/Antarctic/persons/treshnikov/treshnikov_ru.html|work=aari.nw.ru|language=Russian|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ»ÐµÐºÑÐµÐ¹ Ð¤ÐµÐ´Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ Ð¢ÑÐµÑÐ½Ð¸ÐºÐ¾Ð² (1914-1991)}}|trans_title=Alexey Fedorovich Tryoshnikov|accessdate=2011-04-19}}

A [[minor planet]] [[3339 Treshnikov]] and a scientific vessel named after Tryoshnikov. |align=center|[[File:Antarctica 6400px from Blue Marble.jpg|120px|center|thumb|[[Antarctica]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Avgust Tsivolko]]'''
(1810â1839)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, hydrographer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1832-34 Tsivolko participated in the [[Arctic]] expeditions led by [[Pyotr Pakhtusov]]. They '''made the first reliable maps of Novaya Zemlya's southern shores'''. It was Tsivolko who first '''mapped the [[Matochkin Strait]] between two main islands of [[Novaya Zemlya]]'''. In 1837 he commanded a [[schooner]] ''Krotov'' during the [[Karl Ernst von Baer|Karl Baer]]'s expedition to Novaya Zemlya. In 1838 he was sent to map the northern and northeastern shores of Novaya Zemlya, but died from scurvy before this work was completed.{{cite web|url=http://www.rulex.ru/01230064.htm|title={{lang|ru|Ð¦Ð¸Ð²Ð¾Ð»ÑÐºÐ° ÐÐ²Ð³ÑÑÑ ÐÐ°ÑÐ»Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Avgust Karlovich Tsivolko|language=Russian|publisher=Rulex|accessdate=2011-04-19}}

A gulf in the [[Kara Sea]] and a group of islands in the [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]] are named after Tsivolko. |align=center|[[File:Matochkin Strait.svg|thumb|100px|center|[[Matochkin Strait]] in [[Novaya Zemlya]]]] |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:-Ð¦ÑÐ±Ð¸ÐºÐ¾Ð² ÐÐ¾Ð¼Ð±Ð¾Ð¶Ð°Ð±.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Gombojab Tsybikov]]'''
(1873â1930)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''anthropologist, ethnographer, statesmen, explorer of [[Tibet]]''' |A native [[Buryats|Buryat]], Tsybikov studied in [[Tomsk University|Tomsk]] and [[St Petersburg University|St Petersburg]] Universities. In 1899-1902 he traveled to [[Tibet]] in a group of [[Buryats|Buryat]] and [[Kalmyk people|Kalmyk]] [[Bhuddist]] pilgrims. He became '''the first [[photographer]] of [[Tibet]]''', taking pictures in secret. These pictures were widely celebrated throughout the world, printed also by the ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' in the [[U. S.]] In 1904 Tsybikov served as a translator on Russian talks with [[Thubten Gyatso, 13th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] in [[Ulan Bator|Urga]], [[Mongolia]], presenting Dalai Lama with an edition of his pictures. Later Tsybikov published his travelogue with much valuable translations from [[Tibetan language|Tibetan]] included.{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xku_Ik6E96MC&pg=PA1199&dq=tsybikov&hl=en&sig=ACfU3U3-mrLVzumJRGB6PweK4P1ykdgY9Q#PPA1199|author=Jennifer Speake|publisher=Fitzroy Dearborn|title=Literature of Travel and Exploration: An Encyclopedia|isbn=978-1-57958-440-5|pages=1199â1201|year=2003}}

A number of streets in [[Republic of Buryatia|Buryatian]] settlements and a museum are named after Tsybikov. |align=center|[[File:Potala-from-behind 07-2005.jpg|120px|thumb|center|[[Potala Palace]] in [[Lhasa]], [[Tibet]]]] |} ===U=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Unkovskiy.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Ivan Unkovsky]]'''
(1822â1886)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], circumnavigator, explorer of [[North Pacific]] and [[Japan]]''' |Unkovsky '''led a scientific expedition on the frigate ''Pallada'',''' together with Admiral [[Yevfimy Putyatin]], through the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], [[Indian Ocean|Indian]] and [[Pacific Ocean]]s to [[Japan]] in 1852-55. This expedition '''contributed many important discoveries in [[oceanography]]'''. Described in the book of famous writer [[Ivan Goncharov]], who also sailed on ''Pallada'', it was a dangerous voyage since it coincided in time with the [[Crimean War]] between Russia and the [[France|Franco]]-[[United Kingdom|British]] alliance. One of the results achieved was the [[Treaty of Shimoda]] with Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.pgpb.ru/cd/primor/first/ynk.htm|work=pgpb.ru|title={{lang|ru|Ð£Ð½ÐºÐ¾Ð²ÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ ÐÐ²Ð°Ð½ Ð¡ÐµÐ¼ÐµÐ½Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Ivan Semenovich Unkovsky|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-06}}

An island in the [[NordenskiÃ¶ld Archipelago]], a bay and a shallow in the [[Sea of Japan]] have been named after Unkovsky. |align=center|[[File:FrigatePallada.jpg|120px|thumb|center|The frigate ''[[Athena|Pallada]]'']] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Urvantsev.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolay Urvantsev]]'''
(1893â1985)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[geologist]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Urvantsev '''was among the discoverers of a [[coal]] basin and a [[copper]]-[[nickel]] ore region in [[Norilsk]]''' in 1919-22 and was among the founders of Norilsk town. In 1922 he found evidence of the mysteriously disappeared [[Roald Amundsen|Amundsen]]'s 1918 Arctic expedition crew members [[Peter Tessem and Paul Knutsen]] on the [[Kara Sea]] shore. In 1930-32 Urvantsev and [[Georgy Ushakov]] '''explored and completely mapped the [[Severnaya Zemlya]] and established that it was an archipelago''', discovering a number or islands and obliterating enormous "white spaces" on the [[Arctic]] map. Urvantsev also '''explored [[Taymyr Peninsula|Taimyr]] and [[Central Siberian Plateau]]'''. In 1933-34 aboard the [[Steamer Pravda|''Pravda'']] Urvantsev led the first [[Arctic]] [[oil exploration]] expedition to [[Nordvik (Laptev Sea)]]. |align=center|[[File:Severnaya Zemlya.svg|thumb|center|120px|[[Severnaya Zemlya]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Georgy Ushakov.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Georgy Ushakov]]'''
(1901â1963)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''geographer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1926 Ushakov '''founded the first [[Soviet]] settlement on the [[Wrangel Island]]'''. In 1930-32 Ushakov and [[Nikolay Urvantsev]] '''explored and completely mapped the [[Severnaya Zemlya]] and established that it was an archipelago'''. Severnaya Zemlya was a last archipelago on Earth to be explored. In 1935-36 Ushakov led the first Soviet high-latitude expedition on an icebreaker [[Icebreaker Sadko|''Sadko'']], '''examined the last unexplored areas in the northern [[Kara Sea]] and discovered [[Ushakov Island]], the last unknown island in the [[Russian Arctic]]''' outside any archipelago. In 1937 ''Sadko'' was ice-trapped and wintered in the [[Laptev Sea]]. Ushakov died in [[Moscow]], but was buried in Severnaya Zemlya.{{cite web|url=http://www.skypole.ru/ushakov/biogr_e.htm|work=skypole.ru|title=G.A.Ushakov's biography|accessdate=2011-04-06}}

Mountains in the [[Antarctica]], a spit, a cape and a settlement on [[Wrangel Island]], a river in [[Severnaya Zemlya]], and [[Ushakov Island]] bear Ushakov's name. |align=center|[[File:Kara seaUV.PNG|thumb|center|120px|Location of [[Ushakov Island]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Tatyana Ustinova]]'''
(1913â2009)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}
{{flag|Canada}}

'''[[geologist]], explorer of [[Kamchatka]]''' |In 1940 Ustinova came to [[Kronotsky Nature Reserve]] in [[Kamchatka]]. In 1941, with the help of the local guide Anysyfor Krupenin, she '''discovered the [[Valley of Geysers]]''', the second largest concentration of [[geysers]] in the world. She researched the geysers until 1946 and gave the names to the most notable of them. Before she died, in a testament she wished that her ashes were buried in the Valley of Geysers.{{cite web|url=http://www.kronoki.ru/territory/reserve/history/faces/86|publisher={{lang|ru|Ð¤ÐÐ£ ÐÑÐ¾Ð½Ð¾ÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ Ð·Ð°Ð¿Ð¾Ð²ÐµÐ´Ð½Ð¸Ðº}}|title={{lang|ru|Ð¢Ð°ÑÑÑÐ½Ð° Ð£ÑÑÐ¸Ð½Ð¾Ð²Ð°}}|trans_title=Tatyana Ustinove|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-06}} |align=center|[[File:Valley of the Geysers.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Valley of Geysers]] in [[Kamchatka]]]] |} ===V=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | |'''[[Merkury Vagin]]'''
(?â1712)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Siberian Cossack]], seafarer, merchant, Arctic explorer''' |In 1712, Vagin and his companion [[Yakov Permyakov]] crossed the [[Yana Bay]] from the mouth of the [[Yana River|Yana]] over the ice and '''explored [[Bolshoy Lyakhovsky]] island, the southernmost of the [[New Siberian Islands]]''' (the island was sited two years earlier by Permyakov). From Bolshoy Lyakhovsky they '''spotted [[Maly Lyakhovsky]]''' island. Thus they initiated the exploration of the large New Siberian archipelago. On the way back Permyakov and Vagin were murdered by mutineering expedition members.{{cite web|url=http://www.biografija.ru/show_bio.aspx?id=14908|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ°Ð³Ð¸Ð½ ÐÐµÑÐºÑÑÐ¸Ð¹}}|trans_title=Merkury Vagin|publisher=biografija.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-06}}

Merkuriya Island in the Arctic was named after Merkury Vagin. |[[File:NewSiberianIslands.png|thumb|center|120px|Location of the [[New Siberian Islands]]]] |- style="background:#ffe8d5;" |align=center|[[File:Nikolai Vavilov NYWTS.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolai Vavilov]]'''
(1887â1943)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[botanist]] and [[geneticist]],explorer of the [[Vavilov Center|centres of origin]] of cultivated plants''' |Vavilov devoted his life to the study and improvement of [[wheat]], [[Maize|corn]], and other [[crops]] that sustain the [[global population]]. In 1924-35 he was the director of the [[All-Union]] Institute of [[Agricultural Sciences]] at [[Leningrad]]. Vavilov '''organized a series of botanical-agronomic expeditions, collected seeds from every corner of the globe, and created the world's largest collection of plant seeds''' in [[Leningrad]]. As a result of his long work and explorations he '''identified the [[Vavilov Center|centres of origin]] of main cultivated plants'''. During his journeys he had visited a number of virtually unknown regions of the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_we/vavilov_ni.php|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ¸Ð¾Ð³ÑÐ°ÑÐ¸ÑÐµÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ ÑÐºÐ°Ð·Ð°ÑÐµÐ»Ñ}}|work=hrono.ru|accessdate=2011-04-06|language=Russian}}

[[Institute of Plant Industry|N.I. Vavilov Institute of Plant Industry]] in [[St. Petersburg]], the Vavilov Award and the Vavilov Medal of the [[USSR Academy of Sciences]], [[Vavilovian mimicry]], [[Vavilov Center]], many plant species, scientific institutions, streets and settlements are named after [[Nikolai Vavilov]]. A meteostation and a glacier in [[October Revolution Island]] ([[Severnaya Zemlya]]), a [[minor planet]] [[2862 Vavilov]] and the [[Vavilov (crater)|Vavilov crater]] on the [[Moon]] are also named after him and his brother physicist [[Sergey Ivanovich Vavilov|Sergey Vavilov]]. |align=center|[[File:Vavilov-center.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Vavilov Center]]s: the origin of cultivated plants]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Boris Vilkitsky.jpg|90px]] |'''[[Boris Vilkitsky]]'''
(1885â1961)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|United Kingdom}}
{{flag|Belgium}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, hydrographer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1913-15 Vilkitsky led the [[Arctic]] hydrographic expedition on the [[icebreaker]]s [[Icebreaker Taymyr|''Taimyr'']] and [[Icebreaker Vaygach|''Vaigach'']], exploring the parts of the [[Northern Sea Route]]. In 1913, the expedition '''discovered [[Severnaya Zemlya]], the last archipelago on Earth to be explored'''. [[Vilkitsky Island]] also was discovered then, as well as [[Maly Taymyr]] and [[Starokadomsky Island]]s. In 1914-15, Vilkitsky's expedition '''made the first through voyage from [[Vladivostok]] to [[Arkhangelsk]]''', discovered Novopashenniy Island (now [[Zhokhova Island]]), and described the southern coastline of Severnaya Zemlya. In 1920 Vilkitsky emigrated to [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. Later he led commercial expeditions in the [[Kara Sea]] and was employed as a hydrographer in the [[Belgian Congo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/bio_we/vilkicky.html|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ¸Ð¾Ð³ÑÐ°ÑÐ¸ÑÐµÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ ÑÐºÐ°Ð·Ð°ÑÐµÐ»Ñ}}|work=hrono.ru|accessdate=2011-04-06|language=Russian}}

[[Vilkitsky Strait]] between Severnaya Zemlya and [[Taimyr Peninsula]], Vilkitsky bay of [[Novaya Zemlya]], two different Vilkitsky Islands subgroups of the [[Komsomolskaya Pravda Islands]] and [[Nordenskjold Archipelago]], [[Vilkitsky Island (Kara Sea)]], [[Vilkitsky Island (East Siberian Sea)]] and other objects were named after Vilkitsky. |align=center|[[File:Kara sea2SZ.PNG|thumb|center|120px|Location of [[Severnaya Zemlya]] in the [[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Vise 0.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vladimir Vize]]'''
(1886â1954)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''oceanographer, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1912-14 Vize took part in the [[Georgiy Sedov]]'s expedition to [[Novaya Zemlya]] and [[Franz Josef Land]]. In 1924 he studied the drift of [[Georgy Brusilov]]'s ill-fated Russian ship [[Svyataya Anna|''St. Anna'']], trapped on the [[pack ice]]. As a result of this study he '''predicted the location of yet unseen [[Vize Island]], based on the analysys of ice movement in the [[Kara Sea]]'''. Vize took part in a number of Soviet polar expeditions, including the first successful crossing of the [[Northern Sea Route]] in a single navigation on [[Icebreaker Sibiryakov|icebreaker ''Sibiryakov'']] in 1932. In 1938-40 Vize '''conducted the scientific research on the ice-captured [[icebreaker]] [[icebreaker Sedov|''Sedov'']], turned into a [[Soviet and Russian manned drifting ice stations|drifting ice station]]'''.

[[Vize Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]], a bay, a glacier and a point on [[Novaya Zemlya]], and a scientific vessel have been named after Vize. |align=center|[[File:Kara seaVZ.PNG|120px|thumb|center|[[Vize Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]]]] |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center| |'''[[Vladimir Voronin (captain)|Vladimir Voronin]]'''
(1890â1952)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
{{flag|Soviet Union}}

'''[[Soviet Navy]] captain, [[Arctic]] explorer''' |In 1932 Voronin commanded the expedition of the [[Soviet]] [[Icebreaker Sibiryakov|icebreaker ''Alexander Sibiryakov'']] which '''made the first successful crossing of the [[Northern Sea Route]] in a single navigation without wintering'''. In 65 days ''Sibiryakov'' sailed from [[Archangelsk]] to [[Yokohama]] in [[Japan]], having covered more than 2500 miles in the Arctic seas. In 1933-34 Voronin commanded less fortunate [[Chelyuskin steamship|''Cheliuskin'']] steamship with scientific expedition of [[Otto Schmidt]] aboard. The sheep became ice-bound in the [[Chukchi Sea]], but almost all the crew was resqued by planes from their camp on ice.{{cite web|url=http://www.biografija.ru/show_bio.aspx?id=19688|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ¾ÑÐ¾Ð½Ð¸Ð½ ÐÐ»Ð°Ð´Ð¸Ð¼Ð¸Ñ ÐÐ²Ð°Ð½Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Vladimir Ivanovich Voronin|publisher=biografija.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-06}}

[[Voronina Island]] in the [[Kara Sea]], Voronina [[shoal]] in the [[Gulf of Finland]], Voronin bay at [[Novaya Zemlya]], underwater Voronin Trough in the [[Arctic]] basin. |align=center|[[File:A Sibirykov.jpg|thumb|center|120px|[[Icebreaker Sibiryakov|Icebreaker ''Alexander Sibiryakov'']]]] | |} ===W=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |align=center|[[File:Admiral-Wrangel.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Ferdinand von Wrangel]]'''
(1797â1870)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}
(born in [[Estonia]], [[Baltic German]] descent)

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], [[Arctic]] explorer''' |Ferdinand Petrovich Wrangel took part in [[Vasily Golovnin]]'s [[world cruise]] on the ship ''[[Kamchatka]]'' in 1817-19. Subsequently Wrangel led the Kolymskaya expedition in 1820-24 in search of northern lands. He established that north of the [[Kolyma River]] there was an open sea, not dry land, as previously thought. Together with [[Fyodor Matyushkin]] and P. Kuzmin, Wrangel '''described the [[Medvyezhi Islands]] and [[East Siberian Sea]] coastline from the [[Indigirka River]] to the [[Kolyuchinskaya Bay]]''' in the [[Chukchi Sea]]. After noticing [[swarm]]s of birds flying north and questioning the native population, he determined that there must be an undiscovered island in the [[Arctic Ocean]]. Even though his search for it was unsuccessful the island was later named [[Wrangel Island]] to honour his endeavor. Wrangel led the Russian world voyage on the ship ''Krotky'' in 1825-27. He '''was the governor of [[Russian America]]''' in 1829-35, the president of the [[Russian-American Company]] in 1840-49 and the [[Heads of military of Imperial Russia#Ministry of Sea Forces|Minister of the Navy]] in 1855-57. In 1845 he became one of the founders of the [[Russian Geographic Society]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vehi.net/brokgauz/index.html|publisher=Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary|title={{lang|ru|ÐÑÐ°Ð½Ð³ÐµÐ»Ñ, Ð¤ÐµÑÐ´Ð¸Ð½Ð°Ð½Ð´ ÐÐµÑÑÐ¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|trans_title=Ferdinand Petrovich Wrangel|accessdate=2011-04-05|language=Russian}}

[[Wrangel Island]] north of [[Chukchi Peninsula|Chukotka]], [[Wrangell Island]] in [[Alexander Archipelago]] near [[Alaska]] and [[Wrangell, Alaska|a city]] there, [[Wrangell Narrows]] channel in the Alexander Archipelago, [[Cape Wrangell]] of [[Attu Island]] (the westernmost point of Alaska and the continental [[USA]]) and [[Mount Wrangell]] (a [[volcano]] in Alaska) were named after Wrangel. |align=center|[[File:Medvyezhi map.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Medvyezhi Islands]] in the [[East Siberian Sea]]]][[File:Siberia WR.png|thumb|center|120px|Location of the [[Wrangel Island]] in the [[Arctic]]]] |} ===Y=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#ffffd0;" |align=center|[[File:Nikolai Yadrintsev, Russian public figure, explorer, archaeologist.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Nikolai Yadrintsev]]'''
(1842â1894)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''public figure, archaeologist, and [[turkologist]], explorer of [[Siberia]] and [[Central Asia]]''' |Under a contract with Russian Geographical Society, Yadrintsev twice traveled across [[Siberia]] and [[Altai Republic|Altai]], researching economy and geography, archeology and ethnography, anthropology and linguistics. In 1889 he '''located the remains of medieval city Hara-Balgas and the [[Genghis Khan]]'s capital [[Karakorum]] in [[Mongolia]]'''. In the valley of the [[Orkhon River]] Yadrintsev''' discovered the [[Orkhon script]] of ancient TÃ¼rks''' on two petroglyphic monuments with runiform writing, later decoded by the Danish scientist [[Vilhelm Thomsen]]. In 1891 Yadrintsev took part in the expedition led by [[turkologist]] academician [[Vasily Radlov]], finding more monuments of TÃ¼rkic runiform writing.{{cite web|url=http://www.altaiinter.info/project/culture/Researchers/Personnels/Jadrincev/jadr01.htm|work=altaiinter.info|title=Yadrintsev's biography|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-05}}

A number of streets in Siberian cities and a settlement in [[Omsk Oblast]] were named after Yadrintsev. |[[File:Karakorum - Tortue Sud.jpg|thumb|center|120px|An ancient stone turtle in [[Karakorum]], [[Mongolia]]]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Yermak Timofeyevich.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Yermak Timofeyevich]]'''
(1532-42 â 1585)
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Grand Duchy of Moscow]]
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]

'''[[Cossack]] [[ataman]], [[folk hero]], explorer of [[West Siberian Plain|West Siberia]] and conqueror of [[Siberia Khanate]]''' |Around 1577, the merchants [[Stroganovs]], who were the main colonisers of the [[Urals]], hired the [[Cossack]] leader [[Yermak]] to protect their lands from attacks of the Siberian [[Khan (title)|Khan]] [[Kuchum]]. In 1581 Yermak began his voyage into the depths of [[Siberia]]. After a few victories over the khan's army, Yermak's people defeated Kuchum's main forces on [[Irtysh River]] after a 3-day battle [[Battle of Chuvash Cape]] in 1582. The remains of the khan's army retreated to the [[steppes]] and Yermak '''captured the [[Siberia Khanate]]''', including its capital [[Qashliq]] near modern [[Tobolsk]]. Kuchum still was strong and suddenly attacked Yermak in 1585 in the dead of night, killing most of his people. Yermak was wounded and tried to swim across the Wagay River ([[Irtysh]]'s tributary), but drowned under the weight of his own [[Mail (armour)|chain mail]]. Russians had to withdraw from Siberia completely, but thanks to Yermak's having '''explored all the main river routes of central [[West Siberian Plain|West Siberia]]''', they successfully returned all Yermak's conquests just several years later.{{cite web|url=http://ring-siberia.ru/ermak|publisher={{lang|ru|ÐÐ¾Ð»ÑÑÐ¾ Ð¡Ð¸Ð±Ð¸ÑÐ¸}}|title=Yermak. The Conquest of Siberia|accessdate=2011-04-05|language=Russian}}

''[[Icebreaker Yermak|Yermak]]'', the first true [[icebreaker]] able to crush [[pack ice]], was named after Yermak, as well as [[Yermak Stone]] in [[Perm Krai]] and a number of streets and settlements. Yermak's life and death have been subjects for numerous Russian songs, books, and paintings since the 16th century. In 1995 a historical [[biopic]] ''Yermak'' was shot. |align=center|[[File:YermakLubok.jpg|thumb|center|120px|''[[Russian conquest of Siberia|Yermak Timofeyevich the Conqueror of Siberia]]'', [[lubok]]]][[File:Ob watershed.png|thumb|center|120px|[[Ob']]-[[Irtysh]] basin]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" | |'''[[Ivan Yevreinov]]'''
(?â1724)
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.svg|22px]] [[PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth|Poland-Lithuania]]
[[File:Coat of arms of Russia (XV Century).svg|22px]] [[Tsardom of Russia]]
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''cartographer, geodesist, explorer of [[Siberia]] and the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1719-1721, together with [[Fyodor Luzhin]], Yevreinov '''made the first instrumental mapping of [[Kamchatka]] and the first map of the [[Kuril Islands]]''' during the "secret expedition", as ordered by [[Peter I of Russia]]. In 1723-24 he mapped [[Khlynov]] region near [[Kirov Oblast|Vyatka]].{{cite web|url=http://www.npacific.ru/np/library/encicl/6/0001.htm|work=npacific.ru|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ²ÑÐµÐ¸Ð½Ð¾Ð² ÐÐ²Ð°Ð½ ÐÐ¸ÑÐ°Ð¹Ð»Ð¾Ð²Ð¸Ñ}}|accessdate=2011-04-05|language=Russian}}

A strait between [[Makanrushi]] and [[Onekotan]] in the [[Kurils]], a mountain, and a peninsula in the [[Okhotsk Sea]] are named after Yevreinov. |align=center|[[File:ÐÑÐ¾Ð»Ð¸Ð²Ñ ÐÑÑÐ¸Ð»ÑÑÐºÐ¸Ñ Ð¾ÑÑÑÐ¾Ð²Ð¾Ð² Ð¡ÐµÐ²ÐµÑ.png|120px|center|thumb|Northern [[Kurils]], showing Yevreinov and [[Luzhin Strait]]s]] |} ===Z=== {{Compact TOC}} {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" !width=18%|Portrait !width=22%|Person !width=60%|Achievements !Image |- style="background:#dfdfff;" |align=center|[[File:Lavrenty Zagoskin.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Lavrenty Zagoskin]]'''
(1808â1890)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, naturalist, explorer of [[Alaska]]''' |Commissioned by [[Russian America Company]], in 1842-44 Zagoskin '''traveled extensively in [[Alaska]]''', covering more than 3300 miles. He explored and mapped the [[Yukon River|Yukon]], [[Kuskokwim River|Kuskokwim]], [[Innoko River|Innoko]] and [[Koyukuk River]]s, researched the native peoples and nature of the region. He '''published the first detailed description of the inner areas of [[Alaska]]'''.{{cite book|author=Henry N.|year=1967|title=Lieutenant Zagoskin's Travels in Russian America|publisher=University Of Toronto Press|asin=B000J00FME|accessdate=2011-04-05}}

 |align=center|[[File:Yukon watershed.png|120px|thumb|center|[[Yukon River]] basin]] |- style="background:#dfffdf;" |align=center|[[File:Zavoyko VS.jpg|100px]] |'''[[Vasily Zavoyko]]'''
(1809â1898)
{{flag|Russian Empire}}

'''[[Russian Imperial Navy]] officer, [[Admiral]], circumnavigator, explorer of the [[Russian Far East]]''' |In 1835â38 Zavoyko twice circumnavigated the globe. After 1840, during his service for the [[Russian-American Company]] in the [[Okhotsk Sea]], Zavoyko '''explored the [[estuary]] of the [[Amur River]]'''. His reports led to further expeditions and ultimately the incorporation of [[Primorsky Krai]] into Russia. In 1854, at the time of [[Crimean War]], as a governor of [[Kamchatka]] Zavoyko led the successful defence during the [[Siege of Petropavlovsk]]. He repelled the superior allied [[United Kingdom|British]]-[[France|French]] forces and even captured the [[Union Jack|British banner]]. In 1855, making the way through the frozen seas and successfully avoiding the large enemy fleet, he supervised the transfer of the [[Russian Pacific Fleet]] from Petropavlovsk to [[Nikolayevsk-on-Amur]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vehi.net/brokgauz/index.html|publisher=[[Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary]]|title={{lang|ru|ÐÐ°Ð²Ð¾Ð¹ÐºÐ¾}}|trans_title=Savoyko|language=Russian|accessdate=2011-04-05}}

A settlement near [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky]] (now a city district) is named after Zavoyko. |align=center|[[File:Petropavlovsk center port.jpg|120px|thumb|center|Modern view of [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky|Petropavlovsk]] on [[Kamchatka]]]] |} ==See also== {{Div col|3}} * [[1966 Soviet submarine global circumnavigation]] * [[Arctic policy of Russia]] * [[First Russian circumnavigation]] * [[Geography of Russia]] * [[Great Northern Expedition]] * [[List of explorers]] * [[List of Russian Admirals]] * [[List of Russian aviators]] * [[Northern Sea Route]] * [[Russian culture]] * [[Russian Geographical Society]] * [[Soviet Antarctic Expedition]]s * [[Siberian River Routes|Siberian river routes]] * [[Soviet space program]] {{Div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Exploration|state=collapsed}} {{Lists of Russians|state=uncollapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Russian Explorers}} [[Category:Russian people|Explorers]] [[Category:Russian explorers| ]] [[Category:Explorers by nationality]] [[Category:Lists of Russian people|Explorers]] [[Category:Lists of explorers]]
